ARTICLE III. - CONTRACTS GENERALLY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Purchasing and contracts, Art. XIII. 
State Law reference- Model payment and performance bond, G.S. § 44A-25 et seq.; monopolies, trusts and consumer protection, G.S. Ch. 75; regulation of contractors for public works, G.S. § 133-23 et seq.; public building contracts, G.S. § 143-128 et seq.; power of city to contract and be contracted with, G.S. § 160A-11; municipal contracts, G.S. § 160A-16 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-36. - Contract execution. 
(a)  All contracts for the construction, repair work, or purchase of apparatus, supplies, materials, or equipment requiring the estimated expenditure of public money in an amount equal to or more than the limit set forth in G.S. § 143-129 shall be awarded by the city council using the formal bid procedure, or shall otherwise be in compliance with G.S. 143-129. Such award shall constitute authority for the mayor or city manager to execute all documents required in conjunction with such contract on behalf of the city council. 
(b)  All contracts, regardless of the amount of expenditure, shall be awarded by the city council and executed by the mayor when so required by state or federal law. 
(c)  Contracts of any amount for the purchase of gasoline, diesel fuel, alcohol fuel, motor oil, fuel oil, or natural gas may be awarded and executed by the city manager, subject to compliance with G.S. § 143-131. 
(d)  Contracts for sponsorships of city facilities, programs, or services may be awarded and executed by the city manager pursuant to city policy as set forth by city council. 
(e)  Contracts for construction or repair work requiring the estimated expenditure of public money in an amount less than the limit set forth in G.S. § 143-129 may be awarded and executed by the city manager. All other contracts of any nature not addressed by the above subsections, and having a value of less than ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00), may be awarded and executed by the city manager. Contracts not addressed by this, or any of the above subsections, having a value of ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00) or greater, shall be awarded by the city council. 
(f)  Contract amendments and change orders. The city manager may award and execute contract amendments and change orders, of any nature or in any combination, number, or cumulative amount, so long as the original contract budget or value authorized or amended by city council is not increased by more than the amount the city manager could have authorized had the amendment or change order been an original contract of the same nature. The city manager shall report the execution of any contract amendments or change orders having the value of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more, including the amount and purpose, to the city council on a monthly basis. 
(g)  Emergencies. G.S. § 143-129(e)(2) provides an exception to the standard procedural requirements for contracting in cases of special emergency involving the health and safety of people or their property. If, during the existence of a proclaimed state of emergency, the expeditious award of contracts involving the health and safety of the people or their property are reasonably necessary to address the emergency, the city manager is authorized to award contracts without regard to the amount of such contract in compliance with the requirements of G.S. 143-129(e)(2). As soon as reasonably possible after the state of emergency has ended, any contracts executed by the city manager pursuant to this emergency exception shall be placed on a city council meeting agenda for ratification and approval by council. 
(h)  In exercising the authority to contract granted in this section 2-36, the city manager shall not enter into any contract unless: 
(1)  The city council shall have approved a sufficient appropriation therefor in the annual budget for the current fiscal year, in compliance with the Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act; and 
(2)  The city attorney shall have approved such contract as to form. 
(i)  In all cases, the applicable provisions of the city charter and Chapter 143 of the North Carolina General Statutes shall be followed. The city manager is authorized to take any action, other than the award of a contract that is required to be done by the governing board, which the city council is authorized to take under Article 3D or Article 8 of Chapter 143 of the North Carolina General Statutes in making, approving, awarding, exempting, or executing contracts. Such authority includes, by way of illustration and not limitation, the authority to waive the requirements for a performance bond when the city manager determines the company to whom the contract is awarded has a good reputation for performing such contracts and that the company appears to have the financial capacity to fulfill the requirements of the contract. Nothing contained herein shall limit or otherwise alter the lawful authority of either the mayor, the city manager or his designee to execute grant agreements on behalf of the city for the receipt of funds and to make the necessary assurances contained therein. 
(Code 1962, § 2-80; Ord. of 1-11-8, § 2; Ord. of 2-22-83, § 1; Ord. of 8-21-90, § 1; Ord. of 11-7-00, § 1; Ord. No. O-2018-72, § 1, 11-20-18) 
State Law reference- Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act, G.S. § 159-7 et seq.; public building contracts, G.S. § 143-128 et seq.; grants from other governments, G.S. § 160A-17.1. 
Sec. 2-37. - Contract administration. 
    The city manager shall be responsible for supervising the performance of all contracts entered into by the city, whether awarded by the city council or by the city manager. 
(Code 1962, § 2-81; Ord. of 1-11-83, § 1) 
Secs. 2-38-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BIDS BY CONTRACTORS, ETC. 

Sec. 2-51. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, the following terms shall have the meanings stated: 
    Bid-rigging: The act of engaging in any conspiracy, combination or any other act in restraint of trade or commerce declared to be unlawful by provisions of G.S. sections 75-1 and 75-2, or engaging in similar unlawful actions. 
    Contractor: Any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, association, subsidiary, affiliate or other entity formed to do business as a contractor or subcontractor, or any officer, director, employee or agent of a contractor. 
(Code 1962, § 2-71; Ord. of 7-26-83, § 2; Ord. of 7-24-84, § 1) 
Sec. 2-52. - Policy; applicability. 
(a)  The city council may suspend from bidding any contractor which the city has determined, in its discretion, does not meet the statutory criteria of being "lowest responsible bidder," as set forth in G.S. section 143-129 or "reputable and qualified," as set forth in G.S. section 143-132. The city may suspend from bidding any contractor convicted of or indicted for any of the offenses enumerated in G.S. section 133-24, or of similar charges. 
(b)  The provisions of this division apply to bids solicited for award of contracts for the purchase of equipment, goods, services, supplies or materials, or for construction or repair let or to be let by the city council or the city manager. 
(c)  The provisions of this division apply also to all subcontracts for the purchase of equipment, goods, services, supplies or materials, or for construction or repair, either with a prime contractor or proposed prime contractor for the city, or with any affiliate or subsidiary thereof. 
(Code 1962, § 2-70; Ord. of 7-26-83, § 1) 
Sec. 2-53. - Source of funding; preemption. 
    Where bids are solicited for a project or purchase wholly or partially funded by state or federal funds, any regulations imposed by the state or federal agency under the terms of a contract granting the use of such funds for the project or purchase under bid may supersede the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1962, § 2-72) 
Sec. 2-54. - Disqualification of bids. 
(a)  The city council shall reject a bid for failure to qualify as lowest responsible bidder, as defined in G.S. section 143-129, when, during the course of solicitation of the bids and prior to award, it is determined that the bidder has been indicted for or convicted of a violation of G.S. section 133-24. 
(b)  The city manager, or the purchasing agent designated pursuant to section 8.3(i) of the city charter, shall reject a bid solicited pursuant to G.S. section 143-131 for failure to qualify as lowest responsible bidder, as defined in G.S. section 143-131, when, during the course of securing the bids and prior to award, it is determined that the bidder has been indicted for or convicted of a violation of G.S. section 133-24. 
(Code 1962, § 2-73) 
Sec. 2-55. - Affidavit and certificate of noncollusion, nonsuspension, and nonconviction. 
    Prior to submission of a bid or award of a contract by the city to a contractor, the city manager may require the contractor to submit to the city a signed affidavit and certificate verifying noncollusion and nonsuspension by state or federal governmental agencies for bid-rigging and nonconviction for bid-rigging in any federal court or a court of this or any other state. Noncompliance with such requirement may constitute grounds for disqualification of the bid. 
(Code 1962, § 2-74; Ord. of 7-24-84, § 2) 
State Law reference- Noncollusion affidavits, G.S. § 133-30. 
Sec. 2-56. - Contractor under indictment. 
(a)  The city council may, by resolution, temporarily suspend from bidding any contractor who is charged in an indictment or an information with bid-rigging or a similar charge in any federal or state court until the charges are resolved. Such action shall be taken only after the contractor has been notified in writing by the city manager, at least ten (10) days prior to taking action, that the council will consider a temporary suspension at a specific time and date. 
(b)  A contractor who has been notified that the city council will consider enacting a temporary suspension may request an opportunity to be heard before such action is taken by notifying the city clerk, in writing, not less than twenty-four (24) hours before the scheduled time for action. Such opportunity to be heard shall not be in the nature of a public hearing, and shall be governed by the provisions of G.S. section 143-318.11(a)(9). 
(Code 1962, § 2-75) 
State Law reference- Executive sessions of public bodies, G.S. § 143-318.11. 
Sec. 2-57. - Suspension following conviction. 
    Any contractor who has been convicted, pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere on a charge of bid-rigging or similar charges in any federal court, or a court of this or any other state, and has been suspended from bidding on state or federal contracts, shall be suspended from bidding on city contracts for the purchase of equipment, goods, or services, or for construction or repair, during the period of the state and/or federal suspension, but not less than a period of one (1) year from the date of the conviction or plea. 
(Code 1962, § 2-76; Ord. of 7-24-84, § 3; Ord. of 11-26-85, § 1) 
State Law reference- Municipalities authorized to suspend contractors convicted of bid-rigging, G.S. § 133-27. 
Secs. 2-58, 2-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PREQUALIFICATION STANDARDS FOR CONTRACTORS BIDDING ON CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS 

Sec. 2-60. - Prequalification required. 
    In accordance with G.S. § 143-135.8, prequalification, the city shall utilize the prequalification process when it is determined by the city engineer and project manager to be necessary based upon the need to assess a contractor's technical capability to complete the tasks of a complex project's scope of work. The project manager shall use the process outlined in administrative policy 116: contractor prequalification policy and standard operating procedure for the prequalification of contractors. A contractor shall not be allowed to submit a bid on a construction project subject to prequalification unless it has been prequalified in accordance with the city's policy. 
(Ord. of 3-7-00, § 1; Ord. No. O-2017-27, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 2-61. - Prequalifying standards. 
    The prequalification review standards include but are not limited to: 
(1)  The prospective bidder's skill and business judgment as exemplified by previous project work. 
(2)  The financial integrity of the firm. 
(3)  The experience of the bidding firm and its management team on previous projects of similar scope, complexity and value. Specifically, information will be sought to establish the firm's project management ability with projects of similar difficulty, i.e.: scheduling abilities, throughout the project that displays a working knowledge of planning, coordination, and effective management of construction projects. 
(4)  The bidding firm's resources and facilities for carrying out the contract. Specifically of interest will be the abilities of the firm with respect to manpower, equipment (where relevant), credit-worthiness, bonding, licensure, capital, etc. 
(5)  The firm's previous conduct under other contracts, with specific reference to cooperation with other prime contractors, architects, engineers, owners, and subcontractors, and prompt payment of subcontractors and suppliers. 
(6)  The quality exemplified in previous project work whether by the bidder's own forces or by a subcontractor. 
(7)  The ability of the firm to perform the type of work required by the project. 
(Ord. of 3-7-00, § 1; Ord. No. O-2017-27, 4-18-17) 
Sec. 2-62. - Appeal rights. 
    Any firm denied prequalification under this section shall have the opportunity to protest that denial through the process outlined in city administrative policy 116. The appeals process shall be completed prior to the opening of the bids. 
(Ord. of 3-7-00, § 1; Ord. No. O-2017-27, 4-18-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2017-27, adopted April 18, 2017, repealed the former § 2-62 and amended and renumbered § 2-63 as § 2-62, as set out herein. The former § 2-62 pertained to disqualification of bidders and derived from Ord. of March 7, 2000, § 1. 
Secs. 2-63-2-70. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- See editor's note to section 2-62.

ARTICLE V. - COMMUNITY APPEARANCE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-92. - Creation and composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created an appearance commission to be composed of fifteen (15) members who shall reside within the city limits. 
(b)  The members of the appearance commission shall be appointed by the council. 
(c)  Each member shall be appointed for a period of three (3) years; except that the council, in naming the original members of the commission, may prescribe terms of fewer years to the end that the terms of the various members of such commission may be staggered. 
(d)  Appointments to the commission shall be made in such manner as to maintain a majority of members with expertise in the art and science of design. Toward that end and to the extent possible, one (1) appointment shall be made from the staff or boards of each of the following organizations: Arts Council of the Lower Cape Fear; Downtown Area Revitalization Efforts, Inc.; Garden Club Council of New Hanover County; New Hanover County Museum; St. Johns Art Gallery. The remaining ten (10) members shall be appointed from the city at large and shall include persons with the expertise, interests or training indicated above. 
(e)  Members of the commission shall serve without pay; except such members may be reimbursed for actual expenses incidental to the performance of their duties within the limits of any fund allocated for such purposes by the council. 
(Ord. of 7-24-84, § I) 
Sec. 2-93. - Powers and procedure. 
(a)  Upon its appointment, the commission shall make a careful study of the visual aspects of the city and shall make plans and carry out programs that will enhance and improve the visual quality and aesthetic characteristics of such areas within the scope of the powers herein granted. Toward that end, the commission may organize subcommittees dedicated to particular facets of this program, such as city beautification and art acquisition. 
(b)  Powers of the community appearance commission shall include among others those powers and duties outlined in G. S. 160A-452(1), (2), (3) and (4). 
(c)  The commission may recommend to the council suitable arrangements for the procurement or provision of staff or technical services for the commission. 
(d)  The commission shall, no later than April 15 of each year, submit to the council a written report of its activities, a statement of its expenditures to date for the current fiscal year, and its requested budget for the next fiscal year. All accounts and funds of the commission shall be administered substantially in accordance with the requirements of the Local Government Finance Act (G. S. § 159-1 et seq.]. 
(e)  The commission may receive contributions from private agencies, foundations, organizations, individuals and the state or federal government, or any other source in addition to any sums, appropriated for its use by the council. It may accept and disburse these funds for any purpose within the scope of its authority as herein specified. 
(Ord. of 7-24-84, § I) 
Secs. 2-94, 2-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TAX ON SHORT-TERM VEHICLE RENTALS 

Sec. 2-96. - Definition. 
    In addition to the common meaning of words, the following definitions shall be applicable herein: 
    Customer shall mean any person that leases or rents a vehicle on a short-term lease or rental basis. 
    General Statutes shall refer to the North Carolina General Statutes and any reference to a particular section thereof shall include the same as may be from time to time amended, modified, supplemented, revised or superseded. 
    Gross receipts shall mean the amount that is or would be reported as gross receipts on a state income tax return of a business, or on the federal income tax return filed with the state income tax return if the state return does not separately state gross receipts for the most recently completed tax year. Taxes collected hereunder are not subject to the tax herein imposed and are not included in gross receipts. 
    Lease or rental shall mean a transfer, for consideration, of the use but not the ownership of property to another for a period of time. 
    Long-term lease or rental shall mean a lease or rental made under a written agreement to lease or rent property to the same person for a period of at least three hundred sixty-five (365) continuous days. 
    Person shall mean any individual, trustee, executor, other fiduciary, corporation, unincorporated association, partnership, sole proprietorship, company, firm, or other legal entity. 
    Short-term lease or rental shall mean any lease or rental of a vehicle that is not a long-term lease or rental. 
    Tax collector shall refer to that individual appointed by the city council pursuant to section 9.4 of the Wilmington City Charter to collect taxes on behalf of the city and any other person authorized to carry out the duties and functions of such individual. 
    Taxpayer means any person liable for the taxes imposed by this article. 
    Vehicle shall mean any of the following: 
(1)  A motor vehicle of the private passenger type including a passenger van, minivan or sport utility vehicle. 
(2)  A motor vehicle of the cargo type, including a cargo van, pickup truck, or truck with a gross vehicle weight of twenty-six thousand (26,000) pounds or less used predominately in the transportation of property for other than commercial freight, and that does not require the operator to possess a commercial drivers license. 
(3)  A trailer or semitrailer with a gross vehicle weight of six thousand (6,000) pounds or less. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-97. - Levy of tax. 
    A tax is hereby imposed and levied in an amount equal to one and one-half (11/2) percent of the gross receipts derived from the short-term lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public. This tax on gross receipts is in addition to the privilege taxes authorized by G.S. § 160A-211. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-98. - Collection of the tax. 
    Every person engaged in the business of the short-term lease or rental of vehicles at retail to the general public shall collect at the time of the lease or rental the tax herein levied, place the tax so collected in a segregated account, and thereafter remit such tax to the tax collector in accordance with the provisions of this article. The taxpayer shall include a provision in each retail short-term lease or rental agreement stating that the percentage amount enacted by this article of the total lease or rental price, excluding sales tax, is being charged as a tax on gross receipts. The amount of the tax shall be stated separately from the lease or rental and shown separately on the taxpayer's records. The tax shall be paid by the customer to the taxpayer as trustee for and on account of the city. The taxpayer shall be liable for the collection thereof and for its payment to the tax collector and the taxpayer's failure to charge or to collect said tax from the customer shall not affect such liability. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-99. - Report and payment of tax. 
    Taxes levied under this article are due and payable when a return is required to be filed. Every taxpayer shall, within the time specified, submit a return to the tax collector on the form prescribed by the tax collector. A return must be signed by the taxpayer or the taxpayer's agent. Returns of taxpayers are due to the tax collector each month on or before the fifteenth day of the month following the month in which the taxes accrues. As provided in G.S. 160A-208.1, a return shall not be considered a public record and information contained in a return may be disclosed only in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-100. - Taxpayer to keep records. 
    The taxpayer shall keep and preserve suitable records of the gross receipts received by such taxpayer in the conduct of business and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of the tax for which such taxpayer is liable under the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the taxpayer to keep and preserve for a period of three (3) years all such records of gross receipts and other books and accounts described. All records, books and accounts herein described shall be open for examination at all reasonable hours during the day by the tax collector or his duly authorized agent. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-101. - Tax collector to provide forms. 
    The tax collector shall design, prepare, print and make available to all taxpayers operating within the municipal boundaries of the city, forms and instructions for filing returns to insure a full collection of and an accounting for taxes due. The failure of any taxpayer to obtain or receive forms shall not relieve such taxpayer from the payment of the tax at the time and in the manner provided. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-102. - Situs. 
    The transaction giving rise to the tax herein levied shall be deemed to have occurred at the location of the entity from which the customer takes delivery of the vehicle. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-103. - Penalties and remedies. 
    The provisions with respect to remedies and penalties applicable to Subchapter VIII (Local Government Sales and Use Tax) of G.S. Ch. 105, as contained in Arts. 5 and 9, Subchapter 1, Chapter 105 thereof, shall be applicable in like manner to the tax authorized to be levied and collected under this article, to the extent that the same are not inconsistent with the provisions hereof. The governing body of the city may exercise any power the secretary of revenue may exercise in collecting sales and use taxes. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Sec. 2-104. - Administration. 
    In addition to the provisions herein the levy and collection of the taxes herein imposed shall be otherwise administered in the same manner as the sales and use tax as provided in G.S. Ch. 105, Art. 5, Subchapter 1. 
(Ord. of 10-17-00, § 1) 
Chapter 3 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Penalties and remedies. 
(a)  A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in G.S. § 14-4. 
(b)  A violation of any of the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code shall be a misdemeanor and punishable as set forth in G.S. § 143-138. 
(c)  A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code shall subject the offender to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first violation, three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the second violation, and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the third and subsequent violations, except as follows: 
(1)  Any violation for blocked, obstructed or locked exit doors or any other violations for blocked egress shall subject the offender to a civil penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per blocked exit for the first violation, one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per blocked exit for the second violation and one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for the third and subsequent violations. 
(2)  Any violation of overcrowding or any other manner of exceeding the posted occupancy shall subject the offender to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per person in excess of the posted occupancy. 
(d)  If a person fails to pay the civil penalties set forth herein within fifteen (15) days after being cited for a violation, the city may seek to recover the penalties by filing a civil action in the nature of a debt. If any offender fails to pay the civil penalty set forth in subsection (c) within fifteen (15) days after being cited for a violation and notified of the penalty, the offender shall be subject to an additional penalty of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(e)  Each day that a violation of Chapter 8 of the Fire Prevention Code or the NFiPA Life Safety Code continues after the offender has been notified of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. Each day that a violation of any other provision of the Fire Prevention Code or this chapter continues after the expiration of the time for the correction of such a violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(f)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter through any appropriate equitable action. 
(g)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter by using any one (1) or any combination of the foregoing remedies. The issuance of a civil citation shall not preclude the issuance of a criminal summons or arrest warrant where deemed appropriate. 
(Code 1962, § 1-6; Ord. of 5-17-89, § 1; Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1; Ord. of 4-21-98, § 2; Ord. No. 0-2002-30, § 1(a), 5-21-02; Ord. No. O-2009-9, §§ 1, 2, 2-3-09) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prescribe penalties for breach of ordinances, § 1.4(47). 
State Law reference- Enforcement of ordinances, G.S. § 160A-175. 
Sec. 3-2. - Obstructing hydrant. 
    No person shall obstruct, with building material or otherwise, any hydrant or fireplug in the city, in such manner as to interfere with or obstruct the easy approach to the same or its convenient use by the fire department. 
(Code 1962, § 9-2; Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
Sec. 3-3. - Interfering with firemen. 
    No person shall obstruct or interfere with any member of the fire department or the work of the fire department at or during a fire or while answering an alarm of fire. 
(Code 1962, § 9-1; Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
State Law reference- Assault with deadly weapon on fireman, G.S. § 14-34.2; interference with fireman, G.S. § 69-39. 
Secs. 3-4-3-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Fire prevention code, § 24.5. 
  County Code reference- Fire prevention code, § 8-16 et seq. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Technical ordinances, G.S. § 160A-76. 

Sec. 3-16. - Fire Prevention Code. 
(a)  As provided by G.S. Chapter 143, the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, adopted by the North Carolina Building Code Council, including all subsequent amendments or revisions duly adopted, shall be applicable and enforced within the corporate limits of the City of Wilmington. The North Carolina Fire Prevention Code shall be referred to in this Chapter as the "Fire Prevention Code". 
(b)  The listed standards and publications which comprise a part of the Fire Prevention Code, as the same may be periodically revised and updated, shall be applicable and enforced within the city. 
(c)  An official copy of the Fire Prevention Code, and revisions thereto, shall be maintained in the office of the fire department, bureau of fire prevention. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1; Ord. No. 0-2002-30, § 1(b), 5-21-02) 
Sec. 3-17. - Establishment, duties of bureau of fire prevention. 
(a)  The Fire Prevention Code referred to in section 3-16 shall be enforced by the bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city, which bureau is hereby established and which shall be operated under the supervision of the chief of the fire department. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department, with the approval of the city manager, shall designate an officer or member of the fire department to serve as chief of the bureau of fire prevention at the pleasure of the chief of the fire department and the city manager. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department may detail such members of the fire department as fire prevention inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. Such inspectors shall be certified as required by G.S. Ch. 143. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention and the fire prevention inspectors shall have the duties and responsibilities of the fire official as set forth in the Fire Prevention Code, including the duty to issue orders to correct violations of this chapter and the Fire Prevention Code, to issue civil citations for such violations and to bring judicial actions against actual or threatened violations of this chapter and the Fire Prevention Code. 
(d)  The annual report of the bureau of fire prevention shall be made on or before the first day of August and transmitted to the city manager. It shall contain all proceedings under this chapter and the Fire Prevention Code, with such statistics as the chief of the fire department may wish to include therein. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
Sec. 3-18. - Appeals. 
(a)  If any owner, lessee or occupant of any building covered by this chapter shall deem himself or herself aggrieved by any ruling or order of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention or any fire prevention inspector pursuant hereto, he or she may request, in writing within ten (10) working days after written notice of the ruling or order, that the ruling or order be reviewed by the chief of the fire department. The ruling or order under review shall be stayed pending the outcome of the review, unless the chief of the bureau of fire prevention certifies to the fire chief that there is distinct fire hazard to life or property. The chief of the fire department shall review the ruling or order and make written notification of the results of that review to the owner, lessee or occupant within ten (10) working days after receipt of the request. The chief of the fire department may, as a result of this review, uphold, rescind or modify the order of the chief of the bureau of fire prevention or the fire prevention inspector. 
(b)  Except for rulings or orders pertaining to the Fire Prevention Code, after review by the chief of the fire department, if the owner or lessee still deems himself or herself aggrieved, he or she may request in writing, within ten (10) working days, a conference with the city manager to review the ruling or order. The city manager shall set a time and place for such conference, to occur within thirty (30) days of receipt of such request. As a result of the conference, the city manager may uphold, rescind or modify the ruling or order which is the subject of the conference. The ruling or order of the city manager shall be final. 
(c)  Any appeal from the final decision of the chief of department relating to an order, decision, determination or ruling pertaining to the Fire Prevention Code, including the assessment of a civil penalty for a violation thereof, shall be as provided in G.S. 160A-434. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
Sec. 3-19. - Outside fire protection systems. 
(a)  Outside fire protection systems shall be required as set out in this section. As used herein, the term "outside fire protection system" includes underground piping systems together with hydrants and other appurtenances thereto use for fire protection purposes. Existing outside fire protection systems shall be considered to meet these requirements until such time as: 
(1)  Water supply mains are extended, modified or altered; 
(2)  The building is enlarged or modified, for which a building permit must be issued; or 
(3)  The chief of the fire prevention bureau determines that the existing protection for a given building, block or area is not within the minimum acceptable standards established by the insurance services office of North Carolina. 
(b)  Outside fire protection systems placed on public property shall be installed in accordance with chapters 12 and 18 of the Code and the Fire Prevention Code. 
(c)  Outside fire protection systems placed on private property shall be installed in accordance with standards published by the National Fire Protection Association (hereafter "NFiPA") as referenced in the Fire Prevention Code. 
(d)  Fire hydrants shall be installed in sufficient number to provide two (2) streams for every part of the interior of each building not covered by standpipe protection and to provide hose stream protection for every exterior part of each building by the use of lengths of hose usually attached to the hydrants but not less than five hundred (500) feet. There shall be sufficient hydrants to concentrate the required fire flow about any building with the hose line length not to exceed three hundred (300) feet (ninety-one and five-tenths (91.5) meters) in nonresidential districts and in multi-family developments, and five hundred (500) feet (one hundred fifty-two and five-tenths (152.5) meters) in single family residential districts. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
Sec. 3-20. - Placarding of facilities handling hazardous materials. 
(a)  NFiPA Standard 704 entitled "Standard System for the Identification of Fire Hazards of Materials," as amended from time to time, shall be applicable within the city as provided by the Fire Prevention Code. 
(b)  The owner or operator of any facility in the city engaged in the manufacturing, storage or use of hazardous materials shall display symbols on the facilities in accordance with NFiPA 704. The symbols shall be located so they can be readily seen by responding fire companies and emergency personnel and shall be located as near as practical to the area of the hazard. The location and size of the symbol shall be determined by the chief of the bureau of fire prevention. 
(c)  The symbols required by this section shall be maintained to indicate changes in the areas of storage or use of hazardous materials. The symbols shall be removed from the facility when hazardous materials are no longer present. 
(d)  For the purpose of this chapter, hazardous materials shall mean any substances covered by the North Carolina Hazardous Chemical Right To Know Law (G.S. 95-173, et seq.) or the "U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970." 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
Sec. 3-21. - Permits for hazardous materials and fire hazard activities. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any facility in the city engaged in the manufacturing, storage or use of hazardous materials or engaged in operations which produce conditions considered to present an extra or unusual fire hazard to life or property shall obtain a permit from the fire department prior to the commencement of such activities. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, permits shall be required for the following activities: 
(1)  Storage of hazardous materials in buildings. 
(2)  Above-ground storage of flammable or hazardous material. 
(3)  Below ground storage of flammable or hazardous material. 
(4)  The storage, use or handling of explosive materials. 
(5)  Aerial display of fireworks. 
(6)  Any activities requiring a permit under a Fire Prevention Code. 
(b)  The city manager, the chief of the fire department and the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall not act as a committee to determine and specify, after giving affected persons an opportunity to be heard, any new materials, processes or occupancies, which shall require permits, in addition to those now enumerated in this section. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall post such list in a conspicuous place in his or her office, distribute copies thereof to interested persons and file a copy in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Applications for permits shall be made to the fire department on forms provided by the city. Applications for permits shall be accompanied by such data as may be required by the chief of the bureau of fire prevention. 
(d)  A permit shall be issued by the fire department upon the payment of all applicable permit fees as set forth in the fee schedule and compliance with applicable provisions of the Fire Prevention Code, NFiPA 704, the reporting requirements of the Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act of 1986 and the provisions of this chapter. The permit fees shall be in addition to any privilege license tax imposed under the provisions of Chapter 4 of this Code. A permit may be denied if the applicant fails to meet the requirements of this section. If the permit is denied, the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall advise the applicant, in writing, of the reasons for such denial. 
(e)  Unless otherwise specified in the fee schedule, a permit issued pursuant to this section shall extend for the twelve-month period beginning July 1 and ending June 30. Renewal applications are due not later than July 1 of each year. However, if a person begins an operation subject to the provisions of this section after June 1 of any year, the permit shall be issued before the business is begun. Permits for special activities shall be valid only for the permitted event or occurrence, and a new permit shall be obtained for each event or occurrence. 
(f)  Permits are not transferable to other locations or persons, firms or corporations. When an owner or operator is required to obtain more than one (1) permit, the permits may be consolidated onto one (1) permit form. Such consolidated permit form shall list all the hazardous materials or operations covered by the separate permits. When an owner or operator is required to obtain more than one (1) permit for the activities conducted at any location, the owner or operator shall pay the fees as set forth in the fee schedule for each permitted activity. 
(g)  Any person, firm or corporation who fails to obtain a permit as required by this section shall be required to pay twice the amount of the standard permit fee prior to the issuance of a permit. This amount shall be in addition to any penalties set forth in section 3-1 of this chapter. 
(h)  Without limiting the provisions of the Fire Prevention Code, the chief of the bureau of fire prevention may revoke a permit upon his determination that the permit holder, or any of his agents or employees, has violated any provision of the Fire Prevention Code or of this chapter, or any stated condition of the permit. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall advise the permit holder, in writing of the reason for the revocation. When an owner or operator has a consolidated permit, the revocation of any permit or permits shall not invalidate any other permits included within the consolidated permit. 
(i)  The owner or operator of any facility subject to the requirements of this section may appeal the denial or revocation of a permit in accordance with the provisions of section 3-18 of the City Code. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1; Ord. of 4-21-98, § 1) 
Sec. 3-22. - Fires within city limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build, kindle or maintain a fire, or to burn or caused to be burned any leaves, brush, shrubs, tree limbs, trash, rubbish, hazardous material or substance as defined in section 3-24 of this chapter, or any other like refuse or material upon any street, sidewalk, alley, road, highway, property owned or leased by the city, public right of way or on private property within the corporate limits of the City of Wilmington without a permit issued by the Chief of the Fire Department or his designee. This section shall not apply to the use of open-flame cooking devices used in accordance with the provisions of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1; Ord. No. 0-2002-30, § 1(c), 5-21-02) 
Sec. 3-23. - Charges for special testing, inspection and other services. 
    The fire department is authorized to charge for special testing, inspection and other services provided in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The charges for such services shall be as set forth in the fee schedule. The charges for such services shall be due at the time of application for such test, inspection or services. 
(Ord. of 3-4-97, § 1) 
Sec. 3-24. - Hazardous material and substance abatement. 
(a)  Purpose and authority. The City of Wilmington Fire Chief or his designee shall have the authority to summarily abate, control, contain, remove, or remedy hazardous materials or substances which are emitted into the environment or are left unattended in such a manner as to endanger the health, safety or welfare of the general public or the environment. The fire chief or his designee shall have the authority to enter public or private property, with or without the owner's consent, to respond to such hazardous materials emergencies. The fire chief or his designee shall determine the type, amount and quantity of equipment and personnel required to adequately abate, control, contain, remove, or remedy all hazardous materials or substances which are emitted into the environment or which are left unattended in such a manner as to endanger the health, safety or welfare of the general public or the environment. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply, unless a different meaning appears from the context: 
(1)  "Hazardous material or substance" means any material or substance defined as a hazardous material under North Carolina General Statute Section 166A-21, and also includes any material or substance which, when discharged in any quantity, may present a danger to either the health, safety or welfare of the general public, or to the environment. 
(2)  "Exercising or having control over" means, but not be limited to, any person using, transferring, storing, possessing or transporting a hazardous material or substance immediately prior to release of such hazardous material or substance on to the land or into the air or the waters within the city limits. 
(3)  "Hazardous material and substance response" means the sending of city fire department equipment and/or personnel to abate, control, contain, remove, or remedy any hazardous material or substance which endanger the health, safety or welfare of the general public or the environment. 
(4)  "Person" means any individual, firm, partnership, association, institution, corporation, organization, unit of local government, governmental agency, or any other group acting as a unit. 
(c)  Responsibility; fees and charges. Any property owner and/or person exercising or having control over any hazardous material or substance, or property owner and/or person that create a hazardous material or substance emergency shall be held financially responsible and liable for the response, abatement, control, containment, removal, and remedial costs incurred by the city and the city fire department during the emergency. The property owner and/or the person exercising control over such hazardous material or substance shall assist the fire department in the abatement, control, containment, removal and remedial measures associated with the hazardous material emergency. Assistance shall consist of, but not be limited to, any or all of the following: 
(1)  Compliance with the direction of the fire department. 
(2)  Supply of emergency response plan information for the site. 
(3)  Supply of emergency response equipment, personnel and materials available on site. 
(4)  Informing fire department personnel of all matters pertaining to the incident. 
(d)  Payment and collection of penalties. The cost incurred by the city and the city fire department in responding to, abating, controlling, containing, removing, or otherwise remedying a hazardous material or substance emergency shall be assessed to the responsible party as set forth in subsection (c) above, which assessment shall be in writing and delivered to the responsible party by personal delivery, first class mail, or by registered or certified mail return receipt requested, and shall be paid within thirty (30) of receipt thereof. Failure to pay the charges as assessed shall give the city the right to levy a lien upon the land or the premises where the hazardous material or substance emergency arose and said lien shall be collected as unpaid taxes as provided in North Carolina General Statute Section 160A-193. All assessed charges or portions thereof not paid within thirty (30) days after the receipt of a statement of charges, shall bear interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum until paid. If the statement of charges is delivered to the responsible party by first class mail, three days shall be added to the prescribed period within which payment shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 0-2001-65, § 1, 10-2-01) 
Chapter 4 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Penalties and remedies. 
(a)  A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in G.S. section 14-4. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this chapter, except sections 4-2 and 4-109 and Article V, shall also subject the offender to a civil penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(c)  Violations of the provisions of section 4-2 shall not be subject to the civil penalties as enumerated herein. 
(1)  For a first or second violation within any twelve (12) consecutive month period, no civil penalty. 
(2)  For a third violation within any twelve (12) consecutive month period, fifty dollars ($50.00) for a false fire alarm and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for any other violation of section 4-2. 
(3)  For a fourth and any subsequent violation within a twelve (12) consecutive month period, one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each false fire alarm and fifty dollars ($50.00) for any other violation of section 4-2. 
    If a person fails to pay this civil penalty within ten (10) days after being cited for a violation, the city may seek to recover the penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of debt. 
(d)  Any violations of the provisions of section 4-109 shall subject the offender to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00). If a person fails to pay this civil penalty within ten (10) days after being cited for a violation, the city may seek to recover the penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of a debt. 
(e)  Violations of the provisions of Article V shall also subject the offender to the following civil penalties: 
(1)  For a first violation within any twelve (12) consecutive month period, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(2)  For a second violation within any twelve (12) consecutive month period, one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(3)  For a third and any subsequent violation within any twelve (12) consecutive month period, two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
If a person fails to pay this civil penalty within ten (10) days after being cited for a violation, the city may seek to recover the penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of debt. 
(f)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter through any appropriate equitable action. 
(g)  Each day that a violation continues after the offender has been notified of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(h)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter by using any one or any combination of the foregoing remedies. 
(Code 1962, § 1-6; Ord. of 8-6-96, § 1; Ord. No. 0-2001-60, §§ 2, 3, 10-2-01; Ord. No. 0-2005-3, §§ 1, 2, 1-4-05; Ord. No. O-2010-59, § 1, 7-6-10) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prescribe penalties for breach of ordinances, § 1.4(47). 
State Law reference- Enforcement of ordinances, G.S. § 160A-175. 
Sec. 4-2. - False police and fire alarms. 
(a)  Definitions. Except as specifically defined herein, all words used in this chapter shall have their customary dictionary definitions. Certain words or terms used herein are defined as follows: 
    Alarm company: Any private individual or business entity licensed under G.S. Ch. 74D that installs, monitors, or services any alarm system within the City of Wilmington. 
    Alarm system: Any electronic or mechanical device transmitting an alarm signal outside the location, intended to alert law enforcement personnel to an actual or attempted unauthorized entry into a building or to the commission or attempted commission of a crime, or intended to alert fire or emergency medical personnel to an actual or suspected fire or medical emergency. This definition shall include, but not be limited to, "silent," audible and direct telephone dialer alarms. 
    False alarm: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical or electronic failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligence of the alarm user, his employees or agents, which summons a response from the Wilmington Police Department and/or the Wilmington Fire Department. An alarm is false within the meaning of this section if the responding unit finds no evidence of fire, products of combustion, medical emergency or evidence of unauthorized intrusion, robbery, or other such crime or evidence of the attempt to commit such crime in or on the premises. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a false alarm shall not include an alarm which can be clearly shown by the subscriber to have been caused or activated by an act of nature. 
    Subscriber: Any person, corporation, partnership or other entity owning, leasing or operating an alarm system within the City of Wilmington. 
(b)  Automatic dialing devices. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any device which dials a telephone number within the police department. 
(c)  Automatic disconnection device. Audible alarm signals in close proximity to a residential area shall have a device which automatically disconnects a signal not more than thirty (30) minutes after its initiation. Automatically disconnected audible alarm signals shall not be reset until fifteen (15) minutes have elapsed. 
(d)  Maintenance and testing of alarm systems. It is the responsibility of each alarm user to notify the central monitoring station when servicing or performing maintenance on an alarm system within the City of Wilmington and to place that alarm system in a test mode at the central monitoring station during such service or maintenance. The purpose of this procedure is to avoid false alarms during service or maintenance. Servicing or maintenance as used in this part includes the deliberate testing of an alarm system. 
(e)  False alarm responses; service fees. If an alarm is determined to be a false alarm, as defined hereinabove, a warning will be issued to the subscriber for the first occurrence. Thereafter, a service fee, as approved by the city council and included in the city's fee schedule, shall be charged to the subscriber for each response to a false alarm. The city may seek to recover service fees by filing a civil action in the nature of a debt. 
(Code 1962, § 16-56; Ord. of 5-1-90, § 1(a)-(f); Ord. of 6-7-94, § 1; Ord. of 8-6-96, §§ 2-4; Ord. No. O-2010-59, § 2, 7-6-10; Ord. No. O-2011-87, § 1, 10-18-11) 
State Law reference- Private Protective Services Act, G.S. Ch. 74C. 
Sec. 4-3. - Sunday sale hours. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by S.L. 2017-87 any licensed establishment located in the City of Wilmington is permitted to sell alcoholic beverages beginning at 10:00 a.m. on Sunday pursuant to the licensed premises' permit issued under G.S. 18B-1001. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-52, § 1, 7-18-17) 
Sec. 4-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 4-4, prohibiting operation of shooting galleries on Sunday, which derived from Code 1962, § 20-4, was repealed by § 1 of an ordinance adopted Dec. 11, 1984. 
Sec. 4-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 4-5, regulating operation of motion picture theaters on Sunday, which derived from Code 1962, § 20-1, was repealed by § 1 of an ordinance adopted Dec. 11, 1984. 
Secs. 4-6-4-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVILEGE LICENSE TAXES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
County Code reference- Privilege license tax, § 6-80 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-21. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, unless the context requires a different meaning: 
    Business includes each trade, occupation, profession, business and franchise taxed under this article. 
    Person includes any individual, trustee, executor, other fiduciary, corporation, unincorporated association, partnership, sole proprietorship, company, firm or other legal entity. 
    Seasonal means a business which is conducted for profit six (6) months out of the year or less. 
    Supervisor of collections means the city supervisor of collections or any of his lawfully designated agents or representatives. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-21; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 2) 
Sec. 4-22. - Construction of article. 
    This article is enacted for revenue purposes only. Therefore, it should be construed to require payment of the maximum tax permitted under its terms. In addition, issuance of a license pursuant to this article does not excuse a licensee from compliance with any other applicable ordinance or statute. This article does not prevent the city from imposing license taxes on additional businesses, from increasing or decreasing the amount of any license tax or from regulating any business taxed. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-23) 
Sec. 4-23. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 4-23 relative to the appointment of deputy tax collector and derived from Code 1962, § 8A-23, was repealed by § 3 of an ordinance adopted March 26, 1985. 
Secs. 4-24-4-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LEVY 

Sec. 4-36. - Generally. 
    An annual privilege license tax is levied on each business, conducted within this city, listed in the fee schedule, which is incorporated by reference in this section. 
County Code reference-Schedule, § 6-100. 
Sec. 4-37. - Who must pay tax. 
    Each person who conducts a business within the city is subject to this article. A person "conducts business" when he engages in one act of any business taxed under this article. He conducts the business "within the city" if he maintains a business location in the city or, personally or through agents: 
(1)  Solicits business within the city limits; or 
(2)  Picks up or delivers goods or delivers services within the city limits. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-34) 
Sec. 4-38. - Period of license; due date. 
(a)  Annual licenses. Unless otherwise specified, the privilege license issued pursuant to this article is good for the twelve-month period beginning June first and ending May thirty-first. The tax is due and payable not later than June first of each year. However, if a person begins a business after June first of a year, the tax for that year shall be due and payable before the business is begun. 
(b)  Periods shorter than one year. If the section of this article levying the privilege license tax applicable to the particular business so provides, a license may be issued for a period of one day, one week or some comparable period of less than a full license year. A person may not commence a business conducted within the city and taxed under such a provision until the privilege license tax due is paid, and may not continue such business beyond the period for which the license is issued. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-35) 
Sec. 4-39. - Proration of tax. 
    If a business is begun after December thirty-first and before June first, the amount of tax due is half the amount otherwise due. If a business is seasonal in nature, and if the amount of tax is not based on gross receipts, the amount of tax due is half the amount otherwise due. This section shall not apply, however, to subsection numbers 18, 19, 116 and 135 of the fee schedule and the amount of tax due under those sections shall not be reduced. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-36) 
Sec. 4-40. - Refunds. 
    If for any reason a licensee discontinues his business during the license year, he is not entitled to a refund. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-37) 
Sec. 4-41. - Separate businesses. 
    A separate license is required and a separate privilege license tax must be paid for each place of business unless two (2) or more places of business under common ownership, each conducting a business subject to the same tax under this article, are contiguous to each other, communicate directly with and open into each other and are operated as a unit. In addition, a separate privilege license tax must be paid for each business taxable under this article conducted by the taxpayer at any one location; however, the supervisor of collections may issue a single license for all taxable businesses conducted at one location by a single taxpayer. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-38; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-42. - Computation of tax based on gross receipts. 
(a)  Whenever this article levies a privilege license tax computed on the basis of gross receipts, "gross receipts" means the amount reported as gross receipts on a business's state income tax return or on the federal income tax return filed with the state income tax return if the state return does not separately state gross receipts, for the most recently completed tax year. 
(b)  If a business has not been in operation long enough for the information required in subsection (a) of this section to be available, the supervisor of collections shall estimate gross receipts for the business, based on gross receipts of comparable businesses or any other information that the supervisor of collections considers useful. 
(c)  On or before June thirtieth immediately after each license year, each licensee for whom the tax paid in the license year just concluded was based on estimated gross receipts may be required to submit to the supervisor of collections a sworn final report showing the amount of gross receipts for the license year. If the amount shown is more than estimated gross receipts, the licensee shall pay the amount of additional tax that would have been due had the estimate been accurate. If the amount shown is less than estimated gross receipts, the city shall refund to the licensee the difference between the actual tax paid and the amount of tax that would have been due had the estimate been accurate. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-39; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-43. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Generally. Except as otherwise provided in this section or by state law, no person is exempt from the payment of a privilege license tax levied by this article. 
(b)  Charitable organizations. A person who operates a business for a religious, educational, civic, patriotic, charitable or fraternal purpose, when the entire gross income of the business is used for such a purpose, is exempt from paying any privilege license tax levied by this article. 
(c)  Blind persons; members of the armed forces, merchant marine. Blind persons and persons who serve in the United States armed forces or the merchant marine are exempt from paying any privilege license tax levied by this article to the extent provided by G.S. sections 105-249 and 105-249.1. 
(d)  Must obtain license. A person exempt from paying a privilege license tax levied by this article shall nevertheless obtain a license from the supervisor of collections. The license shall state that the licensee is exempt from paying the privilege license tax. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-40; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Secs. 4-44-4-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSES 

Sec. 4-56. - Application. 
    A person shall apply to the supervisor of collections for each license required by this article not less than thirty (30) days before the date the tax is due. The application, which shall be submitted on forms provided by the supervisor of collections, shall contain: 
(1)  The name of the applicant and whether he or it is an individual, a partnership, a corporation or some other entity. 
(2)  The nature of the business. 
(3)  Where the business is conducted. 
(4)  An address to which may be mailed notices and statements required by this article. 
(5)  Whether the business is one regulated by a state occupational licensing board subject to G.S. Chapter 93B, and if so, the serial number of the state license the applicant currently holds. 
(6)  Any other information the supervisor of collections determines to be necessary to compute the amount of tax due. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-51; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-57. - Reasons for refusal or revocation. 
    The supervisor of collections shall refuse to issue a license or shall revoke a license for either of the following reasons: 
(1)  If the applicant misrepresents a fact relevant to the amount of tax due or his qualifications for a license. 
(2)  If the applicant refuses to provide information necessary to compute the amount of tax due. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-52; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-58. - Unqualified applicants; right to conference. 
(a)  After receipt of the completed application, if the supervisor of collections believes that a reason exists for refusing a license under section 4-57, he shall refuse to accept payment of the tax and shall not issue the license. At the applicant's request, the supervisor of collections shall, pursuant to section 4-67, give him a written statement of the reason for refusing the license. The applicant may, within ten (10) days after the day he receives his statement, request in writing a conference with the supervisor of collections to discuss the refusal. In his request he shall specify why his application for a license should not be refused. The supervisor of collections shall arrange the conference with a reasonable time. 
(b)  If the supervisor of collections refuses to issue a license, the applicant may reapply for a license at any time thereafter. If the reason for which the application was refused no longer exists, and if no other reason exists for refusing to issue a license, the supervisor of collections shall issue the license pursuant to section 4-59. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-53; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-59. - Issuance of license; payment of tax. 
    After receipt of the completed application, if the supervisor of collections believes that no reason exists for refusal of a license under section 4-57, he shall issue a license upon receipt of the tax due and owing. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-54; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-60. - Amount of tax disputed. 
    If the applicant disputes the amount the supervisor of collections determines to be due, he must pay the amount and proceed as set forth in section 4-82. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-55; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-61. - Revocation. 
(a)  The supervisor of collections shall revoke a license if a reason exists to revoke it as set forth in section 4-57. Before the supervisor of collections may revoke a license, he shall give the licensee written notice of the grounds for revocation, pursuant to section 4-67. The licensee may, within ten (10) days after the day on which notice is served, request in writing a conference with the supervisor of collections to discuss the revocation. The request shall specify the reasons why the license should not be revoked. The supervisor of collections shall arrange the conference within a reasonable time. 
(b)  If the licensee fails to request a conference within ten (10) days after the day on which notice is served, the supervisor of collections shall revoke the license. If the licensee requests a conference, the supervisor of collections may not revoke the license until after the conference. 
(c)  If the supervisor of collections revokes a license, the former licensee may apply for a new license at any time thereafter. If the reason for which the license was revoked no longer exists, and if no other reason exists for refusing to issue a license, the supervisor of collections shall issue the license pursuant to section 4-59. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-56; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-62. - Form; contents. 
    A license shall show the name of the person licensed, the place where the business is conducted (if it is to be conducted at one place), the nature of business licensed, the period for which the license is issued and the amount of tax paid. The supervisor of collections may provide that the license contain such additional information as may be necessary for the proper administration of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-57; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-63. - Assignment. 
    A license may be assigned if: 
(1)  A business license under this article and carried on at a fixed place is sold as a unit to any person. 
(2)  The purchaser is to carry on the same business at the same place. 
Such a change shall be reported to the supervisor of collections pursuant to section 4-64. Otherwise, each license issued under this article is a personal privilege and is not assignable. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-58; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-64. - Changes in business during tax year. 
(a)  Generally. A licensee or his assignee shall report a change in the information contained in the license application to the supervisor of collections within ten (10) days after the change occurs. If information shown on the license itself is affected thereby, the licensee or his assignee shall surrender the license to the supervisor of collections when reporting the change. 
(b)  Changes affecting the amount of tax due. If there are no reasons for revoking the license under section 4-57, and the change results in the imposition of a separate or additional tax, the supervisor of collections shall reissue a license reflecting the change upon payment of the separate or additional tax. 
(c)  Changes not affecting amount of tax. If there are no reasons for revoking the license under section 4-57 and the change does not result in an imposition of a separate or additional tax, the supervisor of collections shall reissue a license reflecting the change upon payment of a fee prescribed in the fee schedule. 
(d)  Change requiring refusal of license. If there is reason for revoking the license under section 4-57, the supervisor of collections shall refuse to reissue a license and shall instead begin proceedings to revoke the license pursuant to section 4-61. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-59; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-65. - Duplicates. 
    Upon satisfactory proof that a license has been lost or destroyed, the supervisor of collections shall furnish a duplicate for a fee prescribed in the fee schedule. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-60; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-66. - Record of conferences. 
    The supervisor of collections shall maintain for three (3) years a record of each conference held pursuant to this article. The record shall contain the applicant's or licensee's name, the date of the conference and a brief statement of the issues discussed and the result reached. After three (3) years, the supervisor of collections shall dispose of the record pursuant to G.S. section 121-5. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-61; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-67. - Notice to applicant or licensee. 
    Whenever this article requires the supervisor of collections to give a written statement or notice to an applicant or a licensee, he may do so: 
(1)  By personally delivering the statement or notice to the applicant or licensee; 
(2)  By mailing the statement or notice by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address specified for that purpose in the license application; or 
(3)  By causing the statement or notice to be served on the applicant or licensee in accordance with the procedures for service of process under Rule 4, North Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure (G.S. section 1A-1). 
(Code 1962, § 8A-62; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Secs. 4-68-4-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ENFORCEMENT AND COLLECTION 

Sec. 4-76. - Duty to determine whether tax due. 
    Each person has the duty to determine whether the business he conducts is taxed under this article and, if so, whether that tax has been paid for the current tax year. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-73) 
Sec. 4-77. - Supervisor of collections. 
    If the supervisor of collections has reason to believe that a person is conducting a business in the city in violation of this article, he shall conduct an investigation to determine the person's tax liability. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-74; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-78. - Records generally. 
    Each person who conducts a business taxed under this article shall keep all records and books necessary to compute his tax liability. If a person fails to keep books and records as required, the supervisor of collections shall make his own determination of that person's tax liability from the information available to him. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-75; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-79. - Inspection. 
    Each person who conducts business in the city shall permit the supervisor of collections to inspect his business premises during normal business hours to determine the nature of the business conducted there, and to examine his books and records to determine the nature and amount of business transacted. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-76; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-80. - Duty to post license. 
(a)  A licensee shall post his license or licenses conspicuously in the place of business licensed. If he has no regular place of business, the license must be kept where it may be inspected at all times by the proper city officials. 
(b)  Each coin-operated machine, device or other equipment for which a city privilege license is required shall have affixed thereto, in a conspicuous place, a sticker as provided by the supervisor of collections, indicating that the privilege license tax has been paid. Failure to display this sticker shall raise a presumption that the machine, device or other equipment is operated by the owner and/or tenant of the premises where such machine, device or equipment is located; such person shall be responsible for payment of all city taxes and penalties which may be due and payable. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-77; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-81. - Notice of deficiency. 
    If the supervisor of collections determines that a person has not paid the full amount of tax due under this article, either for the current license year or for a prior license year, he shall give the person written notice of the deficiency, pursuant to section 4-67. The notice of deficiency shall specify the total amount of tax due, the amount of tax paid, any penalty due, the balance owed, the manner and time period in which the person may respond to the notice of deficiency and the consequences to the person if he fails to respond as specified. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-78; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-82. - Request for conference. 
    The person may, within ten (10) days after the day on which notice is served, request in writing a conference. The request shall specify the person's objections to the notice of deficiency. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-79) 
Sec. 4-83. - Deficiency to become final. 
    If the taxpayer fails to request a conference under section 4-82, the deficiency becomes final and the supervisor of collections shall proceed to collect the deficiency. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-80; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-84. - Conference held. 
    If the taxpayer requests a conference, the supervisor of collections shall not proceed to collect the deficiency until he hears the taxpayer's objections and determines that the deficiency should become final. Thereafter, any proceedings shall be in accordance with section 4-87. The supervisor of collections shall maintain for three (3) years a record of each conference held pursuant to section 4-82. The record shall contain the name of the taxpayer, the date of the conference and a brief statement of the issues discussed and the results of the discussion. After three (3) years, the supervisor of collections shall dispose of the record pursuant to G.S. section 121-5. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-81; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-85. - Collection of deficiency. 
(a)  The supervisor of collections may use any of the following methods to collect a deficiency: 
(1)  Criminal prosecution in accordance with section 4-1(a). 
(2)  Civil penalties in accordance with section 4-1(b). 
(3)  Equitable relief in accordance with section 4-1(d). 
(4)  The remedies of levy and sale and attachment and garnishment, in accordance with G.S. section 160A-207. 
(5)  The remedies of levy and sale of real and personal property of the taxpayer within the city in accordance with G.S. section 105-109. 
(b)  Any person who commences or continues to conduct a business taxed under this article without payment of the tax is liable for the additional tax or penalty of five (5) percent of the amount of such license tax which was due and payable, for each and every thirty (30) days, or fraction thereof, that such license tax remains unpaid from the date the same was due and payable, as provided in G.S. section 105-109. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-82; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Sec. 4-86. - Enforcement. 
    Payment of a fine or penalty imposed for a violation of this article does not relieve a person of his liability for taxes imposed hereunder. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-83) 
Sec. 4-87. - Refunds; remedies. 
(a)  Any taxpayer asserting a valid defense to the enforcement of the collection of any privilege license tax levied under this article shall proceed as follows: 
(1)  If the tax has been paid, the taxpayer at any time within three (3) years after such tax became due may make a demand for a refund of the tax paid by submitting to the city council a written statement of his defense and a request for a refund thereof. 
(2)  By way of illustration but not limitation, such defense may provide that: 
a.  The tax due has already been paid; 
b.  The supervisor of collections miscalculated the amount of tax due; 
c.  The supervisor of collections based his calculation on incorrect or insufficient information concerning either the nature or amount of business conducted; or 
d.  The supervisor of collections based his determination on an erroneous interpretation of a section of this article that establishes a category of business subject to a particular tax. 
(b)  Upon receiving a taxpayer's written statement of defense and request for release or refund, the city council shall, within ninety (90) days after receipt of such request, determine whether the taxpayer has a valid defense to the tax imposed or any part thereof and shall either release or refund that portion of the amount that is determined to be in excess of the correct tax liability or notify the taxpayer in writing that no release or refund will be made. The action of the council on applications for refunds shall be recorded in its minutes. If a refund is made, the supervisor of collections shall note on all records the amount of refund, check number and date. 
(c)  If, within ninety (90) days after receiving a taxpayer request for refund under (a) above, the council has failed to refund the full amount requested by the taxpayer, has notified the taxpayer that no refund will be made or has taken no action on the request, the taxpayer may bring a civil action against the city for the amount claimed. Such action may be brought at any time within three (3) years from the expiration of the period in which the council is required to act. 
(d)  A civil action brought pursuant to subsection (c) above shall be brought in the appropriate division of the general court of justice in New Hanover County. 
(Code 1962, § 8A-84; Ord. of 3-26-85, § 4) 
Secs. 4-88-4-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES OF MERCHANDISE ON PUBLIC PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Itinerant merchants, peddlers, solicitation of contributions, G.S. § 160A-178. 

Sec. 4-101. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to concessions or other sales locations operated or sponsored by the city, to concessions operated in accordance with the lease of Legion Stadium or to the city parking deck on Water Street in the downtown area, or to sales and concessions at the Wilmington Convention Center, including the Event Lawn, as operated or managed either by the city or a management firm engaged to operate said facilities. 
(Ord. of 6-28-83, § 1; Ord. No. O-2010-84, 11-2-10) 
Sec. 4-102. - Sales of merchandise generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish a location upon any public street, sidewalk, right-of-way, plaza, park or city-owned or leased property for any period of time, or use such property or any part thereof as a location for or as a place of business for selling or offering for sale products or merchandise of any kind, except as otherwise provided in this Code. 
(Ord. of 6-28-83, § 1) 
Sec. 4-103. - Sale of farm products. 
    The sale of fruits, vegetables, meats, produce and farm products shall be permitted house-to-house between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except in those areas of the city designated as fire district No. one. 
(Ord. of 6-28-83, § 1) 
Cross reference- No. 1 fire limits, § 16-57. 
Sec. 4-104. - Sale of ice cream products on city streets. 
(a)  Any person may sell or offer for sale, on the streets or alleys of the city, any ice cream products from motorized ice cream units, subject to this section. 
(b)  Vehicles from which such sales are made must be legally parked. 
(c)  The duration of sales within any one city block in any one day shall be limited to thirty (30) minutes. 
(d)  All sales are prohibited in public parks and within three hundred fifty (350) feet from the property line of all schools. 
(e)  Sales are prohibited in fire district No. one tract number one as defined in section 16-57. 
(f)  Sales are prohibited on the following streets: 
Burnett Boulevard. 
Carolina Beach Road. 
Castle Street. 
Chestnut Street. 
College Road. 
Dawson Street.

(g)  Sales shall be conducted during daylight hours only. 
(h)  Noise-making devices such as, but not inclusive of, bells, whistles and gongs may not be used to advertise or announce sales of such products. 
(Ord. of 6-28-83, § 1) 
Sec. 4-105. - Special event concessions. 
(a)  The sale of merchandise and the operation of concession stands on public plazas, streets, parks or sidewalks may be authorized by permit issued by the city manager in accordance with this section.
