(a)  There are seven (7) standard operating medallions available for operation of horse-drawn vehicles for hire within the city, and they will be awarded by the city manager or his designee on a first-come, first-served basis, based upon the date on which each horse-drawn carriage company began to legally operate within the city. 
(b)  Medallions may be transferred between different horse-drawn vehicles for hire belonging to the same horse-drawn carriage company at any time by the owner/operator of the horse-drawn carriage company without the need for further approval from the city. Medallions are not transferable from one horse-drawn carriage company to another. The medallion remains the property of the city and shall only be surrendered to the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  Each horse-drawn carriage company may be awarded up to four (4) standard operating medallions, restricting the number of horse-drawn vehicles for hire in operation by any one (1) horse-drawn carriage company at one time to four (4) horse-drawn vehicles for hire, except as provided below in section 4-216. 
(d)  For each standard operating medallion issued within the city, the horse-drawn carriage company possessing that medallion shall be assessed an annual fee per medallion, as set forth in the city's fee schedule. 
(e)  Standard operating medallions shall only be issued after the owner/operator of a horse-drawn carriage company has provided the city manager or his designee with a complete listing of all potential regular routes that the horse-drawn vehicles for hire owned by that horse-drawn carriage company intend to take, and such routes have been approved by the city manager or his designee, after consultation with any appropriate city staff. 
(f)  Any changes in regular routes, other than changes resulting from unexpected conditions such as road closures or street maintenance, must be approved by the city manager or his designee prior to operation along the altered route. 
(g)  For private charters when a horse-drawn vehicle for hire displaying either a standard operating medallion, or a single-day temporary medallion as outlined in section 4-216 below, is not beginning or ending a route at a designated carriage loading zone, documentation regarding such private charters, including but not limited to the route taken, the date and time of the charter, and the beginning and ending points for the charter, must be kept and maintained by each horse-drawn carriage company for a period of one (1) year, and must be made available for inspection by the city manager or his designee upon their request at any time. 
(h)  All standard operating medallions shall be issued by the city manager or his designee and visibly displayed on the back of the horse-drawn vehicle for hire. 
(i)  Only horse-drawn vehicles for hire displaying a medallion may load and discharge passengers in areas of the city that are specifically designated as a "carriage loading zone," as those areas are designated in Official Traffic Schedules of the City of Wilmington. Horse-drawn vehicles for hire not displaying a standard operating medallion, or a single-day temporary operating medallion as described in section 4-216 of this division, are not allowed in any carriage loading zone. 
(j)  Horse-drawn vehicles for hire not displaying a standard operating medallion, or a single-day temporary operating medallion as described in section 4-216 of this division, are not allowed to load and/or unload passengers within the city limits at any time. 
(k)  Each horse-drawn carriage company that is awarded a standard operating medallion for operation within the city will be allowed to choose a location for their base of operations from the list of on-street carriage loading zone options listed in the city's Official Traffic Schedules. On-street carriage loading zones will be assigned on a first-come, first-served basis, based upon the date on which each horse-drawn carriage company began to legally operate within the city. Once a location is chosen by the first company in operation, the next company will choose from the remainder of the available locations on the list, and continue in such fashion until all horse-drawn carriage companies have chosen a location. If one (1) horse-drawn carriage company ceases operation and/or no longer requires use of its chosen carriage loading zone location, that location will be offered to the remaining horse-drawn carriage companies in operation in the order of when those companies began legally operating in the city. 
(l)  Each horse-drawn carriage company that chooses to operate out of an approved carriage loading zone location is required to keep that location clean and sanitized from all horse waste and debris during all periods of operation. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-55, § 5, 8-21-18) 
Sec. 4-216. - Single-day temporary operating medallion. 
(a)  In addition to the seven (7) standard operating medallions provided for in section 4-215, the city manager or his designee shall have one (1) single-day temporary operating medallion available for issuance on a first-come, first-served basis to horse-drawn carriage companies already licensed and operating within the City of Wilmington, or to horse-drawn carriage companies operating elsewhere who also meet all of the additional requirements of this section. 
(b)  All single-day temporary operating medallions shall be issued by the city manager or his designee and visibly displayed on the back of the horse-drawn vehicle for hire. 
(c)  Single-day temporary operating medallions are not transferable from one horse-drawn carriage company to another. The medallion remains the property of the city and shall only be surrendered to the city manager or his designee. 
(d)  All of the rules and regulations of section 4-214 of this division relating to prohibited business practices shall also apply to a single-day temporary operating medallion. 
(e)  All of the rules and regulations of section 4-213(a) of this division relating to additional requirements on days, locations, and times of operation shall also apply to a single-day temporary operating medallion. 
(f)  Every horse-drawn vehicle for hire operating under a single-day temporary operating medallion within the city shall substantially comply, in the determination of the city manager or his designee, with the rules and regulations of section 4-213(b)(1) of this division relating to lights and reflective material. 
(g)  All of the rules and regulations of section 4-213(c) of this division relating to restrictions on impeding the normal traffic flow shall also apply to a single-day temporary operating medallion. 
(h)  All of the rules and regulations of section 4-213(e)-(j) of this division relating to animal health, safety, and sanitation shall also apply to a single-day temporary operating medallion. 
(i)  Every horse-drawn vehicle for hire operating under a single-day temporary operating medallion within the city shall be equipped with a diapering apparatus that prevents the droppings of the animal(s) from being deposited on the ground or the right-of-way. 
(j)  Any horse-drawn carriage company wishing to apply for a single-day temporary operating medallion shall submit an application in writing to the city manager or his designee, on a form provided by the city manager or his designee, no less than one (1) but no more than thirty (30) days in advance of the date requested. Such application shall include the date for which the temporary operating medallion is requested, and the route that will be used for the horse-drawn vehicle for hire on that day. 
(k)  Issuance of a single-day temporary operating medallion is in the sole discretion of the city manager or his designee based upon multiple factors including but not limited to the current number of horse-drawn vehicles for hire that will be in operation within the city on the requested date, the requestor's history of compliance with this article and division, and any public health, safety, or welfare concerns known by the city manager or his designee at the time of the request. 
(l)  For any single-day temporary operating medallion issued within the city, the company possessing that medallion shall be assessed a daily fee, as set forth in the city's fee schedule. There shall be no refunds made to any horse-drawn vehicle for hire company for the single-day temporary operating medallion fee once the fee has been paid. 
(m)  No horse-drawn carriage company shall be issued more than four (4) single-day temporary operating medallions in any thirty (30) day period. 
(n)  A horse-drawn carriage company who already has use of a designated carriage loading zone due to possession of one (1) or more standard operating medallions, may use that same carriage loading zone when that company is granted use of a single-day temporary operating medallion. Horse-drawn carriage companies who are not already designated a carriage loading zone space are not allowed to make use of any of the designated carriage loading zones in the city for the purpose of operating with a single-day temporary operating medallion. 
(o)  Operators using single-day temporary operating medallions are required to ensure that any route used by them is kept free of all horse waste and debris during all periods of operation. 
(p)  Failure to comply with this division, or any laws, ordinances, or regulations of this city or state relating to vehicles and/or vehicles for hire, and also including but not limited to any law, ordinance, or regulation governing the treatment of animals, may result in revocation by the city manager or his designee of any single-day temporary operating medallions issued to the horse-drawn carriage company, and may serve as a basis for denial of future requests for single-day temporary operating medallions in the future by that company. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-55, § 5, 8-21-18) 
Secs. 4-217-4-224. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 4-225. - Licensing of pawnbrokers. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to establish or conduct a business of pawnbroker or to operate a pawnshop within the City of Wilmington unless such person, firm or corporation has procured a license to conduct such a business in compliance with this article and the provisions of Chapter 91A of the General Statutes of North Carolina as amended. As provided by G.S. § 91A-12, the provisions of Chapter 91A of the General Statutes are hereby adopted by reference. 
(b)  Every application for a pawnbroker's license shall be on a form approved by the city manager and shall be filed with the city manager or his designee. 
(c)  A copy of the application shall be forwarded to the police department for an appropriate criminal records check, to the fire department to determine compliance with the fire safety code, and to the code enforcement section for a determination as to compliance with zoning, building and development regulations. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-27, § 1, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 4-226. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  Prior to issuing a license under this article, the city manager or his designee shall be satisfied that the applicant is a suitable person to hold a pawnbroker license and that the location is a suitable place for a pawn business and is in compliance with all provisions of Chapter 91A of the General Statutes of North Carolina as amended and applicable provisions of the ordinances of the City of Wilmington. 
(b)  Prior to being issued a pawnbroker's license the applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond as required by G.S. § 91A-14 as amended. 
(c)  Upon approval of the application by the city manager or his designee and upon receipt of a license fee as established by city council and the required bond, a pawnbroker's license shall be issued to the applicant. The pawnbroker's license must be renewed annually at a renewal fee as set by city council. 
(d)  An applicant licensed as a pawnbroker under this article shall have the authority as set forth in G.S. § 91A-4 as amended. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-27, § 1, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 4-227. - Record keeping requirements and pawn transactions. 
(a)  Every pawnbroker licensed under this article shall maintain and keep records as required by G.S. § 91A-7 as amended. 
(b)  All pawnbrokers licensed under this article shall utilize a reporting system of pawn transactions that offers an electronic data transmission system that is compatible with the standard used by the City of Wilmington Police Department law enforcement computer system. The electronic data must be provided to the appropriate law enforcement agency as designated by the Wilmington Police Department within twenty-four (24) hours after the pawn transaction record is created. Failure to utilize an electronic data transmission system required by this section shall be grounds for revocation of the pawnbroker's license. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-27, § 1, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 4-228. - Revocation of pawnbroker's license. 
    Any license issued under this article may be revoked by action of the city manager for substantial abuses of this article or Chapter 91A of the General Statutes of North Carolina as amended. Prior to revocation of a pawnbroker's license, written notice shall be sent to the licensee by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address listed on the licensee's pawnbroker's license application. The notice shall contain a short statement of the allegations supporting revocation and the date, time and location of a hearing before the city manager or his designee. The hearing shall not take place sooner than fifteen (15) calendar days following the date of the notice. A revocation hearing may be initiated by the chiefs of the police or fire departments or the chief code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-27, § 1, 4-17-07) 
Secs. 4-229-4-233. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS 

Sec. 4-234. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the Telecommunication Ordinance of the City of Wilmington. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-235. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following phrases, terms, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein unless otherwise defined by federal or state law. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number. The word "shall" is mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their common and ordinary meaning. 
    City: City of Wilmington, North Carolina. 
    Council: Wilmington City Council. 
    County: New Hanover County. 
    "Franchise: A franchise contract entered into voluntarily by the grantee, containing the specific provisions of the franchise granted, including applications, referenced specifications and other related material. A franchise granted pursuant to this article grants the nonexclusive rights to construct, maintain, and operate a telecommunication system in the public rights-of-way within all or a specified area in the city. Any such authorization, in whatever form granted, shall not mean or include any construction permits or license required for the privilege of transacting and carrying on a business within the city as required by other ordinances and laws of the city. The preceding or any other provision of this ordinance notwithstanding, the city will not impose license, franchise, or privilege fees or taxes on companies taxed under G.S. 105-164.4(a)(4c). 
    Franchise area: The entire city, or portions thereof, for which a franchise is granted under the authority of this article. 
    Grantee: Any natural persons, partnerships, domestic and foreign corporations, associations, joint ventures, or organizations of any kind which have been legally granted a franchise by the city, and shall include the lawful successor, transferee or assignee of such grantee. 
    Grantor: City of Wilmington, North Carolina. 
    Law: Any local, state or federal legislative, judicial or administrative order, certificate, decision, statute, constitution, ordinance, resolution, regulation, rule, tariff, guideline or other requirement, as amended, now in effect or subsequently enacted or issued during the term of a franchise, including, but not limited to, the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-104, 110 Stat. 70, codified at 47 U.S.C., and all orders, rules, tariffs, guidelines and regulations issued by the Federal Communications Commission or the North Carolina Utilities Commission pursuant thereto. 
    Public rights-of-way or public way: The surface, the airspace above the surface and the area below the surface of any public street, highway, lane, path, alley, sidewalk, boulevard, drive, bridge, tunnel, park, parkway, waterway, utility easement or other public rights-of-way now or hereafter held by the city which shall entitle the city and the grantee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing and maintaining the grantee's telecommunication system. No reference herein, or in any franchise, to the "public way" shall be deemed to be representation or guarantee by the city that its title to any property is sufficient to permit its use for such purpose, and the grantee shall, by its use be deemed to gain only such rights to use property in the city as the city may have the undisputed right and power to give or as granted by law. 
    State: The State of North Carolina. 
    Telecommunication system and system: Cabinets, cables, conduits, converters, drains, equipment, handholes, splice boxes, location markers, vaults and other appurtenances used or to be used to transmit, receive, distribute, provide or offer telecommunication service. 
    Telecommunication service: Local, private telephone service, toll telephone service, long distance telephone service, data service, and video service. Telecommunication service does not include a cable network or video programming as defined in Section 602 of the Cable Communication Policy Act of 1984 (47 USC 510), as amended. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 1, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-236. - Franchise required; grant of franchise; general provisions. 
(a)  Franchise required. No telecommunication system shall be allowed to occupy or use the public rights-of-way of the city or be allowed to operate within the city without a franchise. Any telecommunication system located in the public rights-of-way on the effective date of this article shall obtain a franchise from the city pursuant to this article within one hundred and twenty (120) days, unless such timeframe is extended by the city. 
(b)  Grant and area covered. Pursuant to the state law and applicable Charter provisions, ordinances, rules and regulations, the city can grant revocable and non-exclusive franchises to construct, operate and maintain a telecommunication system within the city and in the public rights-of-way. The specific locations of the telecommunication system in the public rights-of-way shall be subject to the approval of the city engineer pursuant to the terms of a franchise and other applicable local ordinances. The franchise shall constitute both a right and an obligation to provide the services of a telecommunication system pursuant to a grantee's certificates of public convenience and necessity and the North Carolina public utilities laws and regulations. By acceptance of a franchise, grantee acknowledges and accepts the legal right of the city to issue the franchise. 
(c)  Use of public rights-of-way. For the purpose of operating and maintaining a telecommunication system within the city, a grantee may erect, install, construct, repair, replace, reconstruct and retain in, on, over, under, upon, across and along the public rights-of-way within the city such cabinets, cables, conduits, converters, drains, equipment, handholes, splice boxes, location markers, vaults and other appurtenances as are necessary to the operation of the telecommunication system, provided, however, that, subject to applicable law, any grantee shall comply with all design, construction, safety, and performance provisions contained in the franchise, this article and other applicable local ordinances. 
(d)  Use of grantee facilities. Solely for the city's non-commercial use, a grantee shall, during the life of the franchise, cooperate with the city to facilitate the installation of cable sufficient to meet the city's needs, at the city's sole cost, if economically and technically feasible to accommodate the city's request at the time such request is made to grantee. 
(e)  Police powers. A grantee's rights under a franchise are subject to the police powers of the city to adopt and enforce ordinances for the health, safety and welfare of the public. Subject to applicable law, grantee shall comply with all applicable general laws and ordinances enacted by the city pursuant to that power. Nothing in this article or the franchise shall be deemed to be a waiver of the lawful, publicly available requirements of the various codes, ordinances, regulations, standards and specifications regarding permits, fees to be paid, or manner of construction. 
(f)  Franchise nonexclusive. Any franchise granted by the city is non-exclusive. The city specifically reserves the right to grant, at any time, additional franchises in accordance with state and federal law, provided any telecommunication system franchise granted by the city contains substantially equivalent standards, terms and conditions as are contained herein or any amendments to this article. 
(g)  Time is of the essence of the franchise. Subject to applicable law, whenever a franchise shall set forth any time for an act to be performed by or on behalf of the grantee, such time shall be deemed of the essence and any failure of the grantee to perform within the time allotted shall always be sufficient material ground for the city to invoke an appropriate penalty including possible revocation of the franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, §§ 2, 3, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-237. - Franchise term. 
    The term of the franchise shall commence upon execution of the franchise by the city and the grantee and shall continue for the period specified in the franchise, unless sooner terminated as provided herein. Grantee shall have no property right upon the expiration of the franchise term, except as provided by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-238. - Franchise fees. 
(a)  Payment of fee. To the extent permitted by applicable law, the grantee of any franchise hereunder shall pay to the city a franchise fee in the amount specified in the franchise. This franchise payment shall be in addition to any other fee and shall commence and be paid as set forth in the franchise. Franchise fees will not be imposed upon companies taxed under G.S. 105-164.4(a)(4c). For telecommunication systems that are not taxed under G.S. 105-164.4(a)(4c), the grantee shall pay to the city an annual fee in the amount of three dollars ($3.00) per linear foot of public right-of-way for the installed system, whether aerial or underground. 
(b)  Fee in addition to taxes. Any franchise fee payment shall be in addition to any other fees, tax or payment owed by the grantee to the city or other taxing jurisdiction. Payment of any franchise fee by grantee to the city shall be in addition to any and all taxes which are now or may be required hereafter to be paid by any federal, state, or local law. 
(c)  Acceptance by the city. No acceptance of any payment by the city shall be construed as a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the city may have for further or additional sums payable as a franchise fee or for the performance of any other obligation of the grantee under this article subject to any applicable statute of limitations. 
(d)  Failure to make required payment. In the event that any franchise payment or installment thereof is not made on or before the dates specified herein or in the franchise, grantee shall pay as additional compensation an interest charge, computed from such due date, at the annual rate equal to the commercial prime interest rate of the city's primary depository bank during the period that such unpaid amount is owed. 
(e)  Time for payment. Subject to applicable law, any other cost or damages assessed under the franchise shall be payable to the city upon demand, unless otherwise provided in the franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 4, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-239. - Service. 
    A grantee shall provide service within the city in accordance with the conditions of its Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity or other applicable requirements of the North Carolina Utilities Commission. A grantee shall not offer any cable network or video programming as defined in Section 602 of the Cable Communication Policy Act of 1984, as amended, without first obtaining a cable franchise from the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 5, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-240. - Construction and technical standards; use of streets. 
(a)  Compliance with construction and technical standards. A grantee shall construct, install and maintain its telecommunication system in an orderly and workmanlike manner and in a manner consistent with all applicable laws and ordinances and all applicable, lawful, publicly available construction standards, current technological standards and governmental requirements, which standards are incorporated by reference herein. 
(b)  Use of existing poles and conduits. To the extent reasonably possible, a grantee shall utilize existing poles or conduits. Existing poles may be replaced or modified to accommodate the grantee's cable. If there are no existing poles in an area or existing, replacement or modified poles cannot accommodate additional aerial lines, a grantee shall not erect any new poles unless shown to the satisfaction of the city to be necessary for the provision of service after considering the feasibility of an underground installation or a change in the telecommunication system route. 
(c)  Tree trimming plan. Grantees shall submit to the city tree trimming plans for review and approval by the City Engineer. All tree trimming activities shall comply with the approved plans. 
(d)  Approvals and construction plan. 
(1)  Prior to the placement or installation of any part of the telecommunication system in the public rights-of-way, a grantee shall first submit to the city a construction plan consistent with the requirements of the North Carolina Utilities Commission. A grantee shall include in its plans submitted to the city engineer a general description of the facilities proposed to be erected or installed (including whether the cable is wire or fiber optic, but not the size or capacity of the cable), the proposed location of all such facilities, the installation depth and profiles of any underground facilities, and the length of the telecommunication system in the public rights-of-way. Such construction plans shall not be necessary for placement or installation of connections from an existing telecommunication system to a customer or group of customers located on property adjacent to the existing system. 
(2)  A grantee shall not attach any part of the telecommunication system to city maintained facilities, without the prior approval of the city. Prior to receipt of a permit for construction of the telecommunication system from the city engineer, a grantee shall submit to the city evidence of the coordination of construction with other utilities and cable companies along the telecommunication system route. 
(3)  Except in emergencies, no placement or installation of any part of the telecommunication system shall be commenced by any person until construction permits and written approval therefor have been received from the city engineer; provided further, that such permits and approval shall not be unreasonably withheld and action thereon shall be taken within a reasonable period of time. Such permits and approvals shall not be necessary for placement or installation of connections from an existing telecommunication system to a customer or group of customers located on property adjacent to the existing system. 
(e)  Requirement for underground installations. All installations shall be underground in those areas of the city where all utilities and cable serving the area are underground at the time of installation. If technologically feasible and subject to the provisions of a grantee's tariffs on file with the North Carolina Utilities Commission, if any, and any applicable laws or regulations, at such time as all utilities and cable serving an area are required to be placed underground by the city or are placed underground, a grantee shall likewise place its services underground. A grantee's system shall be located underground at the request of an adjacent property owner, if technologically feasible, provided that the excess cost over the aerial location shall be borne by such property owner. 
(f)  Applicable standards. A grantee shall at all times comply with the rules and regulations of the North Carolina Utilities Commission; applicable federal, state and lawful, publicly available local regulations; and the standards as set forth in the franchise and this article. 
(g)  Interference with persons, improvements, public and private property and utilities. A grantee's telecommunication system shall be located, erected and maintained so that such system shall: 
(1)  Not endanger or interfere with the health, safety or lives of persons; 
(2)  Not interfere with any improvements the city, county or state may deem proper to make; 
(3)  Not interfere with the free and proper use of public streets, alleys, bridges, easements or other public ways, places or property, except to the minimum extent possible during actual construction, repair or removal; 
(4)  Not interfere with the rights and reasonable convenience of private property owners, except to the minimum extent possible during actual construction, repair or removal; and 
(5)  Not obstruct, hinder or interfere with any gas, electric, water or other utilities, cable, telecommunication or telephone facilities located within the city. 
(h)  Excavation and work in public rights-of-way; restoration; damage. 
(1)  If feasible, a grantee shall install cable under pavement, curb, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, or other surfacing in the public rights-of-way by boring, and, where necessary for the protection of existing improvements, a grantee shall install such cable by directional boring. A grantee may excavate or disturb pavement, curb, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, or other surfacing in the public rights-of-way as necessary for placement of underground facilities. Manholes, handholes and markers may be visible, but shall not extend above grade in residential areas unless approved by the city engineer. 
(2)  Excavations or borings made by a grantee in the public rights-of-way, pursuant to the franchise shall be made in compliance with the lawful, publicly available ordinances and regulations of the city in effect at the time of such excavation, but only to the extent such ordinances and regulations are not contrary to specific requirements imposed upon the grantee by the North Carolina Utilities Commission. 
(3)  Prior to any excavation or boring in the public rights-of-way, a grantee shall notify all other utilities that may be affected by such excavation or boring of the nature of the work to be performed. The services of North Carolina One-Call may be used to notify or protect its member utilities. 
(4)  In situations deemed by a grantee to constitute an emergency involving a danger to the public health, safety and welfare, a grantee shall notify the city manager and the city engineer of the nature, location and potential hazard. 
(5)  During the installation, repair or removal of a grantee's telecommunication system in the public rights-of-way, the grantee shall provide at all times proper signs, signal lights, flagmen, barricades, and other warning devices for the protection of pedestrian and vehicular traffic in conformance with the latest Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways and amendments or supplements thereto. 
(6)  A grantee shall exercise due care in the operation, installation, alteration, repair or removal of its system. If any utility or property of the city, real or personal, is damaged, impaired or destroyed, ordinary wear and tear excepted, as a result of either the negligent or intentional acts of a grantee, its employees, agents or persons operating under its direction, supervision or control, the grantee shall be liable to the city for such damages, including but not limited to the reasonable cost to repair or replace the utility or property. 
(7)  Immediately after a grantee installs or repairs its system, the grantee shall promptly and properly refill any excavations according to the lawful, publicly available specifications of the city. A grantee shall restore and replace landscaping destroyed, disturbed, or damaged by such work in accordance with the lawful, publicly available specifications of the city and subject to inspection by the city engineer. 
(8)  If the installation, alteration, repair or removal of the telecommunication system in the public rights-of-way requires the temporary removal of bricks, grates, trees or other property or materials belonging to the city, a grantee shall, until such materials are reinstalled, and in the exercise of due care, store said property or materials in a safe place satisfactory to the city to minimize the risk of damage or theft. 
(9)  A grantee shall preserve and protect all trees and shrubbery located in the public rights-of-way from damage by the grantee. A grantee shall comply with the regulations of the city concerning the preservation and protection of trees and shrubs. A grantee shall pay to the city the cost of treating, removing and replacing any tree or shrub in the public rights-of-way which has been damaged or destroyed as a result of the work of the grantee. 
(10)  If a grantee fails, neglects, or refuses to refill such excavations within a reasonable period of time not to exceed two (2) business days except in the event of emergency or other agreed special contingency after the telecommunication system has been installed, repaired or removed, or fails, neglects or refuses to restore the landscaping as herein provided within ten (10) business days except in the event of emergency or other agreed special contingency after the telecommunication system has been installed, repaired or removed, then after notice by the city, the grantee shall pay a deposit to the city in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the estimated cost as determined by the city engineer to do all or such part of said work as may remain undone. The city may also contract with a third party to do all or such part of said work as may remain undone at the cost and expense of the grantee. 
Upon completion of the work by the city and after the total cost has been determined, if the amount of a grantee's deposit exceeds the total cost of the work, any excess will be refunded to the grantee, without interest, within fifteen (15) days of official acceptance of the work by the city. If the amount of a grantee's deposit is less than one hundred (100) percent of the city's final cost, the grantee shall pay to the city within fifteen (15) days of written notification, such additional amounts as will bring the total funds deposited equal to the total cost of the work. All work performed by the city or on the city's behalf shall be promptly inspected by the city, and any moneys due grantees shall be promptly refunded within not more than thirty (30) days of the completion of the work. 
(11)  Whenever the city or the city acting in concert with the North Carolina Department of Transportation or its successor shall construct, maintain or repair any public improvement in a public right-of-way or shall widen, modify, close, relocate, grade or regard any public street, sidewalk, or other public way in which a grantee shall have installed any of its telecommunication system, and such work requires the removal or relocation of the telecommunication system or a portion thereof, it shall be the duty of the grantee, upon reasonable notice by the proper authority, and at no cost to the city, to remove or relocate as necessary its telecommunication system. Provided, however, this requirement shall not preclude the grantee from being eligible for reimbursement from any federal, state, or other funds provided or to be provided by any entity other than the city for locating or relocating, moving or removing grantee's facilities. Sufficient notice of the need to remove or relocate of not less than ninety (90) days will be given to the extent practicable. 
(12)  All necessary easements or rights over and under private property or North Carolina Department of Transportation property shall be arranged for by a grantee. The city neither promises nor contracts to obtain or acquire rights-of-way for the construction, installation, maintenance or operation of a grantee's system. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, §§ 6, 7, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-241. - Service to city. 
    To the extent permitted by law, a grantee shall negotiate terms of service to the city at grantee's most favorable rates for the same services provided to similarly situated customers if provided in the same quantities and for the same periods of time. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 8, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-242. - Transfer of ownership or control. 
    To the extent applicable, a transfer of ownership or control of the telecommunication system shall comply with the North Carolina Utilities Commission Rules and Regulations. A grantee shall promptly notify the city of its intent to transfer ownership or control of the telecommunication system and, if such request is required by the North Carolina Utilities Commission, shall provide the city with a true copy of the request to transfer ownership or control made to the North Carolina Utilities Commission and the Commission's approval of the transfer. A transferee is required to accept the grantee's franchise and all of its terms, provisions, and any amendments within fifteen (15) days of the transfer. Such acceptance shall be in the form approved by the City Attorney and attached to the franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 9, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-243. - Franchise renewal. 
    The city may grant or deny renewal of a grantee's franchise subject to the provisions of the Telecommunication Act of 1996, as amended, or other applicable law. The grantee shall own the telecommunication system, but shall have no property right in the public rights-of-way upon the completion of the franchise term. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-244. - Forfeiture or revocation. 
(a)  Grounds for revocation. Subject to applicable law, the city reserves the right to revoke a franchise and rescind all rights and privileges associated with a franchise in accordance with the procedures set forth in this article in the following circumstances, each of which shall represent a default and breach under the franchise: 
(1)  If a grantee defaults in the performance of any of the material obligations under this article and the franchise. 
(2)  If a grantee fails to provide or maintain in full force and effect the liability and other insurance coverage or the security fund as required in this article. 
(3)  If a grantee violates any orders or rulings of any regulatory body having jurisdiction over the grantee relative to this article or the franchise and after notice thereof shall continue the violation and not remedy the same within sixty (60) days. 
(4)  If a grantee attempts to evade any of the provisions of this article or the franchise or practices any fraud or deceit upon the city. 
(5)  If a grantee becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts or is adjudged bankrupt. 
(6)  If a grantee is no longer regulated either by the North Carolina Utilities Commission or the Federal Communications Commission. 
(7)  If a grantee materially misrepresents facts in the application for or negotiation of the franchise or any extension or renewal thereof. 
(8)  If the transferee of a grantee fails or refuses to accept the franchise as required in this article. 
(b)  Effect of circumstances beyond control of grantee. A grantee shall not be declared at fault or be subject to any sanction under any provision of this article in any case in which performance of any such provision is prevented for reasons beyond a grantee's control. A fault shall not bee deemed to be beyond the grantee's control if committed by a corporation or other business entity in which the grantee holds a controlling interest whether held directly or indirectly. 
(c)  Pending litigation. Pending litigation or any appeal to any regulatory body or court having jurisdiction over a grantee shall not excuse the grantee from the performance of its obligations under this article or the franchise. The city and grantee will abide by the terms of any stay order issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(d)  Procedure prior to revocation. 
(1)  The city shall make written demand that a grantee comply with any material requirement; limitation, term condition, rule or regulation or correct any action deemed cause for revocation. If the failure, refusal or neglect of a grantee continues for a period of thirty (30) days following such written demand, the city shall place its request for termination of the grantee's franchise upon a regular council meeting agenda. The city shall cause to be served upon such grantee at least seven (7) days prior to the date of such council meeting, a written notice of this intent to request such termination, and the time and place of the meeting, notice of which shall be published by the city clerk at least once, seven (7) days before such meeting, in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(2)  The council shall hear any persons interested in the franchise and shall determine, in its discretion, whether or not any failure, refusal or neglect by the grantee was with just cause. 
(3)  If such failure, refusal or neglect by the grantee was with just cause, as reasonably defined by the city, the council shall direct the grantee to comply within such time and manner and upon such terms and conditions as are reasonable. 
(4)  If the council shall determine such failure, refusal, or neglect by the grantee was without just cause, then the council shall, by resolution, declare that the grantee's franchise shall be terminated and the performance bond and letter of credit forfeited. 
(e)  Disposition of system. In the event a grantee's franchise is revoked or otherwise terminated, the city may order the removal of that portion of the telecommunication system the continued presence of which would be contrary to the public safety or welfare, which is located in city owned conduit or duct, or which may interfere with the city's use of the right-of-way within a reasonable period of time. Otherwise, the telecommunication system may be abandoned in place. If any portion of the telecommunication system is abandoned in place, the grantee shall file with the city drawings or maps identifying the location of such abandoned system and if required by the city, shall submit to the city an instrument, satisfactory in form to the city, transferring to the city the ownership of such abandoned portion of the telecommunication system. 
(f)  Restoration of property. In removing its telecommunication system, grantee shall not excavate or disturb pavement, curb, gutters, sidewalks, driveways, or other surfaces in the public rights-of-way. The grantee shall refill, at its own expense, any excavation and boring that shall be made by it and shall leave all public ways in as good a condition or better as that prevailing prior to the grantee's removal of its telecommunication system without affecting the electrical, television, telephone or other telecommunication cable, wires or attachments or the utilities. The city shall inspect and approve the condition of the public rights-of-way and cables, wires, attachments, and poles after removal. The liability, indemnity, insurance, performance bond and letter of credit as provided herein shall continue in full force and effect during the period of removal until full compliance by the grantee with the terms and conditions of this paragraph and the franchise. 
(g)  Abandonment. If such removal and restoration is not completed by grantee within one hundred eighty (180) days after notice by the city, all of the grantee's property remaining in the public rights-of-way shall, at the option of the city, be deemed abandoned and shall, at the option of the city, become the property of the city. 
(h)  Restoration by city; reimbursement of costs. In the event of a failure by the grantee to complete any work required by paragraph (f) above, or any other work required by city ordinance, within the time as may be established and to the satisfaction of the city, the city may cause such work to be done and the grantee shall reimburse the city the cost thereof within fifteen (15) days after receipt of an itemized list of such costs or the city may recover such costs from the security fund provided by grantee. The city may also seek legal and equitable relief to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(i)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, §§ 10-12, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-245. - Receivership and foreclosure. 
(a)  Termination by insolvency. Any franchise shall, at the option of the city, cease and terminate one hundred twenty (120) days after the appointment of a receiver or trustee to take over and conduct the business of a grantee whether in a receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy or other action or proceeding unless such receivership or trusteeship shall have been vacated prior to the expiration of said one hundred twenty (120) days, or unless: 
(1)  Such receiver or trustee shall have, within one hundred twenty (120) days after their election or appointment, fully complied with all the terms and provisions of the franchise, and the receiver or trustee within said one hundred twenty (120) days shall have remedied all defaults under the franchise; and 
(2)  Such receiver, or trustee shall, within said one hundred twenty (120) days, execute an agreement duly approved by the court having jurisdiction in the premises, whereby such receiver or trustee assumes and agrees to be bound by each and every term, provision and limitation of the franchise. 
(b)  Termination by judicial action. In the case of a foreclosure or other judicial sale of the plant, property and equipment of the grantee or any part thereof, including or excluding the franchise, the city may serve notice of termination upon the grantee and the successful bidder at such sale, in which event the franchise and all rights and privileges of the grantee thereunder shall cease and terminate thirty (30) days after service of such notice, unless: 
(1)  The North Carolina Utilities Commission shall have approved the transfer of the franchise, in accordance with its rules and regulations, and 
(2)  Such successful bidder shall have covenanted and agreed with the city to assume and be bound by all the terms and conditions of the franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-246. - Performance bond and letter of credit. 
(a)  Security fund. 
(1)  At the time a franchise is accepted and for the term of the franchise and any extensions or renewals thereof, the grantee shall issue and deliver to, and maintain with the city a letter of credit from a federally-insured banking institution that has an office in the State of North Carolina, in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000) and a performance bond issued by a surety licensed in the State of North Carolina in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000). The bond and letter of credit shall be a security fund. Failure to timely obtain, file and maintain said bond and letter of credit shall constitute a substantial violation within the meaning of this section. 
(2)  The security fund shall serve as security for: 
a.  The faithful performance by a grantee of all the terms and conditions of this article and the franchise; 
b.  Any expenditure, damage or loss incurred by the city occasioned by grantee's unexcused or uncured failure to comply with all lawful rules, regulations, orders, permits and other directives of the city issued pursuant to the franchise; 
c.  The payment by grantee of all liens and taxes, and all damages, claims, costs or expenses which the city has been compelled to pay or incur by reason of any act or default of grantee, and all other payments due the city from grantee pursuant to this article and the franchise; 
d.  The costs and expenses incurred by the city as a result of grantee's abandonment of telecommunication system at any time during the term of the franchise or any extension thereto; and 
e.  The damages or loss of revenue caused by a grantee's assignment of the franchise without the approval of the North Carolina Utilities Commission when such approval is required by law. 
(3)  A grantee shall not use the security fund for other purposes and shall not assign, pledge or otherwise use the security fund as security for any purpose. During the term of the franchise, the letter of credit shall be maintained in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000), and the performance bond shall be maintained in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000). 
(b)  Change in amount of letter of credit. Upon written application by a grantee, the city may, at its sole option, permit the amount of the letter of credit to be reduced or waive the requirements for a letter of credit. Reductions granted or denied upon application by a grantee shall be without prejudice to the grantee's subsequent applications or to the city's right to require the full letter of credit at any time thereafter. However, no application shall be made by a grantee within one (1) year of any prior application. 
(c)  Payment from security fund. 
(1)  If a grantee fails to pay to the city any payment due under the terms of the franchise; or, fails to repay to the city, any damages, costs or expenses which the city shall be compelled to pay by reason of any act or default of the grantee in connection with the franchise, the city may then demand payment from the security fund. 
(2)  The letter of credit shall be made payable upon a draft submitted by the city and accompanied by the written statement of an appropriately authorized official for the city that payment is due the city under the terms of the franchise as a result of a default by grantee. The city shall be the beneficiary under the performance bond. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. 0-2005-19, §§ 1, 2, 3-1-05; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 13, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-247. - Insurance. 
(a)  Certificates of insurance. Not later than sixty (60) days after the effective date of the franchise and thereafter continuously throughout the duration of the franchise and any extensions or renewals thereof, a grantee shall furnish to the city, certificates of insurance, approved by the city, for all types of insurance required under this section. Failure to furnish said certificates of insurance in a timely manner shall constitute a violation of this article and the franchise. 
(b)  Insurance policies. 
(1)  All insurance policies maintained pursuant to the franchise shall contain the following, or a comparable, endorsement: 
It is hereby understood and agreed that this insurance policy may not be canceled by the insurance company and the intention not to renew may not be stated by the insurance company until thirty (30) days after receipt by the city manager, by registered mail or certified mail, of a written notice of such intention to cancel or not to renew. 
(2)  Any insurance policy obtained by a grantee in compliance with this section shall be filed and maintained with the city clerk during the term of the franchise. A grantee shall immediately advise the city of any litigation that may develop that would affect this insurance. 
(3)  All contractual liability insurance policies maintained pursuant to the franchise shall include an endorsement covering the indemnity clause set forth in section 4-248, Indemnification. 
(4)  All insurance policies provided under the provisions of this article or the franchise shall be written by companies authorized to do business in the State of North Carolina and approved by the State Commissioner of Insurance. 
(c)  General liability insurance. 
(1)  A grantee shall maintain, and by its acceptance of the franchise specifically agrees that it will maintain throughout the term of the franchise, commercial general liability insurance insuring the grantee in the minimum amount of five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) combined single limits applicable to claims for bodily injury, personal injury and/or property damage relating to grantee's operations, maintenance and construction under the franchise. 
(2)  Such general liability insurance must include coverage for all of the following: comprehensive form, premises-operations, explosion and collapse hazard, underground hazard, products/completed operations hazard, contractual insurance, broad form property damage, and personal injury. 
(3)  At any time during the term of the franchise, the city may request that the city be named as an additional insured under grantee's commercial general liability insurance policy and the grantee shall comply with such request. 
(d)  Automobile liability insurance. A grantee shall maintain, and by its acceptance of the franchise specifically agrees that it will maintain throughout the term of the franchise, automobile liability insurance for owned, non-owned or leased vehicles in the minimum amount of: 
(1)  One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury and consequent death per occurrence; 
(2)  One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury and consequent death to any one person; and 
(3)  Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for property damage per occurrence. 
(e)  Worker's compensation and employer's liability insurance. A grantee shall maintain and by its acceptance of the franchise specifically agrees that it will maintain throughout the term of the franchise, worker's compensation and employer's liability valid in the State in the minimum amount of: 
(1)  Statutory limit for Worker's Compensation; and 
(2)  One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for employer's liability. 
The grantee may provide evidence of required worker's compensation coverage through certification that the grantee has qualified as a self-insured employer or as a member of a self-insurance fund under North Carolina law. 
(f)  Neither the provisions of this section nor any damages recovered by the city hereunder, shall limit the liability of a grantee under this article or the franchise or for damages. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 14, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-248. - Indemnification. 
(a)  Release, indemnity and hold harmless. Subject to the provisions of grantee's tariffs, if any, on file with the North Carolina Utilities Commission, and provided the act or omission proximately causing such damage or injury was not performed or omitted by the city, or any person or entity for which the city is legally responsible, the grantee shall release, indemnify, and hold harmless the city, its agents, officials, and employees from any and all responsibility or liability for any and all damage or injury of any kind or nature whatsoever (including death resulting therefrom) to all persons, whether agents, officials, employees of the city, or third persons, and to all property, proximately caused by, incident to, and resulting from, directly or indirectly, the design, construction, installation, maintenance, or operation of grantee's telecommunication system upon the city's streets or rights-of-way, whether such claim may be based in whole or in part upon contract, tort (including alleged active or passive negligence or participation in the wrong), or upon breach of any duty or obligation on the part of the grantee, its agents, officials and employees. 
(b)  Claims. The provisions of this section shall include: 
(1)  Any claims for equitable relief or for damages (compensatory or punitive) against the city, its agents, officials, and employees including injury to the business of any claimant and shall include any and all losses, damages, injuries, settlements, judgments, decrees, awards, fines, penalties, claims, costs and expenses. Expenses as used herein shall include without limitation the costs incurred by the city, its agents, officials and employees, in connection with investigating any claim or defending any action, and shall also include reasonable attorneys' fees by reason of the assertion of any such claim against the city, its agents, officials or employees; 
(2)  Any claim for invasion of the right of privacy, for defamation of any person, firm or corporation, or the violation or infringement of any copyright, trademark, trade name, service mark or patent, or of any other right of any person, firm or corporation; and 
(3)  Any claims arising out of grantee's failure to comply with the provisions of any federal, state, or local statute, ordinances or regulation applicable to grantee in its business. 
(c)  Broad construction. Any security fund or insurance protection required by the grantee or the city, shall in no way limit the grantee's responsibility to release, indemnify, keep and save harmless and defend the city as herein provided. The intention of this article is to apply and construe broadly in favor of the city the foregoing provisions subject to the limitations, if any, contained in North Carolina General Statutes, the Rules and Regulations of the North Carolina Utilities Commission, Statutes of the United States, and any applicable federal regulation. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, §§ 15-17, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-249. - Liquidated damages. 
(a)  Liquidated damages. The city and the grantee understand and agree that grantee's violation of any of the time and performance requirements set forth in this article or in the franchise may result in damage to the city and that it is and will be impracticable to determine the actual amount of such damage in the event of delay or nonperformance. Accordingly, subject to applicable law, whenever the city determines, consistent with subsection (b) hereinafter, that the grantee has violated any such requirement, the city may charge the grantee and collect from the security fund, as necessary, the following liquidated damages: 
(1)  For failure to maintain with the city engineer drawings required by section 4-240 of this article, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for each day, or part thereof, such failure occurs or continues. 
(2)  For failure to comply with construction or maintenance standards over which the city has authority and jurisdiction, the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day, or part thereof, such failure occurs or continues. 
(3)  For failure to comply with all conditions of city permits, the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for each day, or part thereof, such failure occurs or continues. 
(b)  Unavoidable delay. No charge shall be made to the security fund for an unavoidable delay. For purposes of this section, "Unavoidable delay" means that period of time during which the grantee is delayed from complying with the time and performance requirements of the franchise because of acts of God, strikes, lockouts or other industrial disturbances, acts of public enemy, orders of any kind of the government of the United States or of the state or any civil or military authority, insurrections, riots, epidemics, landslides, lightning, earthquakes, fires, hurricanes, storms, floods, washouts, drought, arrest, restraining of government and people, civil disturbances, explosions, partial or entire failure of utilities or equipment, shortages of labor, materials, supplies or transportation, or any other similar cause not reasonably within the control of the grantee, but not including reasonably anticipated weather conditions for the city's geographic area or reasonably anticipated difficulties with equipment, suppliers or shippers. 
(c)  Procedure for imposition of liquidated damages. 
(1)  Whenever the city finds that a grantee has violated one or more terms, conditions or provisions of this article or the franchise, a written notice shall be sent to grantee informing it of such violation or liability. The written notice shall describe in reasonable detail the specific violation so as to afford the grantee an opportunity to remedy the violation. Grantee shall begin corrective action within ten (10) business days after receipt of such notice. Grantee may, within ten (10) business days of receipt of notice, notify the city that there is a dispute as to whether a violation or failure has, in fact, occurred; provided, however, that if the last day of the ten-day period falls on a day on which the City Hall is closed, the period shall be extended to include the next day on which City Hall is open for business. Such notice by grantee to the city shall specify with particularity the matters disputed by grantee and shall stay the running of the above-described time. In the event grantee fails to request a hearing, then grantee shall be deemed to have waived any defense whatsoever to the violation alleged. 
a.  The city council shall hear grantee's dispute at a meeting called in a timely manner. Grantee shall be afforded reasonable notice of the meeting and afforded a reasonable opportunity to participate in and be heard at this meeting. The city or its designee shall supplement any decision with written findings of fact. 
b.  If after hearing the dispute the claim is upheld by council, the grantee shall have ten (10) business days from such a determination to remedy the violation or failure. At any time after that ten-day period, the city may draw against the security fund all damages due it as determined by the city. 
(2)  The time for a grantee to correct any violation or liability may be extended by the city if the necessary action to correct such violation or liability is of such a nature or character to require more than ten (10) days within which to perform, provided grantee commenced the corrective action within the ten-day period and thereafter uses reasonable diligence, as determined by the city, to correct the violation or liability. 
(3)  The rights reserved to the city with respect to the security fund are in addition to all other rights of the city whether reserved by the franchise or authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such security fund shall affect any other right the city may have. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, §§ 18, 19, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-250. - Reports and other requirements. 
(a)  Maps and report. Grantee shall maintain with the city engineer and update as necessary a complete set of drawings showing with a reasonable degree of accuracy the location of the grantee's system and any additional information required by section 4-240(d)(1) of this article. To the extent reasonably feasible, the grantee shall provide such drawings in electronic format compatible with the city's geographic information system. 
(b)  Proof of bond, letter of credit and insurance. Grantee shall submit to the city the required performance bond, letter of credit, and certificates of insurance for all policies of insurance required by this section, or certified copies thereof. 
(c)  Public company submissions. If the grantee is a public company regulated by the United States Securities Exchange Commission, or a subsidiary thereof, grantee shall deliver to the city a copy of its, or its parent's, annual reports as and when each is filed at the Securities Exchange Commission. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 20, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-251. - Equal opportunity policy. 
(a)  Equal employment opportunity. The grantee shall afford equal employment opportunity to all qualified persons, and no person shall be discriminated against in employment because of race, color, religion, age, national origin, sex, or handicap. Grantee shall comply with all equal opportunity provisions enacted by federal, state and local authorities, as well as all such provisions contained in this article and the franchise. 
(b)  Local employment and procurement practices. Whenever practicable, economically feasible, and not in violation of constitutional or other legal provisions or requirements, services, personnel, hardware, and supplies for the construction, maintenance and operation of the system shall be procured from the grantee's service area. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 21, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-252. - Notices. 
    Grantee shall maintain within the city, throughout the term of the franchise, an address for service of notices by mail. Grantee shall also maintain within the city a local office and telephone number for the conduct of matters related to the franchise during normal business hours. Provided, however, if the grantee is a public company, or a subsidiary thereof, such address, office and telephone number may be elsewhere within the State of North Carolina. The grantee shall advise the city of such address(es) and telephone numbers and any changes thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 22, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 4-253. - Failure of city to enforce a franchise, no waiver of the terms thereof. 
    The grantee shall not be excused from complying with any of the terms and conditions of this article or the franchise by any failure of the city upon any one or more occasions to insist upon or to seek compliance with any such provisions, terms or conditions. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-254. - No recourse against the city. 
    The grantee shall have no recourse whatsoever against the city or its officials, boards, commissions, agents or employees for any loss, cost, expense or damage arising out of any provision of this article or requirements of the franchise or because of the enforcement thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-255. - Reserved. 
Sec. 4-256. - Severability. 
(a)  Invalidity. If any term, condition or provision of this article or the franchise or the application thereof to any person or circumstances shall, to any extent, be held to be invalid or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder hereof and the application of such term, condition or provision to persons or circumstances, other than those as to whom it shall be held invalid or unenforceable, shall not be affected thereby, and this article and the franchise and all the terms, provisions and conditions thereof shall, in all other respects, continue to be effective and grantee shall comply. In the event that such law, rule or regulation is subsequently repealed, rescinded, amended or otherwise changed so that the provision which had been held invalid or modified is no longer in conflict with the law, rules and regulations then in effect, said provision shall thereupon return to full force and effect and shall thereafter be binding on the grantee and the city. 
(b)  Court action. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, in the event that any court, agency, commission, legislative body or other authority of competent jurisdiction declares any portion of this article or the franchise deemed by the city to be material, invalid in whole or in part; requires grantee to perform any act which is inconsistent with any portion deemed by the city to be material or requires grantee to cease performing any act deemed by the city to be material, the city shall so notify grantee and the city and grantee shall, in good faith, renegotiate that term or those terms of the franchise. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-257. - Rights cumulative. 
    All rights and remedies given to the city and grantee by this article and the franchise shall be in addition to and cumulative with any and all other rights or remedies, existing or implied, now or hereafter available to the city and grantee, at law or in equity, and such rights and remedies shall not be exclusive, but each and every right and remedy specifically given by the franchise or otherwise existing or given may be exercised from time to time and as often and in such order as may be deemed expedient by the city and grantee and the exercise of one or more rights or remedies shall not be deemed a waiver of the right to exercise at the same time or thereafter any other right or remedy. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 4-258. - Acceptance of grantee required. 
    This article and the franchise and all of their terms, provisions, and any amendments shall be accepted by a grantee in writing within fifteen (15) days of the grant of a franchise by the city council and within fifteen (15) days of proper passage of any amendments to this article or the franchise and when accepted shall be filed with the city clerk who shall record the same. Such written acceptance may be upon or at the end of a copy of the franchise ordinance and it shall state and express the acceptance of this article and the franchise and its terms, conditions, provisions, and amendments; and the grantee shall agree in said written acceptance to abide by, to observe and perform the same according to all of its terms and provisions, and shall declare that statements and recitals contained in the article and the franchise are correct and that it has made and does make the agreements and statements set forth in this article and the franchise and accepts the validity of the terms and conditions thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-39, § 1, 4-11-00; Ord. No. O-2006-12, § 23, 1-17-06) 
Chapter 5 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate motor vehicles and bicycles, § 1.4(14), (15); traffic control, Art. XXVII. 
County Code Reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 10. 
Cross reference- Transit authority, § 2-71 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 3; taxicabs, § 4-176 et seq.; smoking in city-owned buses, § 6-11; use of golf carts on municipal golf courses, § 7-4; police department, Ch. 9; temporary closing of streets, § 11-9; parades, § 11-12; signal lights near excavations, § 11-77. 
Related law reference- Wilmington Transit Authority, Art. I. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, G.S. Ch. 20; powers of local authorities, G.S. § 20-169; motor vehicles and traffic in cities, G.S. § 160A-300 et seq. 
Annotation- Under an ordinance requiring the driver of a vehicle on the left at an intersection to yield the right-of-way to a vehicle on the right, this requirement may apply even if the vehicle on the left may have arrived at the intersection a split second or two sooner than the vehicle on the right. Cf. Moore v. Butler, 10 NC App 120, 178 SE2d 35 (1970). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The definitions set out in G.S. section 20-4.01 are hereby adopted as a part of this chapter. 
(b)  In addition to the definitions adopted in subsection (a), the words and phrases defined in this subsection shall have the meaning indicated when used in this chapter unless otherwise specifically provided, or unless otherwise clearly required by the context: 
    Authorized emergency vehicle: A vehicle of the fire department, a police vehicle and any ambulance designated or authorized by the chief of police. 
    Bicycle or bike: A device upon which a person may ride, propelled solely by human power via pedals, having two (2) tandem wheels either of which is twenty (20) inches or more in diameter; provided that for the purpose of this chapter, a tricycle used by an adult shall be deemed a bicycle or bike. The words "bicycle" and "bike" may be used interchangeably. 
    Bike lane: A bikeway which is a restricted portion of the roadway. 
    Bike path: A bikeway which is separated from the roadway. 
    Bike route: A street signed for bicycle use but sharing the roadway with other traffic. 
    Bikeway: Either an off-street area or a portion of a street for the exclusive use of bicycles, including areas for necessary crossflow of motor vehicles at driveways and of pedestrians at crosswalks. 
    Block: A portion of any street located between two (2) adjacent intersections. 
    Boot: Any device that is attached to a vehicle that prevents the vehicle from being driven. 
    Booting service: Any person or other entity who engages in or who owns or operates a business which engages in whole or in part in the booting of vehicles. 
    Bus: Any motor vehicle designed to carry more than nine (9) passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and any motor vehicle, other than a taxicab; designed for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Bus stop: A space reserved for the use of buses while loading or unloading passengers or during layover periods in their operating schedules. 
    Central Business District: The Central Business District Zoning District as established and modified from time to time under Chapter 18 of this Code. 
    Class A vehicle: Any vehicle with a gross weight up to and including nine thousand (9,000) pounds. 
    Commercial vehicle: A vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for the transportation of merchandise. 
    Commercial vehicle loading zone or loading zone: A space reserved for the exclusive use of commercial vehicles during the actual loading or unloading of merchandise. 
    Corner: The point of intersection of the lines of two (2) roadway edges or curb faces extended toward the point of intersection. 
    Crosswalk: That portion of a roadway, either marked or unmarked, included within the prolongation across such roadways of sidewalks or sidewalk areas, at intersections, or any portion of a roadway, other than at intersections, distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by pavement markings. 
    Curb or curbing: A structural element at the edge of an existing or proposed roadway or other way, generally at a higher elevation than the adjacent edge of roadway, installed to deter vehicles and water from leaving the roadway, to otherwise control drainage, to delineate the edge of existing or future roadways or driveways, to present a more finished appearance to the street, to assist in the orderly development of the roadside and to contribute to the structural integrity of the pavement. 
    Driveway, private: The area outside a street intended to serve as ingress and/or egress for vehicular traffic between the property lines and an off-street parking area or other area outside the property lines. 
    Driveway, public: The way or area between the roadway of a public street and other property, designed for, installed for or serving as ingress and/or egress for vehicular traffic between such roadway and an off-street parking area or private driveway. 
    Fire lane: A space reserved for use of fire trucks, ambulances and police vehicles responding to an emergency. 
    Loading zone: See "commercial vehicle loading zone." 
    Mailing zone: A space reserved for the exclusive use of a vehicle while an occupant of said vehicle is inserting mail into a mailbox immediately adjacent to said vehicle. 
    Manager: The city manager or any other person designated by the manager to perform the functions assigned by this chapter to the manager. 
    Manual on Uniform Traffic-Control Devices (MUTCD): The manual published by the United States Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration, Washington, D.C., latest edition, and all errata and supplements thereto and official interpretations and revisions thereof, as well as any North Carolina supplements thereto and interpretations thereof. 
    Median: A channelization island located, generally, along or near the middle of a street or between two (2) roadways or driveways and which is intended to separate opposite directions of vehicular traffic flow. 
    Park or parking: The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily in obedience to traffic regulations, signs or signals, or the involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle. 
    Parking meter: Any mechanical device or meter placed or erected for the regulation of parking by authority of this chapter, installed in such a manner as to indicate, by appropriate legend, the legal parking duration established by the city for the adjacent parking space. 
    Parking space: An area where a vehicle can legally park. 
    Passenger loading zone: A space reserved for the exclusive use of passenger vehicles during actual loading or unloading of a passenger or passengers. 
    Passenger vehicle: A vehicle designed, maintained or used primarily for transportation of people. 
    Pedestrian: Any person afoot or handicapped person in a wheelchair. 
    Plaza: An unpaved area between a sidewalk or sidewalk area and a roadway, along which vertical face curbing is in place. 
    Police officer: Any officer of the police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private parking lot: Any parking lot or area owned by a private entity that provides parking spaces for a fee or requires the permission of the owner, lessee or agent before a person may park at that location. A private parking lot includes vehicle parking spaces in an apartment complex. 
    School bus loading zone or school loading zone: A space reserved for the exclusive use of school buses in the vicinity of a school during the actual loading or unloading of a passenger or passengers or while such bus is remaining in such zone awaiting the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Sidewalk: The pave portion of a street between the curb or edge of the roadway and the adjacent property line, except for any portion of the same which is designated as a bikeway. 
    Sidewalk area: The unpaved area of a street lying between the property line of said street and a line parallel with and five (5) feet from said line, measured perpendicular to the property line, and which is reserved for eventual development as a sidewalk or used as a pedestrian passageway. 
    Sight distance triangle: The area located in a triangle created by connecting the point created by the intersection of curblines, or roadway edges, and the points forty-six (46) feet or other approved distance from said intersection measured along each curbline or roadway edge. 
    Standing: Any stopping of a vehicle, whether occupied or not.
