    Stop: The complete cessation of movement. 
    Stopping: The cessation of movement of a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control device. 
    Taxi or taxicab: A licensed motor vehicle carrying passengers for hire, designed and constructed to seat not more than nine (9) persons and operating upon any street or highway on call or demand. 
    Taxi stand or taxicab stand: An area in a roadway, adjacent to the curb or edge of roadway or in another location, set aside for taxicabs to stand or wait for passengers while the driver remains in or at said vehicle. 
    Tow: To haul, carry, pull along, or otherwise transport or remove a motor vehicle by means of another vehicle. 
    Towing service: Any person or other entity, whether licensed or not, that engages in or who owns or operates a business which engages, in whole or in part, in the towing or removal of motor vehicles for compensation. 
    Traffic: Pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singly or together, while using any street or public vehicular area for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic-control device: Any sign, signal, marking or other device, conforming to the Manual on Uniform Traffic-Control Devices (MUTCD), not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of the city council, or the official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Traffic-control schedules: An official schedule of traffic and parking regulations and restrictions adopted by the city council. 
    Traffic lane: A longitudinal section of roadway or driveway, of a standard width, other than a bikeway, either delineated by pavement markings or other devices, or unmarked, intended to accommodate a single file of moving vehicles. 
    Trespass towing: The towing or removal of a vehicle, without the consent of the vehicle's owner or operator, that is parked on a private parking lot without the property owner or agent's consent. 
    Walkway: A paved or unpaved area or way, outside of a street, intended for exclusive use by pedestrians, including handicapped persons in wheelchairs. Walkways are differentiated from bikeways in that bikeways have signs and/or markings installed to inform persons as to their intended use as bicycle facilities. 
(Ord. of 4-22-86, § 1; Ord. No. 0-2006-43, § 1, 5-1-06) 
Sec. 5-2. - Schedule of traffic and parking regulations. 
(a)  Whenever the provisions of this chapter establish specific traffic and parking regulations and restrictions which are effective only upon certain streets, parts of streets or public vehicular areas which are not generally identifiable, or at certain times or for periods of time which are not generally applicable, such traffic and parking regulations, and the locations and/or times where and when the same are effective shall be set out upon official traffic schedules, as amended from time to time by the manager under the authority of this chapter or the city council, and retained permanently in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  All official traffic schedules adopted under the authority of this chapter are hereby incorporated by reference and shall be as effective as if set out in full herein. Such traffic schedules are authorized pursuant to G.S. section 160A-77(b1). 
Sec. 5-3. - City manager's authority. 
(a)  Under this chapter, and notwithstanding the authority reserved solely to city council in subsection (c) of this section, the city manager is authorized, without further action by city council, to establish, post, and amend all necessary and proper traffic and parking regulations, designations, and related traffic schedules, upon all public streets or public vehicular areas within the city or upon property or rights-of-way belonging to the city. Any permanent amendments that require a change to language set forth in Wilmington City Code must be ratified by city council. This authority includes, but is not limited to, regulations, traffic schedules, and traffic control devices or markings related to: 
(1)  Traffic-control signals; turn on red. (§ 5-6) 
(2)  Stop and yield signs. (§ 5-7) 
(3)  One-way streets or roadways. (§ 5-8) 
(4)  Trucks and large vehicles prohibited on certain streets. (§ 5-27) 
(5)  Administrative amendments or updates to any traffic schedule(s) that do not alter the existing speed limit on any portion of a public street. 
(6)  Parking prohibited on certain streets and public parking lots at certain times. (§ 5-53) 
(b)  The city manager shall notify city council in summary fashion and within a reasonable time of any actions taken pursuant to subsection (a) to establish or amend traffic or parking regulations. 
(c)  The city manager is not authorized to establish, post, or amend any of the below traffic or parking regulations, or any traffic schedules related to them, except on a temporary basis as authorized by section 5-93. Otherwise, city council retains the sole authority to establish or amend the following, and any traffic schedule related to them: 
(1)  Trucks and large vehicles. (Art. II., Div. 2. §5-25 through 5-34, except regulations or amendments related to §5-27) 
(2)  Speed limits. (Art. III. §5-48 through 5-51, except administrative amendments to traffic schedules that do not alter existing speed limits) 
(3)  Controlled parking in residential areas. (Art. IV., Div. 6. §5-89) 
(Ord. No. O-2018-32, § 1, 5-15-18) 
Secs. 5-4, 5-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRAFFIC CONTROL AND TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-6. - Traffic-control signals; turn on red. 
(a)  The manager shall erect or install traffic-control signals to regulate vehicular and pedestrian traffic at the intersections and locations set forth in section 1 of the traffic-control schedules. The effect of such signals on vehicles and pedestrians shall be as provided in G.S. sections 20-158 and 20-172. 
(b)  The manager shall erect a sign or signs notifying motorists that no right turn on red is permitted at the locations set forth in section 2 of the traffic-control schedules. When such signs are erected, no person may make a right turn against a red light contrary to such signs. 
Sec. 5-7. - Stop and yield signs. 
    The manager shall erect stop or yield signs at the locations set forth in section 3 of the traffic-control schedules. The effect of such signs on vehicles and pedestrians shall be as provided in G.S. sections 20-158, 20-158.1 and 20-172. 
Sec. 5-8. - One-way streets or roadways. 
(a)  Whenever a street or roadway is designated one-way and traffic-control devices are installed in accordance with subsection (b), no person may drive a vehicle on such street or roadway except in the direction indicated by the traffic-control devices. (Note: G.S. section 20-165.1 makes it unlawful to drive contrary to a sign erected by the state department of transportation.) 
(b)  The streets or roadways set forth in section 4 of the traffic-control schedules are hereby designated one-way streets or roadways, and the manager shall install appropriate traffic-control devices at every intersection to indicate the direction of lawful traffic movement. 
Sec. 5-9. - Turning; lane use. 
(a)  Whenever, pursuant to subsection (b), appropriate traffic-control devices are installed to indicate that turns or movements are prohibited or required, no person may drive any vehicle contrary to the directions of any such traffic-control device. 
(b)  The manager may install appropriate traffic-control devices to inform drivers of prohibited or permitted turns and/or lane use controls at those locations where there is the need for such controls. 
Sec. 5-10. - Unlawful passing. 
(a)  Whenever, pursuant to subsection (b), appropriate traffic control devices have been installed that clearly indicate that no passing is allowed on a portion of any street, no driver of a vehicle may overtake and pass another on any portion of any street so restricted. (Note: G.S. section 20-150(e) makes it unlawful to pass contrary to signs posted by the state department of transportation.) 
(b)  The manager may install appropriate traffic-control devices to indicate that no passing is allowed whenever and wherever passing would be unsafe. 
Sec. 5-11. - Traffic lanes. 
(a)  The manager is hereby authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(b)  Where such traffic lanes have been marked, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to fail to keep such vehicle within the boundaries of such lane except when lawfully passing another vehicle or preparatory to making a lawful turning movement. 
(c)  Except when entering or leaving a parking space, no person may drive a vehicle on any section of a street marked for parking pursuant to Article IV of this chapter. 
Sec. 5-12. - Riding on part of vehicle not intended for passengers. 
    No person may ride on any vehicle or upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers, nor shall the driver of such vehicle permit a person to so ride. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
Sec. 5-13. - Avoidance of official traffic-control devices. 
    No person may drive any vehicle over and upon private property for the purpose of entering any cross street or intersecting street, or enter such cross street or intersecting street in any manner other than by driving such vehicle over and upon public streets. 
Sec. 5-14. - Blocking intersections and crosswalks. 
    Notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed, no driver may enter an intersection or marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians. 
Sec. 5-15. - Driving over medians. 
    No person shall drive over or across, or stand or walk on, any median, except as a matter of necessity, in the performance of official duties, or where special provisions for pedestrians and/or vehicles exist. 
Sec. 5-16. - Interfering with parades. 
    Whenever processions, assemblages and parades have been authorized on, upon or over certain streets of the city, no person, except participants in such processions, assemblages or parades and operators of emergency vehicles, shall drive or park any vehicles on such streets during such events. 
Secs. 5-17-5-24. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRUCKS AND LARGE VEHICLES 

Sec. 5-25. - Definition. 
    Except as otherwise provided, for the purposes of this division, the term "truck" shall mean trucks that have any of the following characteristics: 
(1)  Tractor-trailer units, with or without trailers attached; 
(2)  Trucks exceeding twenty-five (25) feet in length; 
(3)  Trucks exceeding seven (7) feet in width; or 
(4)  Trucks having a gross weight of two and one-half (21/2) tons or more. 
Sec. 5-26. - Trucks on city streets. 
    Any truck having as its destination any location on a city-maintained street shall proceed on state highway system streets to the point on the state system nearest to its destination and shall use the most direct lawful route to such destination and to return to the state highway system for further travel within or without the city. 
    This section shall not apply to those street corridors designated by the city council and set forth in the traffic control schedules. 
(Ord. No. 0-2003-47, § 1, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 5-27. - Trucks and large vehicles prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (d), no person may drive any truck over the streets set forth in section 5 of the traffic-control schedules. 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (d), no person may drive any vehicle with a gross vehicle weight in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds over the streets designated in section 6 of the traffic-control schedules. 
(c)  No person may drive a truck, bus or other vehicle with the characteristics listed in section 7 of the traffic-control schedules over the corresponding alleys, streets or bridges designated in such schedule. 
(d)  Trucks may use the streets described in subsections (a) and (b) to the extent necessary to reach a destination for the purpose of loading or unloading goods, merchandise or equipment, or as necessitated by street repairs or other emergencies. 
Secs. 5-28, 5-29. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 5-30. - Crosswalk and safety zones. 
(a)  The manager is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Mark crosswalks where there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway; 
(2)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(b)  The effect of such crosswalks upon vehicles and pedestrians shall be as provided in G.S. sections 20-173 and 20-174 and other provisions of law. 
Sec. 5-31. - Soliciting business in streets. 
    In the interest of public safety and in order to protect both pedestrians and motorists, no person shall walk, stand or sit on any traveled portion of a street or on a median, or lean into any traveled portion of a street, and distribute any item or solicit employment, business or contributions from the driver or occupant of any motor vehicle which is located in a traveling lane. 
(Ord. of 6-19-90, § 1) 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 4; sale of merchandise on public property, § 4-101 et seq. 
Secs. 5-32-5-34. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BICYCLES AND BICYCLISTS 

Sec. 5-35. - Application of traffic regulations to riders of bicycles. 
    Every person operating a bicycle upon a highway or bikeway shall be subject to the provisions of Article 3, Motor Vehicle Act of 1937, as found in Chapter 20 of the North Carolina General Statutes, except those provisions of such sections of the General Statutes which by their nature can have no application. 
Sec. 5-36. - Riding on roadways and bikeways. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway or bikeway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway or bikeway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway or bikeway shall ride in a single file except in areas where riding two (2) abreast is permitted. 
(c)  Travel and parking by motor vehicles and travel by pedestrians within bikeways is prohibited when such travel would conflict with the use of the bikeway by a bicyclist. This 
prohibition shall not apply to city buses entering or leaving bus stops, other governmental vehicles required by the nature of their duties to travel within such bikeways, nor to necessary and legal crossflow by vehicles at driveways and by pedestrians at crosswalks. This prohibition shall not apply to travel by pedestrians on that bikeway surrounding Greenfield Lake in the city. 
(d)  Unless specifically designated otherwise, no person shall ride or operate a bicycle on a bikeway in any direction except that permitted for vehicular traffic travelling on the same side of the roadway. 
Sec. 5-37. - Obedience to traffic-control devices generally. 
    A person operating a bicycle on a bikeway shall obey the instructions of official traffic-control devices erected for the purpose of controlling bicycle travel on such bikeway. 
Sec. 5-38. - Riding on bicycles. 
(a)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed or equipped, except that an adult rider may carry a child securely attached to his or her back pack or sling. 
(b)  No person operating a motorcycle or bicycle shall carry any person upon the handlebars, frame or tank of any such motorcycle or bicycle, and no person shall so ride upon any such motorcycle or bicycle. 
Sec. 5-39. - Hands on handlebars. 
    No person, except a lawful passenger on a motorcycle, shall ride a bicycle or motorcycle on any street without having his hands upon the handlebars. 
Sec. 5-40. - Parking. 
    No person shall park a bicycle upon a roadway, sidewalk or bikeway in such a manner as to impede the normal and reasonable movement of vehicles, bicycles or pedestrians. No bicycle shall be secured to any fire hydrant or police or fire call box support. 
Sec. 5-41. - Riding on sidewalk, sidewalk area or walkway. 
    A person riding a bicycle on a sidewalk, sidewalk area or walkway shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before passing any pedestrian. 
Sec. 5-42. - Brakes. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on a dry, level, clean pavement. 
Sec. 5-43. - Racing. 
(a)  Bicycle racing on roadways, sidewalks or bikeways is prohibited except as authorized by this section. 
(b)  Any individual, group of individuals or association desiring to sponsor a bicycle race shall apply to the manager for a permit. No race shall be held on any roadway, sidewalk, bikeway or park walkway without such permit having been issued. Prior to the issuance of such permit the manager shall ensure that the sponsor of such demonstrates that the event will be conducted under conditions which assure the safety of all race participants, spectators or other roadway, sidewalk or bikeway users and that there will be no unreasonable interference with traffic flow which would seriously inconvenience other roadway, sidewalk or bikeway users. 
(c)  By agreement with the chief of police, participants in an approved bicycle highway racing event may be exempted from compliance with any traffic laws otherwise applicable thereto, provided that traffic control is adequate to assure the safety of all highway users. 
Sec. 5-44. - Opening vehicle doors. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to open a door of any vehicle parked adjacent to a bikeway without first determining that such door can be opened without endangering the operator or passenger on a bicycle operating in the adjacent bikeway. 
Secs. 5-45, 5-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TRAFFIC CONTROL PHOTOGRAPHIC SYSTEMS 

Sec. 5-46.1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Traffic control photographic system is an electronic system consisting of a photographic, video or electronic camera and a vehicle sensor installed to work in conjunction with an official traffic control device and to automatically produce photographs, video or digital images of each vehicle violating a standard traffic control. 
(b)  In operation means operating in good working condition. 
(c)  System location is the approach to an intersection toward which a photographic, video or electronic camera is directed and is in operation. 
(d)  Vehicle owner is the person identified by the North Carolina Division of Motor Vehicles as the registered owner of a vehicle. 
(Ord. of 12-7-99, § 1) 
Sec. 5-46.2. - General. 
(a)  The City of Wilmington Public Services and Facilities Department shall administer the Traffic Control Photographic Program and shall maintain a list of system locations where traffic control photographic systems are installed. 
(b)  Any citation for a violation of G.S. 20-158 issued by an officer of the Wilmington Police Department at a system location shall be treated in the same manner as prescribed in this article. 
(c)  The citation shall clearly state the manner in which the violation may be appealed. The citation shall be processed by officials or agents of the City of Wilmington and shall be forwarded by personal service or first-class mail to the owner's address as given on the motor vehicle registration. 
(Ord. of 12-7-99, § 1) 
Sec. 5-46.3. - Offense. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a vehicle to cross the stop line at a system location when the traffic signal for that vehicle's direction of travel is emitting a steady red light, or for a vehicle to violate any other traffic regulation specified in G.S. 20-158. 
(b)  The owner of a vehicle shall be responsible for a violation under this section unless the owner, within twenty-eight (28) days after issuance of the citation, can furnish reliable evidence to officials or agents of the city that the vehicle was in the care, custody, or control of another person at the time of the violation. Evidence furnished by the owner shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  The name and address of the person or entity who, leased, rented, or otherwise had the care, custody, and control of the vehicle at the time of the violation; or 
(2)  An affidavit by the owner stating that, at the time of the violation, the vehicle involved was stolen or was in the care, custody, or control of some person who did not have permission of the owner to use the vehicle. 
(Ord. of 12-7-99, § 1; Ord. of 9-5-00, § 1(a); Ord. No. 0-2001-57B, § 1(a), (b), 8-21-01) 
Sec. 5-46.4. - Penalty. 
    Any violation of section 5-46.3(a) shall be deemed a noncriminal violation for which a civil penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be assessed, and for which no points authorized by G.S. 20-16(c) shall be assigned to the owner or driver of the vehicle, nor insurance points as authorized by N.C.G.S. § 58-36-65. Failure to pay the civil penalty or file an appeal within twenty-eight (28) days after the citation issuance date shall result in an additional penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00). The city may establish procedures for the collection of the civil penalties and may enforce the penalties by a civil action in the nature of a debt. 
(Ord. of 12-7-99, § 1; Ord. of 9-5-00, § 1(b)) 
Sec. 5-46.5. - Appeals. 
    A notice of appeal shall be filed within twenty-eight (28) days after the issuance date of the citation. The failure to give notice of appeal within this time period shall constitute a waiver of the right to contest the citation. Appeals shall be heard through an administrative process established by the City of Wilmington Department of Public Services and Facilities. An individual desiring a hearing must post a bond equal to the amount of the civil penalty before an appeal hearing will be scheduled. The hearing officer's decision is subject to review by the Superior Court of New Hanover County by certiorari proceeding. Any petition for review by the superior court shall be verified and filed with the Clerk of the Superior Court of New Hanover County within thirty (30) days after the hearing officer's decision is delivered to the aggrieved party. The decision of the hearing officer may be delivered to the aggrieved party either by personal service, first class mail, or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. If the decision of the hearing officer is delivered to the aggrieved party by first class mail, three (3) days shall be added to the prescribed period within which the petition must be filed with the Clerk of the Superior Court. 
(Ord. of 12-7-99, § 1; Ord. of 9-5-00, § 1(c); Ord. No. 0-2001-57B, § 1(c), 8-21-01) 
Sec. 5-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPEED LIMITS 

Sec. 5-48. - Speed limit on particular streets. 
(a)  Whenever a speed limit has been established and appropriate traffic-control devices have been installed in accordance with subsections (b) and (c), no person may operate a vehicle on any street in excess of the posted speed, except that no signs shall be required where the speed limit is thirty-five (35) miles per hour. See G.S. sections 20-141(b)(1) and 20-141(e). 
(b)  The speed limits set forth in section 8 of the traffic-control schedules shall be applicable to the streets named therein, and the manager shall install appropriate traffic-control devices to indicate the established speed limit. 
(c)  The speed limits set forth in section 9 of the traffic-control schedules shall be applicable to the streets named therein (which are in the vicinity of a public or private elementary or secondary school), and the manager shall install appropriate traffic-control devices to indicate the established speed limit. 
(1)  The reduced speed limits described in this subsection shall not be in effect for more than five hundred (500) feet on either side of the school property line. 
(2)  [Reserved.] 
(3)  Where flashing warning lights are installed, the signs indicating the effective time of the speed restrictions in the zone shall indicate "WHEN FLASHING." Where no flashing warning lights are installed, the signs indicating the effective time of the speed restrictions in the zone shall indicate "SCHOOL DAYS." 
(Ord. of 4-1-86, § 1) 
Sec. 5-49. - Speed limit for trains. 
    The speed limits for trains set forth in section 10 of the traffic-control schedules shall be applicable to the streets named therein. Wherever a speed limit for trains has been established, no person may operate a railroad engine, locomotive, car or train over the designated streets in excess of the established speed limits. 
Secs. 5-50, 5-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-52. - Parking prohibited in certain locations; traffic-control devices. 
(a)  No person, except the operator of an emergency vehicle during an emergency, a law enforcement officer or other public employees required to so park in the performance of his duties, shall park any vehicle on any street in any of the following locations: 
(1)  In front of a private driveway as provided in G.S. section 20-162; 
(2)  Within fifteen (15) feet of either direction of a fire hydrant or the entrance to a fire station as provided in G.S. section 20-162; 
(3)  Within twenty-five (25) feet of the intersection of curb lines, or if none, then within fifteen (15) feet of the intersection of property lines at an intersection of highways, except that this paragraph shall not apply to buses stopping in properly designated locations; 
(4)  Within an intersection or in front of any alley; 
(5)  Within twenty (20) feet of any ground-mounted traffic signal, stop sign or yield sign; 
(6)  On a sidewalk, sidewalk area or plaza; 
(7)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped, standing or parked at the edge of a curb or street; 
(8)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking or standing would obstruct traffic; 
(9)  Upon any bridge, overpass or other elevated structure or within any tunnel or other underpass structure; 
(10)  On either side of any street at the approaches to a bridge, an underpass or an overhead bridge within fifty (50) feet in either direction of the outer edge of such structure, or within two hundred (200) feet of the outer edge of the Heide Trask drawbridge; 
(11)  On either side of any street leading to a grade crossing within fifty (50) feet of the closest rail; provided that where existing permanent structures are located closer than fifty (50) feet parking may be permitted in front of such structures unless otherwise prohibited, and if such parking does not block the view in either direction of the approach of a locomotive or train; 
(12)  In such a manner as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular travel; 
(13)  On the left side of any street in the direction of vehicular travel, except where permitted on one-way roadways; 
(14)  In any bus stop, except for buses; 
(15)  Within any marked traffic lane; 
(16)  On any median; 
(17)  On any crosswalk; 
(18)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk or handicap ramp; 
(19)  On any street in the area bounded by the Cape Fear River, the north line of Red Cross Street, the east line of Fourth Street between Red Cross Street and Chestnut Street, the west line of Chestnut Street between Fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, the east line of Fifth Avenue between Chestnut Street and Market Street, the south line of Market Street between Fifth Avenue and Second Street, the east line of Second Street between Market Street and Orange Street, the south line of Orange Street between Second Street and Front Street, the east line of Front Street between Orange Street and Ann Street and the south line of Ann Street between Front Street and the Cape Fear River, except entirely within a space which is marked as a parking space, or except in a loading zone of any type during times when the restrictions applicable to such loading zone are not in effect. 
(b)  The manager may install no-parking signs, yellow curb markings or other traffic-control devices, to indicate where parking and standing are prohibited as stated in subsection (a), but enforcement of the provisions of this section is not dependent on the installation of such devices. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-49, § 1, 7-17-18) 
Sec. 5-53. - Parking prohibited on certain streets and public parking lots at certain times. 
(a)  [Reserved.] 
(b)  No person may park any vehicle in any street or public vehicular area in which parking is prohibited. No-parking areas shall be designated by yellow curb markings, no-parking signs, or other traffic control devices which indicate that parking is prohibited in the locations and under the circumstances described therein. The manager or official having jurisdiction shall designate all areas in which parking is prohibited. In addition, the manager shall designate all locations described in sections 11 through 19 of the traffic-control schedules as no-parking areas. 
(c)  Parking is permitted only at specified times or for a specific duration on streets or public vehicular areas which have been designated as limited parking areas. Limited parking areas shall be designated by signs or other traffic-control devices which indicate the circumstances and times during which parking shall be allowed. No person may park a vehicle in any limited parking area except as allowed by the sign or traffic-control device regulating that area. The manager or official having jurisdiction shall designate all areas in which the duration or time of parking is limited. In addition, the manager shall designate all locations described in sections 20 through 30 of the traffic-control schedules as areas in which the duration or times of parking are limited. 
(d)  A change of the position of a vehicle from one point directly to another point within the same block or parking lot shall be deemed one continuous parking period. The parking period shall be as designated on traffic signs erected within the same block or parking lot regulating the parking time limit. 
(Ord. of 7-15-86, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 5-54. - Parking for certain purposes. 
    No person may park any vehicle upon any street while: 
(1)  Washing, servicing or repairing such vehicle, except to the extent necessitated by an emergency; 
(2)  Storing such vehicle for more than forty-eight (48) hours; 
(3)  Using the vehicle for advertising; 
(4)  Transferring merchandise or freight from one vehicle to another, except within a loading zone; 
(5)  Using the vehicle to present shows, exhibitions or entertainment of any kind. 
(Ord. of 3-26-85, § 1; Ord. of 7-23-85, § 1) 
Sec. 5-55. - Parking close to curb; marked spaces. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person may park a vehicle or permit it to stand in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, heading in the direction of lawful traffic movement, and with the wheels of the vehicles within twelve (12) inches of the curb or the edge of the roadway. 
(b)  Any vehicle parking in any marked on-street parking space shall be entirely within the lines or markings. 
Sec. 5-56. - Angle parking. 
(a)  On those streets that have been signed or marked by the manager for angle parking, no person may park a vehicle within an area so marked unless the vehicle is located entirely within a single marked space and with the front tire nearest the curb, not more than twelve (12) inches from the curb. 
(b)  No person shall park any vehicle on any area of any street in the city at an angle to the curb or edge of the roadway unless such angle parking has been designated and marked in such area. 
Sec. 5-57. - Parking large vehicles. 
(a)  Except for the purpose of loading or unloading, no person shall park on the streets in the city, except in designated areas, any motor vehicle, tractor trailer unit, trailer, semitrailer, or towed vehicle, any characteristic of which equals or exceeds a width of seven (7) feet, an overall length of twenty-five (25) feet or a gross weight of two and one-half (21/2) tons. 
(b)  When unloading or loading a vehicle described in this section, no person shall park such vehicle for more than two (2) hours unless the person obtains a permit for loading and unloading as described in subsection (c) below from the chief of police. 
(c)  The chief of police shall issue permits for parking more than two (2) hours for the purpose of loading and unloading when he finds that such parking is necessary to complete the loading or unloading and the extended parking will not endanger the public safety. 
(d)  This section shall apply to the operator of the vehicle, registered owner of the vehicle, lessee of the vehicle or any person who causes the vehicle to be parked in violation of this section in connection with a commercial enterprise or other activity abutting the public street. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 1; Ord. of 5-6-97, § 1) 
Sec. 5-58. - Lights on parked vehicles. 
(a)  The lighting required by G.S. section 20-134 on parked vehicles need not be displayed upon any vehicle when parked in accordance with this chapter upon a street where there is sufficient light to reveal any person within a distance of two hundred (200) feet upon such street. 
(b)  Any lighted headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed. 
Sec. 5-59. - Marking vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be lawful for a traffic officer, parking officer or any other appropriate agent of the city to apply a visible mark using chalk, crayon or other nonpermanent material to any tire of any vehicle parked in a time-restricted parking space under the control of the city for the purpose of recording the presence or duration of such vehicle in such space. Vehicles may also be marked by marks which are not visible to the naked eye. 
(b)  No person may remove or attempt to remove or to obscure any markings applied pursuant to this section so as to interfere with the determination of the prior presence or duration of parking of a vehicle in a time-restricted space. 
Sec. 5-60. - Handicapped parking. 
    No person shall park a vehicle in any parking space appropriately designated for the handicapped in any public vehicular area when the vehicle does not display the distinguishing license plate or placard as provided in G.S. section 20-37.6. 
Sec. 5-61. - Limitation of regulations on legal holidays. 
    The following provisions of Article IV, Parking, shall not be effective on the legal holidays of New Year's Day, Martin Luther King Day, Good Friday, Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, Veteran's Day, Thanksgiving Day, Day After Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day and city observed holidays: 
(1)  Provisions regulating the time and duration of parking adopted pursuant to section 5-53. 
(2)  Section 5-63. Parking Lots for Limited Use. 
(3)  Division 3 of this article. 
(4)  Division 4 of this article. 
    In addition, such provision shall not be effective on such dates and times as designated by the city manager during the annual Azalea Festival, Riverfest and Small Business Saturday events. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 2; Ord. No. O-2001-23, § 1, 3-20-01; Ord. No. O-2006-5, § 1, 1-3-06; Ord. No. O-2016-66, § 1, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 5-62. - Parking in the vicinity of certain temporary uses. 
    No person shall park any vehicle on the paved or unpaved portion of the public streets or rights-of-way located within two thousand (2,000) feet measured linearly of the site of a circus, carnival, bazaar, evangelistic, or religious congregation, open lot sale, fair or special entertainment event, or special sale as permitted under section 19-69 of the City Code, if the purpose of such parking is for work or attendance at such events. 
(Ord. of 2-2-93, § 1) 
Sec. 5-62.1. - Passenger loading zones. 
    The following locations are hereby designated as passenger loading zones: 
[Ord. No. O-2013-33 deleted the street previously listed herein.] 
(Ord. of 5-6-97, § 2; Ord. No. O-2013-33, § 1, 5-21-13) 
Sec. 5-62.2. - Parking of large vehicles. 
    Pursuant to section 5-57(a) of the City Code, the following locations are hereby designated for the parking of large vehicles: 
North Fourth Street between Swann Street and Nixon Street. 
North Second Street between Hanover Street and Brunswick Street. 
Water Street, east side, beginning 321 feet south of Grace Street and ending 391 feet south of Grace Street. 
(Ord. of 5-6-97, § 3; Ord. No. O-2013-33, § 2, 5-21-13; Ord. No. O-2016-31, § 1, 4-19-16) 
DIVISION 2. - OFF-STREET PARKING 

Sec. 5-63. - Parking lots for limited use. 
(a)  The manager may mark off and designate parking spaces on property owned by or leased to the city for the use of equipment and vehicles owned or operated by the city, for use by designated city officials or employees, or by such other persons as the manager may determine. The manager may establish policies, procedures, rules or regulations for use of such parking areas, and may provide for the enforcement thereof. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any space on city-owned or leased property or to park any vehicle thereon in violation of this division or any policy, procedure, rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this division. 
(c)  The manager shall have the authority to designate space on such lots as parking meter spaces. Any person parking in a parking meter space shall comply with the provisions of Division 3 of this article. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 3) 
Sec. 5-64. - Public hospitals. 
(a)  The manager is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to designate and mark off access streets, parking areas and other grounds of public hospitals in the city for the regulation of traffic in such areas in the interests of safety, for the purposes of fire protection, for the general health, welfare and well-being of the patients in such hospitals and for the orderly operation of such hospitals. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any vehicle for any purpose other than to receive and discharge persons therefrom on any grounds of any hospital in the city where parking is prohibited, or to park or leave standing any vehicle at any time in any area of limited parking for a period of time longer than the time specified, or to park or leave standing any vehicle in violation of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing any vehicle in the area adjacent to the emergency room at New Hanover County Memorial Hospital, which area is marked "Emergency Room Parking Only." 
(d)  Any law enforcement officer of the city, or any security personnel of any public hospital located in the city is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce the provisions of this section and any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this section. 
(e)  Any special police officer of the hospital is hereby authorized to direct the towing of vehicles parked in violation of this section or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this section. When the parking areas are clearly designated with signs consistent with the requirements of G.S. § 20-219.2 providing notification that vehicles may be towed for violating the parking regulations, the city council hereby determines that the immediate removal of such vehicles may be warranted. The special police officer authorizing the tow shall comply with section 5-115 of this Code. When a vehicle is removed, notice shall be provided in accordance with section 5-116 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 12-13-88, §§ 1, 2; Ord. of 2-18-97, § 1) 
Sec. 5-65. - Parking in designated fire lanes. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of G.S. section 20-162(b), and for the protection and safety of the lives and property of the citizens of Wilmington, there are hereby established certain fire lanes, both on private property which constitutes a public vehicular area as that term is defined by G.S. section 20-4.01(32) (or by a subsequent statute amending this statutory section), and on any public drive, driveway, road, roadway, street, alley or other surface generally used or reserved for the movement or parking of motor vehicles. 
(b)  All fire lane designations shall be made by the manager upon recommendation of the city fire marshal, with the concurrence of the police chief or his designee. Designations shall be clearly marked by appropriate aboveground signs, or signs and pavement markings, and a list of such designations shall be maintained on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  Fire lanes may be designated on any drive, driveway, road, roadway, street, alley or other surface generally used or reserved for the movement or parking of motor vehicles when the parking or placing of vehicles or obstructions in the area designated as a fire lane would interfere with the proper ingress or egress of fire fighting trucks or other emergency vehicles, equipment or personnel. 
(d)  The person or legal entity in possession of the property on which a designation of a fire lane is made shall be responsible for installation and maintenance of the required signs or pavement markings. All signs and pavement markings utilized under the provisions of this division shall be approved by the city. 
(e)  No person shall park a vehicle or permit it to stand, whether attended or unattended, or put or place any other object, structure or obstruction, in a fire lane which has been established and properly marked under the provisions of this section; provided, however, persons loading or unloading supplies or merchandise may park temporarily in a fire lane located in a shopping center or mall parking lot as long as the vehicle is not left unattended. It shall be lawful for governmental vehicles, including municipal transit buses, or nongovernmental emergency vehicles, including rescue squad vehicles, to stop, stand or travel within such fire lanes when required to do so in the performance of their official duties. 
Secs. 5-66, 5-67. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING METERS 

Sec. 5-68. - Authorization; responsibility. 
    The manager shall have the authority and responsibility for the installation, operation, setting of rates and maintenance of parking meters on public streets and on off-street parking facilities operated by the city. Each parking meter so installed shall be capable of displaying a signal indicating that such meter has been activated and of showing the remaining balance of legal parking time, upon the deposit of valid coin or coins of the United States of America. Each meter shall be so designed as to continue in operation from the time of depositing a coin until the expiration of the periods of time fixed by authority of this division and which are posted on the meter or on a sign posted in the vicinity of the meter. In the event any such meter may be deactivated by an appropriate act or agent of the city, then the requirements and provisions of this division shall not apply during the time of such intentional deactivation by the city. 
Sec. 5-69. - Operation of meters. 
    All persons parking a vehicle in a parking meter space shall deposit a valid coin or coins of the United States of America in the adjacent parking meter in order to activate such meter immediately after the vehicle is parked in such parking meter space. Coin or coins of sufficient value may be inserted in such meter at that time to cause the indicator to indicate the maximum permissible legal parking duration permitted for that parking space, or an amount of time less than the maximum allowable time. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit additional coin or coins in the same meter while the same vehicle is still in the same parking meter space adjacent to said meter other than at the initial time of parking of such vehicle in said space. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in any parking meter any slug, device or substitute for coins of the United States of America. The coins required to be deposited in parking meters are for the purpose of activating the meter, and all revenue from the on-street meters is used for traffic and parking control. The purposes of the parking meters are to provide a readily visible means of enforcing the parking duration regulations in effect for the parking space and to facilitate the frequent turnover of space usage. 
Sec. 5-70. - Hours of operation. 
    The hours during which the operation of parking meters is required shall be posted by the city on each meter or may be on a sign near each meter or group of meters. For meters on-street or in off-street parking facilities these hours shall be from 9:00 a.m. to 6:30 p.m., Monday through Saturday. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 4; Ord. No. O-2019-16, § 1, 4-2-19) 
Sec. 5-71. - Loading and unloading of commercial vehicles in parking meter spaces. 
    During the act of loading or unloading a commercial vehicle, the operator of such commercial vehicle shall be permitted to park in multiple meter spaces to complete the loading or unloading of such vehicle without being required to deposit coins in the meters between the hours of 5:00 p.m. to 10:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 0-2004-107, § 1, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 5-72. - Parking without depositing coins. 
    No person shall cause or permit any vehicle registered in his name or which vehicle is under his control to be or remain parked in any parking meter space for any period of time for which any required deposit of coinage into the parking meter shall not have been made. The act of parking in a parking meter space without the meter serving such space having been activated shall be deemed a violation of the overtime parking provisions of this article. 
Sec. 5-73. - Rates. 
    For any vehicle to be deemed legally parking in any on-street or off-street parking meter space, there shall have been deposited in the meter controlling such space, at the initial time of parking of such vehicle, a coin or coins of the denomination or denominations as indicated on said meter and as established in the City of Wilmington Fee Schedule. 
(Ord. No. 0-2004-69, § 1, 8-3-04) 
Secs. 5-74-5-76. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING DECK 

Sec. 5-77. - Illegal use of city parking lot. 
    No person shall knowingly and designedly by means of any forged or counterfeit paper or card or by any false token or other false pretense whatsoever obtain or attempt to obtain the use of city parking lots. 
Sec. 5-78. - Tampering with gate control arms; unlawful use of monthly card. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To deliberately break off gate control arms. 
(2)  To apply any pressure on the downward motion of the gate arm causing it to reopen. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 5) 
Sec. 5-79. - Deck parking fee. 
    Each person parking a motor vehicle in the city parking deck shall pay a fee as provided in the traffic control schedule. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 6) 
Secs. 5-80-5-82. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - LOADING ZONES 

Sec. 5-83. - Generally. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, whenever streets or portions of streets are designated as loading and unloading zones in accordance with the provisions of this article, parking and standing are permitted in those locations, but only in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The manager is hereby authorized to set apart spaces for loading zones, mailing zones, passenger loading zones, school loading zones, taxi stands and other places in which no parking or limited parking is permitted. 
Sec. 5-84. - Passenger loading zones. 
    Whenever a passenger loading zone is designated and signed, no person may park any vehicle in any such zone for any purpose other than the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, and then only for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) minutes. The driver of such vehicle must remain in or at the vehicle. 
Sec. 5-85. - Commercial vehicle loading zones. 
(a)  Whenever a commercial vehicle loading zone is designated and signed, no person may park any vehicle in any such zone for any purpose other than the expeditious loading or pickup of material and goods, or unloading and delivery. No person shall park any vehicle in a commercial loading zone for more than two (2) hours unless the person obtains a permit for loading or unloading from the chief of police in accordance with section 5-57 above. 
(b)  Size restriction: Operators of three-axle vehicles shall not be permitted to load and unload vehicles in any areas along Front Street from Dock Street to Walnut Street between the hours of 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., Monday through Sunday. 
(Ord. of 2-17-87, § 7; Ord. No. 0-2007-25, § 1, 4-17-07) 
Sec. 5-86. - School loading zones. 
    Whenever a school loading zone is designated and signed, no person shall stop or park a vehicle in any such place for any purpose or length of time other than for the purpose of and while actually loading or unloading passengers or while such vehicle is left standing in such school zone awaiting the loading of passengers into such vehicle for a period not to exceed eight (8) consecutive hours, providing, however that if the lengthy parking of such vehicle in such zone constitutes a potential hazard to the general public in the opinion of the manager, then such vehicle may be required by said person to be removed, during hours when the regulations applicable to such zones are in effect. A vehicle commonly known as, and appropriately marked as a school bus shall be the only type of vehicle permitted to stop, stand or park in a school loading zone. 
Sec. 5-87. - Mailing zone. 
    Whenever a mailing zone is designated and signed, no person may park any vehicle in any such zone for any purpose other than while an occupant of such vehicle is actually inserting mail into a mailbox immediately adjacent to said vehicle, unless such vehicle is waiting to approach said mailbox for such purpose. 
Sec. 5-88. - Taxi stand. 
    Whenever a taxi stand is designated and signed, no person may park any vehicle in any such stand for any purpose, other than a taxicab while waiting for passengers and while the driver remains in or at said taxi. 
DIVISION 6. - CONTROLLED PARKING IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS 

Sec. 5-89. - Regulation of controlled parking in residential areas. 
(a)  Purpose. The city council hereby declares that: 
(1)  It is in the best interests of the City of Wilmington to reduce vehicular congestion on residential streets and to facilitate the efficient movement of traffic by providing for residential parking preference during certain hours of the day and days of the week within certain areas meeting the criteria hereinafter set forth; 
(2)  That residential permit parking regulation is necessary to promote the health, safety and welfare of the residents of Wilmington by providing adequate parking spaces for residents adjacent to or close by their place of residence and by separating parking for commercial uses from residential parking; 
(3)  It is in the public interest to reduce hazardous traffic conditions resulting from the use of streets located within congested residential areas for the parking of vehicles by persons using such residential areas to gain access to other places; to protect those areas from unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their residences; to preserve the character of those areas as residential districts; to promote efficiency in the maintenance of those streets in a clean and safe condition; to preserve the value of the property in those areas; to preserve the safety of children and other pedestrians and to promote traffic safety, clean air, and the comfort, health, convenience and welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(b)  Designation of areas. The city council may designate controlled parking in residential areas based on the following minimum criteria as determined in a study by the city manager or his designee. The study shall be initiated in accordance with the procedures set forth in the administrative policy for "Traffic Management in Residential Neighborhoods." 
(1)  The area is contiguous or nearly contiguous area containing streets or parts thereof primarily abutted by property which is zoned residential on the official zoning maps of the City of Wilmington; and 
(2)  For any time period during the week proposed for regulation hereunder, the number of vehicles parked or standing legally or illegally, on the streets in the area is equal to seventy (70) percent or more of the legal on-street parking capacity of the area with twenty-five (25) percent or more of the vehicles parked or standing on the streets in the area being registered in the name of persons not residing in the area; or 
(3)  During any period as described in item (2) above, any nonresident vehicles utilize the parking to patronize commercial establishments in adjacent areas; and 
(4)  The residents of the area have difficulty or are unable to secure adequate on-street parking adjacent to or close by their places of residence because of widespread use of available parking spaces in that area by nonresident transient motorists or the effects of the nonresident parking are detrimental to the residential character of the area; and 
(5)  The residents of the area desire the institution of a parking permit system and have shown a willingness to bear the administrative costs incidental to the issuance of permits authorized by this section. 
(c)  Parking regulations in permit areas. Following the designation of a controlled parking residential area by the city council, the area shall be posted with signs or other traffic control devices indicating the times, locations and conditions under which parking shall be by permit only. No person shall park any vehicle in a designated controlled parking residential area during the hours set forth in the ordinance designating the controlled parking area, unless the vehicle displays a current parking permit for such residential area issued in accordance with this section. 
(d)  Issuance of residential parking permits. Following the designation of a controlled parking residential area, the chief of police or his designee shall issue appropriate residential parking permits. A resident of a controlled parking residential area is eligible to receive one resident parking permit for each vehicle which is principally operated by the resident and one additional resident parking permit per household. The chief of police shall verify the residence address of persons obtaining such permits and shall record on the face of the permit the letter designation of the controlled parking residential area for which issued. As proof of residency, the chief of police may require utility bills, notarized affidavits of the landlord, auto registration cards and other documentation deemed necessary naming the permittee and showing an address within the controlled parking area. The permit shall be valid for a calendar year and shall be renewed for each successive calendar year. 
(e)  Privileges and restrictions on residential parking permits. 
(1)  The holder of a residential parking permit shall be permitted to stand or park a motor vehicle displaying the permit and operated by him in any designated residential controlled parking area during such times and places as the parking of motor vehicles is permitted. A residential parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve to the holder a parking space within a designated controlled parking residential area. 
(2)  A residential parking permit shall not authorize the holder thereof to stand or park a motor vehicle in such places or during such times as the stopping, standing or parking the motor vehicle is prohibited or set aside for specific types of vehicles, nor exempt the holder from the observance of any traffic regulation other than the limitation on parking within the controlled parking residential area. 
(3)  It shall constitute a violation of this section for any person to falsely represent himself as eligible for a residential parking permit or to furnish any false information in an application to the chief of police in order to obtain a residential parking permit. 
(4)  The chief of police is authorized to revoke the residential parking permit of any permittee found to be in violation of this section; and, upon written notification thereof, the permittee shall surrender such permit to the chief of police. Failure, when so requested, to surrender a residential parking permit so revoked shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1-5-88, § 1, Ord. of 10-29-96, § 1) 
DIVISION 7. - UNIVERSITY AREA PARKING ON RESIDENTIAL LOTS 

Sec. 5-89.1. - Area identified. 
    For purposes of this Division 7, the area in which these parking regulations shall be enforced shall be defined as the lots used for residential purposes located on the streets listed in Section 16 of the Traffic Control Schedules. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-61, § 1, 8-7-07) 
Sec. 5-89.2. - Prohibited activity. 
    No owner or tenant of property located within the identified area shall park, stand or allow to park or stand more than two (2) vehicles in the front yard of a dwelling other than those vehicles belonging to or being operated by the owner or a tenant of the dwelling located thereon. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-61, § 1, 8-7-07) 
Sec. 5-89.3 - Presumption of violation. 
    The owner or tenant of property located within the identified area will be presumed to have violated this division when vehicles in excess of those allowed under section 5-89.2 are present and observed by a Code Enforcement Officer or the designee of the City Manager on more than two (2) occasions within a thirty-day period. This presumption shall not include any designated North Carolina state holidays. An owner of any premises subject to this division who is not also an occupant of the premises shall be responsible for any actions by tenants, guests, or other licensees that constitute second or subsequent violations of this division; provided, that no absentee owner shall be liable unless notified of first or previous violations of the division, and further provided that such first or previous violations shall have occurred within the previous twelve-month period. Notice of any first or previous violations pursuant to this paragraph shall be effected by registered or certified mail. No absentee owner may be subjected to criminal liability under this chapter, but shall be subject to civil penalties and equitable relief as provided in section 5-122. This section shall in no way relieve any other person from responsibility for violations of this division. 
(Ord. No. 0-2007-61, § 1, 8-7-07) 
ARTICLE V. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 5-90. - Alteration and removal of violation notice. 
(a)  No person may alter a violation notice, and no person may have in his possession an unlawfully altered notice. 
(b)  No person may remove a violation notice from a vehicle or permit it to be removed, except for the purpose of answering the charge for which it was issued. 
Sec. 5-91. - Towing vehicles. 
    Without limiting the authority conferred in Article VII of this chapter to remove vehicles, members of the police department are hereby authorized to direct the towing of vehicles in accordance with the procedures set forth in Article VII under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, overpass or other elevated structure or within any tunnel or other underpass structure where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; 
(2)  When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic; 
(4)  When a vehicle is left unattended upon a street continuously for more than forty-eight (48) hours; 
(5)  When the driver of a vehicle is taken into custody by a law enforcement office and such vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon the street; 
(6)  When any vehicle is left unattended on a street to be used for a procession, assemblage or parade; 
(7)  When removal is necessary in the interest of public safety because of fire, flood, storm or other emergency. 
(8)  When any vehicle is parked in violation of section 5-57 of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 7-23-85, § 1; Ord. of 2-17-87, § 8) 
Sec. 5-92. - Funeral processions. 
(a)  As used in this section, "funeral procession" means two (2) or more vehicles accompanying the remains of a deceased person when such vehicles have their headlights in operation and random vehicles in the procession display a pennant identifying the vehicles as part of a funeral procession in such manner as to be clearly visible to traffic approaching from any direction. At a minimum, the lead vehicle and the final vehicle of a funeral procession shall bear a pennant as described in the previous sentence. 
(b)  The operator of any motor vehicle traveling on or entering on the streets or highways in the city shall yield the right-of-way to a funeral procession. A funeral procession shall have the right-of-way at any intersection regardless of the method of traffic control which is present or in operation at said intersection. 
(c)  Each driver in a funeral procession shall drive as near to the right hand edge of the roadway as practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as closely as possible consistent with safety. When a driver enters an intersection in a manner inconsistent with the method of traffic control at said intersection, the driver shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any other vehicle or pedestrian upon the roadway. 
(d)  Unless otherwise directed by a police officer, no pedestrian or operator of a vehicle, other than an emergency vehicle described in and operated in conformity with the provisions of N.C.G.S. section 20-156 and 20-157, may go or be driven between the vehicles constituting a funeral procession when such vehicles are in motion. 
(Ord. of 4-28-87, § 1) 
Sec. 5-93. - Temporary regulations. 
    The manager is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of the city and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. 
Secs. 5-94-5-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - REGISTRATION AND LICENSE TAX 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of an ordinance adopted June 24, 1986, deleted former Div. 1, §§ 5-100-5-103, relative to general registration and license tax provisions and enacted in lieu thereof a new Div. 1, §§ 5-100, 5-101 to read as herein set out. Former §§ 5-101-5-103 did not contain history notation and former § 5-100 derived from § 1 of an ordinance adopted June 11, 1985. 

Sec. 5-100. - License tax imposed. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b), each owner of a motor vehicle that displays a current North Carolina State license plate and resides within the city shall pay an annual license tax of five dollars ($5.00) for each such vehicle. Ownership shall be determined annually in accordance with the provisions of G.S. 105-330.3. 
(b)  The requirements of subsection (a) shall not apply to: 
(1)  Motor vehicles stored or operated for demonstration purposes by manufacturers or dealers. 
(2)  Motor vehicles owned by the city, New Hanover County, the State of North Carolina, or the United States of America. 
(3)  Trailers. 
(c)  The term "resides within the city," when referring to motor vehicles, includes but is not limited to the following: 
(1)  Those vehicles owned or principally used by a person who establishes a residence within the city, temporarily or permanently, for a period of thirty (30) days, and which vehicle is used in the city, or normally stored in the city when not in use. 
(2)  Those vehicles used and maintained or normally stored within the city in connection with a business located in the city. 
It shall be a rebuttable presumption that when a vehicle is registered by the North Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles at an address within the city, such address is the place of residence for said vehicle. 
(d)  Effective January 1, 1993, the tax year for the license tax imposed by this section shall be as defined in G.S. 105-330.6. The license tax shall be added to the property tax bill for the motor vehicle and collected by the division of motor vehicles or an agent contracting with the division of motor vehicles. The tax established by this section shall not be delinquent until the property taxes on the motor vehicle included in such bill become delinquent. 
(Ord. of 6-24-86, § 1; Ord. of 4-20-93, §§ 1, 2; Sess. Laws 2005, Ch. 294) 
Sec. 5-101. - Operation of motor vehicle without payment of tax unlawful. 
    No person may operate or maintain within the city any motor vehicle unless the license tax for such vehicle has been paid in accordance with this division. 
(Ord. of 6-24-86, § 1) 
Secs. 5-102-5-104. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 5-105. - Registration-Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any resident of the city to operate or ride a bicycle upon any of the streets, alleys or public ways of the city without obtaining a certificate of registration from the city chief of police and having attached to such a bicycle a decal registration issued by the chief of police in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The city shall provide bicycle registrations, together with a certificate of registration free of charge to residents of the city and at a cost of one dollar ($1.00) to any person living outside the city who wishes to participate in the program. Each bicycle decal registration shall bear a number and each certificate registration shall bear the same number. It shall be the duty of the owner to attach the bicycle decal registration to the frame of each bicycle, and the chief of police shall issue a corresponding certificate of registration. Such bicycle decal registration shall remain attached to the bicycle for which it was issued at all times. The chief of police shall keep a permanent register in which shall be entered the name, address and age of the owner, the number and date of registration and other information as sufficient to identify such bicycle. 
Sec. 5-106. - Same-Removal, mutilation, alteration, etc., of card. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number on a decal registration issued for any bicycle, or the registration card issued with each registration decal, without first registering such bicycle under the provisions of this article. 
Sec. 5-107. - Sale; transfer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or transfer the ownership of any registered bicycle without reporting such sale or transfer to the city chief of police within forty-eight (48) hours after such sale or transfer, and the purchaser or transferee of any such bicycle shall, within five (5) days thereafter, apply to the chief of police for a transfer of such bicycle registration. 
Sec. 5-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ABANDONED, JUNKED AND HEALTH OR SAFETY HAZARD VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of an ordinance adopted May 21, 1991, amended Art. VII, Div. 1 in its entirety to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Div. 1, §§ 5-109-5-114 derived from the original codification and ordinance adopted Dec. 11, 1984, §§ 1, 2; March 26, 1985, §§ 1, 2; July 15, 1986, §§ 1, 2; and Feb. 17, 1989, § 9. 
Section 2 of said ordinance adopted May 21, 1991 provided that a violation of the provisions of Sections 5-111, 5-112, 5-113, or 5-116.1(b) shall subject the offender to the penalties set forth in Section 5-122 of the City Code. 

Sec. 5-109. - Purpose. 
    North Carolina General Statutes Sections 160A-193, 160A-303 and 160A-303.2 authorize the city to regulate, restrain or prohibit abandoned, junked and health or safety hazard vehicles on public and private property within the city's ordinance-making jurisdiction. Pursuant to that authority, the city council finds that such regulation, restraint or prohibition is necessary and desirable to promote or enhance the: 
(a)  Quality of urban attractiveness and the aesthetic appearance of the city; 
(b)  Protection of property values throughout the city; 
(c)  Preservation of the livability and the attractiveness of neighborhoods; 
(d)  Promotion of tourism, conventions and other opportunities for economic development for the city; 
(e)  Attractiveness of the city's thoroughfares and commercial roads which present the primary, public visibility to visitors and to passers-by of the city; and 
(f)  Promotion of the comfort, happiness and emotional stability of the occupants of property in the vicinity of junked motor vehicles. 
(Ord. of 5-21-91, § 1) 
Sec. 5-110. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases shall have the meaning indicated when used in this article: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle: A motor vehicle that (1) is left upon a street or highway in violation of a law or ordinance prohibiting parking, or (2) is left for longer than twenty-four (24) hours on property owned or operated by the city, or (3) is left for longer than two (2) hours on private property without the consent of the owner, occupant or lessee of the property, or (4) is left for longer than seven (7) days on any public street or highway. 
    Authorizing city official: A police officer, code enforcement officer or inspector designated by the city manager to carry out the duties described in this chapter. 
    Health or safety hazard vehicle: A vehicle that has, for a period of more than forty-eight (48) hours, been in a state of disrepair and is incapable of being moved under its own power and is found to be: 
(1)  A breeding ground or harbor for mosquitos or other insects, snails, rats or vermin of any kind; 
(2)  A point of heavy growth of weeds and grass over eight (8) inches in height; 
(3)  A point of accumulation of stagnant water; 
(4)  A point of concentration of gasoline, oil, or other flammable or explosive materials; 
(5)  So located that there is danger of the vehicles falling or turning over; 
(6)  A source of danger for children through entrapment in areas of confinement that cannot be opened from the inside or from exposed surfaces of metal, glass or other rigid materials; or 
(7)  In any other condition detrimental to the public health or safety, as determined by the authorizing city official. 
    Junked motor vehicle: A motor vehicle that does not display a current license plate when the motor vehicle is required by laws of this state to have such a license plate to operate on public roads, and that (1) is partially dismantled or wrecked, or (2) cannot be self-propelled or moved in the manner in which it was originally intended to move, or (3) is more than five (5) years old and appears to be worth less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. of 5-21-91, § 1) 
Sec. 5-111. - Abandoned vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle to cause or allow such vehicle to be abandoned as the term is defined herein. 
(b)  Upon investigation, the authorizing city official may determine that a vehicle is an abandoned vehicle and order the vehicle removed. 
(Ord. of 5-21-91, § 1) 
Sec. 5-112. - Health or Safety hazard vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee, or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after it has been declared a health or safety hazard. 
(b)  Upon investigation, the authorizing city official may determine and declare that a vehicle is a health or safety hazard vehicle as defined above, and order the vehicle removed. 
(Ord. of 5-21-91, § 1) 
Sec. 5-113. - Junked motor vehicle regulated; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to the possession of a junked motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee, or occupant of the real property upon which a junked motor vehicle is located to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after the vehicle has been ordered removed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to have more than one junked motor vehicle, as defined herein, on the premises of public or private property. The single, permitted junked motor vehicle must strictly comply with the location and concealment requirements of this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, person entitled to the possession of a junked motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee, or occupant of the real property upon which a junked motor vehicle is located to fail to comply with the locational requirements or the concealment requirements of this section. 
(d)  Subject to the provisions of subsection (e), upon investigation, the authorized city official may order the removal of a junked motor vehicle as defined in this chapter after finding in writing that the aesthetic benefits of removing the vehicle outweigh the burdens imposed on the private property owner. Such finding shall be based on a balancing of the monetary loss of the apparent owner against the corresponding gain to the public by promoting or enhancing community, neighborhood or area appearance. The following among other relevant factors may be considered: 
(1)  Protection of property values; 
(2)  Promotion of tourism and other economic development opportunities; 
(3)  Indirect protection of public health and safety; 
(4)  Preservation of the character and integrity of the community; and 
(5)  Promotion of the comfort, happiness and emotional stability of area residents. 
(e)  Permitted concealment or enclosure of junked motor vehicles: 
(1)  One junked motor vehicle, in its entirety, can be located in the rear yard of a lot or parcel as defined by the city's zoning ordinance if the junked motor vehicle is entirely concealed from public view from a public street and from abutting premises by an acceptable covering. 
The authorizing city official has the authority to determine whether any junked motor vehicle is adequately concealed as required by this provision. The covering must remain in good repair and must not be allowed to deteriorate. The covering or enclosure must be compatible with the objectives stated in section 5-109 of this article. 
(2)  More than one junked motor vehicle. Any other junked motor vehicle(s) must be kept in a garage or building structure that provides a complete enclosure so that the junked motor vehicle(s) cannot be seen from a public street or abutting property. A garage or building structure means either a lawful, nonconforming use or a garage or building structure erected pursuant to the lawful issuance of a building permit and which has been constructed in accordance with all zoning and building code regulations. 
(Ord. of 5-21-91, § 1) 
Sec. 5-114. - Removal of abandoned, junked or health or safety hazard motor vehicles; pre-towing notice requirements. 
    Except as set forth in section 5-115 below, an abandoned, junked or health or safety hazard vehicle which is to be removed shall be towed only after notice to the registered owner or person entitled to possession of the vehicle. In the case of a health or safety hazard vehicle or a junked motor vehicle, if the names and mailing addresses of the registered owner or person entitled to the possession of the vehicle or the owner, lessee, or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located can be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable diligence, the notice shall be given by first class mail. The person who mails the notice(s) shall retain a written record to show the name(s) and address(es) to which mailed, and the date mailed. If such names and addresses cannot be ascertained or if the vehicle to be removed is an abandoned motor vehicle, notice shall be given by affixing on the windshield or some other conspicuous place on the vehicle a notice indicating that the vehicle will be removed by the city on a specified date no sooner than seven (7) days after the notice is affixed. The notice shall state that the vehicle will be removed by the city on a specified date, no sooner than seven (7) days after the notice is affixed or mailed, unless the vehicle is moved by the owner or legal possessor prior to that time. 
    With respect to abandoned vehicles on private property, junked and health or safety hazard motor vehicles to which notice is required to be given, if the registered owner or person entitled to possession does not remove the vehicle but chooses to appeal the determination that the vehicle is abandoned, a health or safety hazard vehicle or in the case of a junked motor vehicle that the aesthetic benefits of removing the vehicle outweigh the burdens, such appeal shall be made to the city manager in writing. The city manager shall fix a time for the hearing within thirty (30) days of the appeal and further proceedings to remove the vehicle shall be stayed until the appeal is heard and decided. 
(Ord. of 5-21-91, § 1) 
Sec. 5-115. - Exceptions to prior notice requirement. 
    The requirement that notice be given prior to the removal of an abandoned, junked or health or safety hazard vehicle may, as determined by the authorizing official, be omitted in those circumstances where there is a special need for prompt action to eliminate traffic obstructions or to otherwise maintain and protect the public safety and welfare. Such findings shall, in all cases, be entered by the authorizing official in the appropriate daily records. Circumstances justifying the removal of vehicles without prior notice include but are not limited to: 
(a)  Vehicles abandoned on the streets. For vehicles left on the public streets and highways, the city council hereby determines that immediate removal of such vehicles may be warranted when they are: 
(1)  Obstructing traffic, 
(2)  Parked in violation of an ordinance prohibiting or restricting parking, 
(3)  Parked in a no-stopping or standing zone, 
(4)  Parked in loading zones, 
(5)  Parked in bus zones, 
(6)  Parked in violation of temporary parking restrictions imposed under this code, or 
(7)  Meeting any of the circumstances set forth in section 5-91 of this code. 
(b)  Other abandoned or health or safety hazard vehicles.
