Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 3; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 4; motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 5; leaving refuse material on Greenfield Lake property, § 7-25; solid waste receptacles on sidewalks and plazas, § 11-44. 
State Law reference- Littering, G.S. § 14-399; radioactive waste, G.S. § 104E-1 et seq.; solid waste management, G.S. § 130-166.16 et seq.; waste containers on highways, G.S. § 136-18.3; municipal regulation of solid waste, G.S. § 160A-192; abatement of health and safety nuisances, G.S. § 160A-193; public enterprises, G.S. § 160A-311 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Activation fee: Non-refundable service fee charged to establish new solid waste accounts. Fee covers administrative and cart delivery cost. 
    Banned electronics: Discarded TV's, computer equipment (includes laptops, desktops, monitors, video displays, printers, scanners, printer-scanner-fax combos, mice and keyboards). 
    Building materials: Any material such as lumber, brick, plaster, sheetrock, concrete, asphalt, shingles, wire mesh, gutters or other items accumulated as a result of repairs or additions to existing buildings, construction of new buildings or demolition of existing structures. 
    Bulky items: Inorganic items of such volume that they cannot be placed in a roll-out cart for collection, e.g., appliances, furniture, play equipment, and building fixtures. 
    Chronic violator: A chronic violator is a person who owns, rents, occupies or leases property whereupon, in the previous calendar year, the city gave notice of violation at least three (3) times under the provisions of section 10-18 of this Code or article II of this chapter. 
    Banned electronics: Discarded TV's, computer equipment (includes laptops, desktops, monitors, video displays, printers, scanners, printer-scanner-fax combos, mice and keyboards). 
    Garbage: All solid wastes capable of being rapidly decomposed by microorganisms, including but not limited to animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food, excluding sewage and human wastes. 
    Hazardous wastes: Materials such as cleaning fluids, crankcase oils, cutting fluids, paints, solvents, explosives, ammunition, acids, caustics, poisons, drugs, chemical pesticides, radioactive products, infectious or infected materials, offal, and any other material of similar nature. Including any material that may be dangerous to human health or the environment or exhibits the following characteristics: ignitability (i.e., flammable), reactivity, corrosively, and toxicity. 
    Illegal dumping: Illegal dumping is the disposal of any solid waste or refuse on any public street or sidewalk within the city or on any property owned or operated by the city or any other public property, except in properly designated receptacles or any property owned, occupied or leased by a private property owner without the consent of the owner of the property. 
    Industrial waste: All waste, including solids, semi-solids, sludge and liquids resulting directly from industrial, processing or manufacturing operations. 
    Inspector: The person or persons designated by the city manager to perform the duties and responsibilities assigned by this chapter to the inspector. 
    Occupied property or premises: Any property that is inhabited full time or part time or if water usage exceeds the fixed meter charge. 
    Public refuse receptacle: Refuse receptacle designated and maintained by the city to collect refuse for the benefit of the public in transport in order to prevent litter and are not intended for the purpose of depositing household or other trash accumulated from another location. 
    Recyclables: Materials designated by the city's recyclables processing contractor as capable of being sorted, processed, transported and sold to markets for the remanufacture of like or different products. 
    Refuse: Solid waste material consisting of garbage and trash. 
    Regular collection: All city collection services offered recurrently in accordance with preset approved schedules in a manner safe to public health. 
    Roll-out cart: A container of various capacity, having wheels and a hinged lid, issued by the city or by a firm under contract with the city, for the disposal of but not limited to refuse or collection of recyclables as defined herein and prepared in accordance with this article. 
    Separate collection: All collection of specifically defined materials not associated with regular collection practices. 
    Trash: All refuse resulting from the use and maintenance of property, regardless of the nature of the activity thereon, except garbage. 
    Unacceptable materials: Those items or waste products which are not accepted by any of the city's collection programs. 
    Yard waste: Leaves, grass trimmings, shrubs or shrub trimmings, tree trimmings and other plant waste other than garbage. Yard waste is not considered a recyclable. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-2. - Penalties and remedies. 
(a)  A violation of any of the provisions of this chapter may constitute a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in G.S. § 14-4. 
(b)  A violation of article II of this chapter may also be subject the offender to a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00). A violation of any of the other provisions of this chapter may also subject the offender to a civil penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00). If a person fails to pay this civil penalty within ten (10) days after being cited for a violation, the city may seek to recover the penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of debt. 
(c)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter through any appropriate equitable action. 
(d)  Each day that a violation continues after the offender has been notified of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter by using any one (1) or any combination of the foregoing remedies. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-3. - Supervision of collection; rules and regulations. 
(a)  The superintendent of solid waste management, with the approval of the director of public services, shall supervise the collection, removal, disposition, processing and sale of all refuse, bulky items, yard waste, and recyclables. 
(b)  The superintendent of solid waste management and the director of public services, with the approval of the city manager, may prepare and publish policies and procedures for the effective administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations. 
(c)  The city manager and director of public services shall have the authority to vary the level of refuse collection service for experimental purposes and on a temporary basis at the direction of the city council. Service elements that may be altered include, but are not limited to, frequency of collection, container type, and allowable volume per customer per pickup. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-4. - Charges generally. 
    No owner or occupant within the city limits shall be exempt from an approved solid waste collection service. For the service of collecting and disposing of refuse, the owner or occupant of all premises from which refuse is collected by the city shall be charged such rates as may be established, from time to time, by the city council. Such charges may be considered a debt owing to the city from the owner or occupant of the premises and other persons using the disposal area. No occupied premises within the city that have either petitioned the city for solid waste service or on publically maintained streets or roads shall be exempt from the collection and disposal service provided by the city unless it is a service the city does not provide. All owners or occupants of premises within the city shall be subject to the service charges prescribed by the city council, and an adjustment for such charges may be made at the discretion of the city council on recommendation of the city manager. Fees for the collection and disposal of refuse by the city shall be charged to the owner or occupant of all premises in the amount specified in the fee schedule. Occupied property required to be on city solid waste collection services shall not be exempt from city solid waste collection charges. Owners of rental properties shall upon vacancy of property resume financial responsibly of solid waste collection and fees until notification to terminate solid waste by the owner, any solid waste activity shall be deemed an active account. No solid waste services will be provided after tenant and landlord terminate service. All newly activated solid waste accounts will be subjected to an activation fee as prescribed in the fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-5. - Solid waste collection service. 
    Solid waste collection service will consist of at least one (1) collection per week of household refuse, yard waste, and bulky items and bi-weekly collection of recycling, prepared in accordance with this article, and placed in one (1) or more of the appropriate roll-out carts or other approved containers. 
    The superintendent of solid waste management may exempt customers from using the roll-out cart(s) if requiring such use causes a hardship related to the customer's age, an infirmity, or a topographic site restriction or other similar type of hardship. Such exemptions will be recorded in writing and kept in the office of the superintendent of solid waste management. All such exempt customers must comply with the requirements of section 10-8 herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-6. - Special services. 
(a)  The city will collect and dispose of the following properly prepared items on a scheduled basis based on requests for such services from the city's solid waste customers. 
(1)  Bulky item pick up. The city will collect normal household discarded furniture and appliances, including sofas, chairs, beds, refrigerators, washers, dryers, hot water heaters and similar items. Items for collection should only be from the premise served and shall be placed at curbside no earlier than noon the day preceding the scheduled collection. Items on trucks or trailers will not be collected. 
(b)  Dead animals. Small dead animals, except from slaughterhouses and rendering plants, will be collected by the city during normal operating hours provided that, when practical, the bodies are placed in front of the premises upon the grass strip between the street and the sidewalk where such strips exist and they should be placed off that portion of the street right-of-way used by vehicles, pedestrians or used for surface drainage. 
(c)  Tree trunks, limbs, branches, tree trimmings, hedge cuttings, bagged leaves, pine straw and grass clippings stacked in a neat and orderly manner for easy handling at curbside shall be collected at least once per week if limbs are not in excess of six (6) inches in diameter and are not in excess of four (4) feet in length. Yard waste curbside collection for occupant cut material is limited to a total volume of seven (7) cubic yards, measuring five (5) feet wide by three and one half (3.5) feet high by eleven (11) feet long per week. Volume is to include loose and all bagged materials. Small yard waste items shall be separated from household trash and containerized in a bag, box, or container provided by the customer, not to exceed thirty-five (35) gallons or fifty (50) pounds and then placed at the curb. The city will not collect branches, tree trimmings, hedge cuttings and limbs from unimproved property or resulting from land clearing work or from anywhere other than the premise served. Yard waste from tree service companies, landscapers, independent contractors or work performed by non-occupant will not be collected by the city. The use of tarps for containment is not permitted. Yard waste on trucks, trailers, wheel barrows or carts will not be collected. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-7. - Improper preparation. 
    All refuse not prepared in accordance with the provisions of this chapter will not be collected, and it will be the responsibility of the active account holder or the property owner to correct the violation before collection can occur. Upon determination by an inspector, improperly prepared or placed refuse which is located within the public right-of-way, causing a potential public health or public safety hazard notice shall be given to the active account holder, either in person, by telephone or by placing a written notice on the door of the building or residence that the hazard will be abated by the solid waste management division after seventy-two (72) hours and the actual cost incurred by the city in removing or remedying the hazard shall be charge to the active account holder. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-8. - Containers, preparation and storage. 
(a)  Each customer will either be provided a roll-out cart by the city or will be exempted from having to use said roll-out cart as provided for in section 10-5 herein. 
(1)  Carts issued by the city's solid waste management office are the property of the city. City carts must remain at the address where they were issued. No person shall damage, deface or alter the city owned rollout carts. It is the responsibility of the account holder to keep the cart reasonably clean. City has the right to remove the city owned carts and containers when the account is closed. All trash accounts remain active until the carts are collected by the city. 
(2)  Excess household trash that does not fit in the roll out cart requires an authorized City of Wilmington orange extra sticker attached on each bag or box. Stickers can be purchased by contacting the solid waste management office. 
Carts and containers may only hold trash from the premise served. 
Customers using the roll-out cart may not fill the cart in such a manner that the cart lid will not close tightly over the cart body or so full (over one hundred fifty (150) pounds) that the mechanical lifters mounted on refuse packers cannot lift the cart. 
(b)  Customers exempted from using the roll-out cart shall provide for their premises durable metal or plastic containers with tight-fitting covers. Additionally, these containers shall: 
(1)  Be sufficient in number to accommodate the accumulation of refuse between collections. 
(2)  Be of sturdy construction throughout. They shall be made of corrosion resistant metal or plastic. They shall be watertight and have strong handles. The capacity of such containers shall not exceed thirty (30) gallons by volume or seventy-five (75) pounds combined weight when filled. Tight-fitting covers shall be kept on refuse containers at all times except when filling or emptying. A limit of three (3) thirty-gallon containers per residence per collection day shall be allowed. 
(3)  Be maintained in good condition. Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this chapter or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents shall be promptly replaced by a proper container upon receipt of notice to that effect from the superintendent of solid waste management. Failure to replace such nonconforming or defective container within ten (10) days may be sufficient reason for the solid waste management division to collect and dispose of such defective container and to discontinue service until compliance is effected. 
(c)  Pending collection by the city, refuse shall be stored in conformity to the following regulations. 
(1)  Garbage shall be wrapped, bagged, or enclosed in paper or plastic material. All excess liquid shall be drained before such garbage is placed in the container. No liquid waste will be collected by the city. 
(2)  All dangerous trash items and all waste material of a hazardous nature, such as broken glass, light bulbs, sharp pieces of metal, and fluorescent tubes that do not contain mercury shall be securely wrapped to prevent injury to the collection crews. 
(3)  Trash of a hollow or bulky nature shall be flattened out or broken up prior to depositing it in authorized containers. 
(4)  The disposal of fecal matter waste is permitted in roll-out carts. Such waste must be double bagged in a plastic bag and sealed to control odor and inadvertent spillage. 
(d)  Containers other than those described in this section, or containers with orange extra trash stickers attached will be treated as refuse and may be collected by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-9. - Containers for apartments, commercial and industrial establishments. 
    The city will collect refuse from stores, hotels, apartments, multifamily units, condominiums, theaters, office buildings, schools, clubs, commercial establishments, industrial establishments or at any other places in accordance with section 10-5 solid waste collection services. Each customer must have enough city issued roll out carts to accommodate refuse accumulated between pick up dates. All city roll out carts and other refuse must be set out for collection in accordance with section 10-14 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-10. - Solid wastes the city will not collect. 
    The city will not collect the following types of solid wastes, and no person may place any of the following in any container or receptacle intended for collection by the city. 
(1)  Bulky items or any other trash form contracted work or from anywhere other than the premise served or from commercially related activities not named on the account. 
(2)  Hazardous or industrial wastes: No hazardous or industrial waste shall be collected. It shall be the responsibility of the person in possession of the premises where hazardous refuse or industrial waste is generated to see that it is disposed of properly. 
(3)  Contagious diseases refuse: The removal of clothing, bedding or other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious diseases have occurred shall be performed under the supervision and direction of the county health department. 
(4)  Building materials: Building materials from contract work shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor. No new accounts shall be established until such material has been removed by the owner or contractor. Small amounts not associated with contract work such as repairs, alterations, construction and demolition performed by the resident may be picked up by the city. No concrete or bricks, blocks or rocks are accepted by the city solid waste collection program. 
(5)  Human tissues or waste from operation, autopsy or obstetrical procedures or any other material of similar nature. 
(6)  Hot or live coals or burning material. 
(7)  Hypodermic instruments: It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of or discard any hypodermic syringe, hypodermic needle or any instrument or device for making hypodermic injections before first breaking, disassembling, destroying or otherwise rendering such device inoperable and incapable of reuse and safeguarding the disposal thereof by placing such device in either a milk jug, coffee can with a lid or such similar containers so as to avoid the possibility of causing injury to the collection personnel. 
(8)  Paint, other than dry or solidified paint, or liquids of any kind. 
(9)  Electronics banned include discarded TV's, computer equipment (includes laptops, desktops, monitors, video displays, printers, scanners, printer-scanner-fax combos, mice and keyboards). 
(10)  Fluorescent bulbs containing mercury. 
(11)  Bulky waste that has not been scheduled by the customer. 
(12)  Household trash outside the roll out container with no orange extra trash sticker. 
(13)  Trash and garbage or bulky items mixed with organic matter. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-11. - Removal from unimproved premises. 
    Refuse shall not be removed from unimproved property or inactive city solid waste accounts except when such refuse meets the conditions set forth in this chapter, and then not in excessive quantities. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-12. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-13. - Scavenging, private collection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to scavenge, sort, pick through or remove refuse, trash, yard wastes or recyclables stored or set out for collection, or for any person other than the city or its contractors to collect recyclables in the city where those materials have been prepared and set out for collection by the city in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-14. - Collection schedules; routes; placement of containers. 
(a)  The superintendent of solid waste management and the director of public services, with approval of the city manager, may arrange the schedule for the public collections of refuse throughout the city. 
(b)  Alleys will be used as routes for the collection of refuse wherever the physical features of the alley are such that its use is practical for the purpose. Any right-of-way dedicated for public use and lying to the rear or side of any building lot shall be not less than twenty (20) feet in width if such right-of-way is to serve in any capacity for the removal of refuse. Where collection of refuse is made from the side or rear of property, containers shall be placed near the service street. Collections will be made only to the rear of interior property when such service streets are provided and are usable. Where no access road or alley exists behind or beside property from which the city removes refuse, containers shall be placed directly behind the curbing or three (3) feet from the edge of those paved streets having no curbing. All containers and refuse shall be placed in only one (1) location adjacent to the premises served. 
(c)  Roll-out carts and other containers for refuse and recycling shall be set out for collection no sooner than noon the day before those days designated for the premises involved in the schedule provided for in this section. 
(d)  Roll-out carts and other containers for refuse shall be removed from the street or alley by midnight on the scheduled collection day. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-15. - Private collection. 
(a)  Permit: It shall be unlawful for any person not an employee of the city to collect garbage in the city unless: they have a current franchise agreement with New Hanover County and are in compliance with N.C. Division of Waste Management; Solid Waste Rules section .0100 subsection 15A NCAC 13B.0105. 
(b)  Vehicles generally: It shall be unlawful for any person that meets the requirements in subsection (a) to transport garbage over the streets of the city in vehicles that do not meet the standards of N.C. Division of Waste Management; Solid Waste Rule section .0100 subsection 15A NCAC 13B.0105(c) and (d). 
Vehicles which allow spillage of refuse will be considered unsuitable for hauling garbage. 
(c)  Littering and spillage of refuse, generally: It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the private collection or transportation of refuse to cause or allow spillage of refuse resulting from improper use of containers or from the employment of a vehicle not meeting the requirements of subsection (b). Such spillage shall, in addition to any penalty that may be imposed, subject the holder of the permit, as referred to in subsection (a), to revocation of such permit. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-16. - Accumulation of solid wastes prohibited. 
(a)  No person may cause, suffer, or permit refuse to accumulate or remain on premises under his control except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The remaining subsections of this section are not intended to limit the generality of the foregoing. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the general contractor to see that all construction and demolition contractors keep the site in as reasonably clean and litter-free condition as possible for a construction or demolition site. All loose debris, paper, building material waste, scrap building materials and other trash produced by those working on the site shall be containerized or disposed of in any other reasonable manner by the contractor. Dirt, mud, construction materials or other debris deposited upon any public or private property as a result of construction or demolition shall be immediately removed by the contractor. 
(c)  All commercial establishments shall, particularly with respect to their loading and unloading areas, store their refuse in containers so as to eliminate wind driven debris and litter in and about their establishments. Approved methods of containerization include refuse receptacles and bulk containers. Spillage and overflow shall be immediately cleaned up by said establishment when and as it occurs unless caused by the city when servicing approved containers. 
(d)  Parking lots shall be maintained by the person in possession in a clean, litter-free manner, with all trash generated therein containerized and prevented from spreading to adjoining property. It shall be the responsibility of the person in possession of the parking lot to collect deposited refuse and trash on the lot and place it in containers serviced by the city or a private contractor. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-17. - Dumping, littering, or unattended property on public or private property. 
    No person shall place, discard, throw, drop, dump, cause to fall, deposit, or cause to be placed, discarded, thrown, dropped, dumped or deposited any litter, trash or refuse on: 
(1)  Any public street or sidewalk within the city or on any property owned or operated by the city or any other public property, except in properly designated receptacles; or 
(2)  Any property owned, occupied or leased by a private property owner without the consent of the owner of the property. 
No person shall, on any property owned or operated by the city or any other public property, store or leave unattended personal belongings. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-18. - Creation of public nuisances unlawful. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner, lessee or occupant of any property to create, maintain, permit or fail to abate any public nuisance as defined in this Code on such property. 
(b)  Every owner, lessee or occupant of any property within the city shall keep the same clean and clear of all weeds, bushes and any wild growth thereon, including grass over eight (8) inches in height. Every owner, lessee or occupant shall also keep such property free and clear of all filth, open wells or containers, and all refuse materials of every kind and description. 
(c)  As provided in section 11-42 of this Code, the obligations set forth in this section shall extend to the area between the property line of a lot and the curb line or edge of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-19. - Distribution of handbills. 
    No person, firm, corporation or organization shall deposit in, paste on, or attach to any motor vehicle any handbills, advertisements, cards, circulars, leaflets, folders, banners, letters or pamphlets or cause said materials to be deposited in, pasted on or attached to any motor vehicle without the consent of the owner of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-20. - Special regulations for downtown business area. 
(a)  A volume based bag system shall be utilized for the collection of solid waste in the downtown business area ("DBA"). The downtown business area is defined as the area between and including Water Street and Third Street and between and including Red Cross Street and Ann Street. To the extent that there is any conflict between this section and the other provisions of this chapter, this section shall control. 
(b)  All commercial and residential owners and occupants within the DBA shall use the bag system unless such owner and occupants utilize an approved private collection service pursuant to section 10-9 of this chapter. Trash containers of any kind are prohibited on public property including streets, alleys, sidewalks, and curbs except as set forth herein. 
(c)  All refuse, as defined in section 10-1 of this chapter, must be placed in an approved City of Wilmington refuse bag purchased from the city. Residential green bag accounts will be issued one bag voucher per year per account. Residents will be required to present the voucher to receive a two-month supply of twenty (20) green bags. Vouchers become void on August 31 each year. All bags must be securely tied and must not exceed forty (40) pounds each. 
(d)  Bags may be placed at either end of an alley for collection if the owner or occupant has direct access to an alley, and if there is no alley access, bags shall be placed at the curb in front of the main door of the commercial establishment or residence for collection. 
(e)  Bags shall be placed outside for collection no sooner than twenty (20) minutes prior to the scheduled collection. Only the authorized number of bags as set forth in the fee schedule shall be allowed for each scheduled collection. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-21. - Recycling in downtown business area. 
(a)  In addition to the recycling program, owners and occupants in the DBA may recycle corrugated cardboard. The cardboard must be flattened and placed outside for collection on the same schedule as refuse bags. 
(b)  Owners and occupants utilizing and paying for ABC glass recycling collection may place large amounts of glass outside for collection after 2:00 a.m., only on their scheduled collection days. All glass must be placed in city issued blue ABC recycling containers. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Secs. 10-22-10-27. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ABATEMENT OF PUBLIC NUISANCES 

Sec. 10-28. - Public nuisances enumerated. 
(a)  The existence of any of the following conditions on any vacant lot or other parcel of land within the corporate limits whether on public or private property is hereby declared to be dangerous and prejudicial to the public health or safety and to constitute a public nuisance: 
(1)  The uncontrolled growth of weeds or grass to a height of eight (8) inches or more within one hundred (100) feet of any principal structure or public right-of-way; 
(2)  Any accumulation of animal or vegetable matter that is offensive by virtue of odors or vapors or which is inhabited by rats, mice, snakes, or vermin of any kind which is or may be dangerous or prejudicial to the public health; 
(3)  Any accumulation of trash, garbage or other waste not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter; 
(4)  Any accumulation of hazardous refuse or concentration of combustible items such as mattresses, boxes, paper, automobile tires, old clothes, or any other combustible materials or objects of a like nature; 
(5)  Open wells; 
(6)  Any accumulation of stagnant water causing or threatening to cause the inhabitation thereof by mosquitoes; 
(7)  The open storage of any item detrimental to the public health or safety including, but not limited to, any furniture, appliance, ice box, stove, glass, building material or building rubbish; 
(8)  Any condition detrimental to the public health which violates the rules and regulations of the New Hanover County Health Department; and 
(9)  The presence of any debris from the demolition of any structure on the property, including but not limited to, partially demolished walls, foundations, basements, building materials and rubbish, after the cessation of all active demolition activity on the property. 
(10)  Unsecured and deteriorated windows, doors or other openings in dwellings or structures that (a) do not have water or other utility services, or (b) are used or have been used by persons, not residents, as living quarters in the absence of sanitary facilities, or (c) are used or have been used for criminal activity. 
(11)  Graffiti, which is defined as any unauthorized inscription, word, figure, painting or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted, or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of public or private property by any implement, to the extent that graffiti was not authorized in advance by the owner or occupant of the property, or, despite advance authorization, is otherwise deemed a public nuisance. 
(b)  When any of the following conditions exist on a public right-of-way between the property line and the curb or edge of the roadway and threatens, limits, impairs or creates a hazard to the use of the right-of-way by vehicles or pedestrians, such a condition is declared to be dangerous and prejudicial to the public health or safety and to constitute a severe nuisance: 
(1)  Any accumulation of animal or organic matter that is offensive by virtue of odors or which is inhabited by rats, mice, snakes or vermin which may be dangerous to the public health. 
(2)  Any accumulation of trash, garbage or other waste not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Any accumulation of hazardous refuse or concentration of combustible items such as mattresses, boxes, paper, housewares, tires, clothes, or furniture. 
(4)  Any accumulation of appliances, glass, building materials, demolition materials or rubbish. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-29. - Notice and order to abate nuisance. 
(a)  For purposes of this article, the respondent is the person in possession of the property where a public nuisance (as described in section 10-28) is located, as well as the owner of such property, if different from the former. 
(b)  Upon determination by the inspector that there exists on any property conditions constituting a public nuisance (as described in section 10-28), the inspector shall notify the respondent by certified and first class mail of such conditions and shall order the abatement thereof within fifteen (15) days of the date of such notice. If the certified mail notice is unclaimed or refused but the first class mail is not returned within ten (10) days after the mailing, the first class mail shall be sufficient to provide notice. If after due diligence the respondent's correct address cannot be determined, then the required notice shall be posted conspicuously on the offending property. The posted notice shall order the abatement of the nuisance within fifteen (15) days of the posting of the notice. Failure to give notice as set forth herein shall not affect the enforcement of section 10-18 of this chapter. 
(c)  Upon determination by the inspector that there exists on the public right-of-way conditions constituting a severe nuisance, the inspector shall notify the owner of the abutting property of such conditions and shall order the abatement thereof within twenty-four (24) hours of such notice. This notice shall, if feasible, be given by telephone. Whether or not the owner is reached by telephone, notice shall be mailed by first class mail to his last known address unless he or his agent receives this notice in writing. 
(d)  The inspector may notify a property owner who is a chronic violator that if the violator's property is found to be in violation of section 10-18 of this Code or article II of this chapter, the city shall, without further notice in the calendar year in which notice is given, take action to remedy the violation, and the expense of the action shall become a lien upon the property and shall be collected as unpaid taxes. The initial annual notice shall be served by registered or certified mail. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-30. - Appeal. 
(a)  At any time before the expiration of the fifteen (15) days abatement period specified in subsection 10-29(b), the respondent may request a hearing before the city manager to appeal the finding of the inspector that a public nuisance as defined in section 10-28 exists on the premises. Upon completion of the hearing, the city manager shall consider the evidence before him and shall either revoke the initial order, issue a final order which differs from the initial order, or reinstate the initial order as a final abatement order. 
(b)  If the city has caused the abatement of a severe nuisance as defined in subsection 10-28(b), at any time within thirty (30) days of the owner's receipt of a statement of charges from the city for the removal of the conditions, the property owner may request a hearing before the city manager to appeal the charges and the finding of the inspector that a severe nuisance existed on the right-of-way. Upon completion of the hearing, the city manager shall consider the evidence before him and shall either uphold, modify or revoke the charges resulting from the abatement by the city. 
(c)  Any request for a hearing pursuant to this section must be in writing and must be filed in the office of the city manager. The city manager shall fix a time for the hearing, and the initial abatement order or the accrual of interest on the statement of charges shall be temporarily suspended pending such hearing. The hearing must be held by the city manager within thirty-one (31) calendar days following receipt of the request for hearing by the office of the city manager. At the hearing, the individual affected by the order shall be given the opportunity to present evidence to refute the findings which supported the abatement order or the removal of the nuisance condition. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-31. - Abatement of nuisance by city. 
    Upon the occurrence of either of the following conditions: 
(1)  A hearing is requested and held under section 10-30 above resulting in either a final order with modifications or the reinstatement of the initial order as a final order, and such order is not complied with within fifteen (15) days from adjournment of the hearing; 
(2)  No hearing is requested or held, and the respondent having been ordered to abate such public nuisance fails, neglects or refuses to abate or remove the condition constituting the nuisance within fifteen (15) days from the date of said order, or 
(3)  The property owner fails to abate conditions constituting a severe nuisance within ten (10) days of notification of the owner of such conditions; then, the inspector shall cause said condition to be removed or otherwise remedied by having employees of the city go upon said premises and remove or otherwise abate such nuisance under the supervision of an officer or employee designated by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-32. - Charges for abatement by city; lien. 
(a)  The actual cost incurred by the city in removing or otherwise remedying a public nuisance pursuant to section 10-31 shall be charged to the owner of the offending property and shall be a lien upon the land or premises where the public nuisance existed and shall be collected as unpaid taxes, as provided in G.S. § 160A-193. 
(b)  In the event charges for the removal or abatement of a public nuisance are not paid within thirty (30) days after the receipt of a statement of charges from the city, such charges shall bear interest at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum until paid. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Secs. 10-33-10-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY COLLECTIONS 

Sec. 10-36. - Authority of council. 
(a)  When, in the judgment of the city manager, a temporary emergency condition exists which restricts the city from being able to both collect and properly dispose of all refuse normally placed for city collection, the manager shall so inform the city council. The city council may thereafter, by resolution, declare a temporary emergency condition to exist and require all customers of city collection services, hereinafter called "collection customers." to comply with the following emergency requirements. 
(1)  Place garbage in separate refuse containers from trash. 
(2)  Place only containers holding garbage for regular collection. 
(3)  Store trash on the customers' premises in a safe and sanitary manner until the same may be collected by the city. 
(b)  Said requirements will take effect not less than one (1) week following proper notice to all city collection customers. Said notice shall include emergency collection requirements, changes in collection schedules, date requirements take effect and conditions making emergency requirements necessary. When, in the judgment of the city manager, all emergency conditions cease to exist or subside sufficiently for the city to revert to its regular policies, then the manager shall recommend to the city council that the emergency requirements be terminated. The mayor or the city council may thereafter declare that said emergency condition requirements be terminated and the city's regular collection policies be resumed. Said declaration shall be filed in writing in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-37. - Collection of garbage. 
    During emergency conditions, the volume of refuse prepared for regular collection shall be restricted to a maximum of one (1) roll-out cart per week, or three (3) containers if the customer is exempt from or does not receive cart service, each container being limited to a thirty-gallon capacity. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-38. - Storage of trash. 
(a)  All trash stored on premises shall be placed in a durable metal or plastic container or in a plastic bag which shall, when sealed, be both waterproof and fly-tight. All containers shall be kept sealed and may be placed either inside or outside of the structure located on the premises. 
(b)  Prior to placement in a container or bag, the following types of trash shall be prepared in the following manner: 
(1)  Beverage metal cans and beverage bottles must be thoroughly rinsed with water. 
(2)  Beverage metal cans must be crushed flat. 
(3)  Newspapers and magazines must be bundled and tied. 
(c)  Other reasonable requirements necessary to avoid the creation of a public health or safety hazard may also be imposed. 
(d)  Bulky items and yard wastes shall not be placed at the curb during emergency conditions; said refuse shall be stored safely on the customers' premises. 
(e)  During emergency conditions, as defined in this article, the city council is authorized to establish separate collection services for resource recovery purposes. Said services shall be instituted upon adoption of a resolution by the city council, and shall be terminated immediately upon the city council's declaration by resolution that emergency requirements be terminated (section 10-36 of this Code). Said resolution instituting separate collection services shall state specific materials being collected and the frequency of separate collection during the emergency. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-39. - Placement of garbage in containers on city property. 
    During emergency conditions, as defined within this article, it shall be illegal to place any trash, or refuse other than garbage, in any container located on city property. Such containers shall include all roadside containers and all containers located at any city park. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-40. - Regulation of private collection. 
    During emergency conditions, if any person engaged in private collection, who has obtained the proper permit as prescribed by section 10-15 of this Code, (hereinafter called "collector") requests the assistance of the city for disposal of said collector's collected refuse, the city manager is authorized to enter into contract with said collector on an interim basis and under such terms and conditions as will reasonably protect the city and its facilities. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-41. - General. 
(a)  Participation in the recycling program is voluntary and shall be available upon requests of a regular user of the city's solid waste collection service. 
(b)  Properly prepared recyclables set out for collection by the city in accordance with this article are the property of the city; it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation not under contract with or having permission from the city to collect such recyclables in the city. 
(c)  Participants in the voluntary recycling program are subject to the same civil or criminal penalties as set forth in section 10-2. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-42. - Collection of recyclables. 
(a)  Each participant in the recycling program shall be issued a container for disposing of recyclables in accordance with this article. This container shall be referred to herein as the "recycling container." 
(b)  Collection of recyclables will consist of one (1) pick up every other week of properly prepared recyclables. 
(c)  Categories of recyclables that the city will collect shall be designated and may from time to time be changed by the superintendent of solid waste management, who shall take reasonable steps to provide this information to participants in the recycling program. 
(d)  On designated collection days, recyclables shall be placed in the recycling container, which shall be placed at the same location as the roll-out carts used for regular refuse collection. 
(e)  When the volume of recyclables exceeds the capacity of the recycling container, excess recyclables may be placed near the recycling container in a bag or other container in such a manner that it is clear that the container contains recyclables. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 10-43. - Preparation of recyclables. 
(a)  All containers shall be rinsed out or otherwise made free of residue and cardboard should be flattened. 
(b)  Any recyclables not prepared in accordance with this section will not be collected and it shall be the responsibility of the "account customer/owner" to properly prepare and separate unacceptable materials from the recycle container. 
(c)  In the event a repeat offender continues to misuse the recycle containers, the city reserves the right to remove the container and discontinue participation in the recycling program with no reduction in fee. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-46, § 1, 6-16-15)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Penalties and remedies. 
(a)  Unless specifically exempted herein, a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall constitute a misdemeanor, punishable as provided in G.S. § 14-4. A violation of section 11-16 shall not be a misdemeanor but shall be subject to the civil penalties provided below. 
(b)  Except as specifically provided otherwise herein, a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall also subject the offender to a civil penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). A violation of Article V of this chapter shall subject the offender to a civil penalty of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(c)  If any offender fails to pay any civil penalty set forth herein within ten (10) days after being cited for a violation, the city may seek to recover the penalty by filing a civil action in the nature of debt. 
(d)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter through any appropriate equitable action. 
(e)  Each day that a violation continues after the offender has been notified of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(f)  The city may seek to enforce this chapter by using any one or any combination of the foregoing remedies. 
(Code 1962, § 1-6; Ord. of 8-20-91, § 2; Ord. of 5-4-99, § 2; Ord. No. O-2009-8, § 1, 2-3-09; Ord. No. O-2017-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-18-17; Ord. No. O-2018-61, § 2, 10-2-18) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prescribe penalties for breach of ordinances, § 1.4(47). 
State Law reference- Enforcement of ordinances, G.S. § 160A-175. 
Sec. 11-1.1. - References to director or department of public works. 
    Any reference in this chapter to the director of public works or the department of public works shall be deemed a reference to the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. of 8-19-86, § 2) 
Sec. 11-2. - Removal of obstructions and encroachments generally. 
(a)  The city manager, upon receipt of a report of the city engineer that there are obstructions or encroachments upon any of the streets, sidewalks, wharves or other public places in the city, shall consider such report and if he finds that such obstruction does exist and ought to be removed shall direct the city engineer to give written notice to any person causing such obstruction or encroachment to remove same within thirty (30) days, or to appear before the council on a certain date to show cause, if any there be, why such obstruction should not be removed. Upon the owner's failure to remove, on the appointed day the council shall consider the report of the city engineer and determine whether the reported obstruction or encroachment is an obstruction or encroachment and ought to be removed, and if the council shall order such obstruction or encroachment removed, the city clerk shall thereupon, within two (2) days, in writing, notify the chief of police of the acts of the council, and the chief of police shall forthwith notify the owner, or agent of such owner, to conform to the order of the council within ten (10) days from the time such notice is given. If such owner is unknown, or a nonresident, then such notice shall be published three (3) times in some daily paper published in the city. Any person refusing or failing to remove such obstruction or encroachment within ten (10) days after such notice from the chief of police shall be subject to a penalty as provided in section 11-1 for each day such obstruction or encroachment shall continue after the limit fixed for its removal. 
(b)  If any owner fails to remove such obstruction or encroachment within the time limit herein provided, it shall be lawful for the city, through the city engineer, to immediately remove such obstruction or encroachment and the owner of such obstruction or encroachment shall pay to the city the actual cost of the removal of such obstruction or encroachment in addition to the penalty herein provided for. The cost of such removal, if not paid, shall constitute a lien against the property. 
(c)  The requirements of this section are intended to apply to any obstruction of any nature, kind and description upon any street, sidewalk, wharf or any other public place in the city. 
(Code 1962, § 25-20) 
Sec. 11-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-2004-104, § 1, adopted Dec. 14, 2004, repealed § 11-3 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to debris in gutters, catch basins, etc., as enacted by Code 1962, §§ 25-23, 25-23.2. Similar provisions are now located in chapter 18 of this Code. 
Sec. 11-4. - Railing around lot below street level. 
    The owner or agent of every lot, piece or parcel of ground, within the city, that is more than eighteen (18) inches below any street of the city, and bordering thereon, shall erect, and at all times maintain, along the edge of such lot, piece or parcel of land next to such street or sidewalk, a secure railing or fence, sufficiently high and strong enough to keep persons from falling from the street or sidewalk into such low lot. 
(Code 1962, § 25-29) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 16. 
State Law reference- Damaging fences, G.S. §§ 14-144, 14-159. 
Sec. 11-5. - Barbed-wire fences. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct or maintain, on any premises within one foot of any street right-of-way of the city, any barbed wire or barbed-wire fence, except as approved by the city engineer and in such a manner as to protect the public safety. 
(Code 1962, § 25-24) 
Sec. 11-6. - Vaults, basements, etc., under street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, construct or maintain any vault, tank, basement, cellar, elevator or structure of any kind under the street or street right-of-way within the city. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the construction by the city of necessary drain lines and drainage structures for the handling of storm water and sewage waste, or for the distribution of water. This section shall not be construed to prohibit construction by the city of underground conduits as necessary for its fire alarm, police call system and traffic control, nor shall this section be construed to prohibit the installation of underground facilities, including transformer access ways, by public utility companies operating under franchise in the city. Such transformer access ways shall not extend upon the property line more than ten (10) per cent of the width of the street right-of-way and not to exceed ten (10) feet in any case. Before, however, any utility company shall make any excavation within the street rights-of-way of the city, such utility company shall apply for a permit and conform to the provisions of Article V of this chapter. 
(Code 1962, §§ 25-32, 25-33) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 11-7. - Maintenance of cellar doors, covering, etc. 
(a)  Every cellar door, cellar covering, skylight, coal chute or other opening through the pavement or sidewalks of any street of the city which shall have been constructed shall be maintained by the owner in a safe condition which is satisfactory to the city engineer. It is not the city's purpose to allow the construction of new openings in the sidewalk or street areas of the city, but it will allow such openings as presently exist to remain; provided, that they are kept in good and safe condition. Such cellar doors, or cellar coverings shall be placed upon the same level exactly as the surface of such pavement or sidewalk and shall be of approved, substantial materials, fitted to rest upon sills of stone, steel or concrete, fixed in the pavement or sidewalk where there are pavements, and where there are no pavements, the sills of any cellar door shall be so placed as not to project above the surface of such cellar door, which shall be constructed upon the same level with the sidewalk; provided, that within the fire limits of the city, every cellar door or cellar covering shall be constructed of iron or steel or other fireproof material. 
(b)  Where the city engineer serves notice to remove or repair any cellar door or covering which has become in bad repair, and is dangerous to pedestrian safety, the owner or tenant of any building to which such cellar belongs, and for which such door or covering shall have been constructed or made, shall correct such condition within a period of ten (10) days after written notice from the city engineer so to do. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the above provisions of this section 11-7 and section 11-6 of this Code, the city council may approve the reconstruction of stairways accessed through openings in sidewalk areas of the city for buildings constructed before 1961 and located in the area of the city included in the National Registry of Historic places, the Historic District and or Historic District Overlay zones as described in the zoning ordinance and as amended from time to time. Such reopenings shall be approved as encroachments pursuant to section 11-92 of this Code. 
(Code 1962, §§ 6-95, 6-96; Ord. of 6-18-96, § 1) 
Sec. 11-8. - Reserved. 
Sec. 11-9. - Temporary closing of streets, etc. 
(a)  Authority of city manager. The city manager may, when in his judgment the occasion warrants, block off, or cause to be blocked off, any street or sidewalk or any portion of any street or sidewalk, and may allow obstructions on streets or sidewalks for such periods of time as, in his judgment, may be reasonably necessary. The city manager may delegate the authority to block off streets and sidewalks to the various department heads as necessary in the performance of their duties. 
(b)  Obstructions and signs. When any street or portion of the same is blocked off as provided for in subsection (a), it shall be lawful to place in the street at or near the approaches to the blocked off area appropriate traffic-control devices indicating that such street or portion thereof is blocked off, and that motor or other vehicles shall not pass along such street past such traffic-control devices. 
(c)  Vehicles not to be driven into street. When any street or portion of the same has been blocked off as provided for in subsection (a), it shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive such vehicle along such street past such sign and obstruction and into or upon the blocked off area of such street. 
(Code 1962, §§ 25-59-25-61) 
County Code reference- Closure of roads, easements, § 14-16 et seq. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 11-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 0-2004-104, § 1, adopted Dec. 14, 2004, repealed § 11-10 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to numbering of buildings as enacted by Code 1962, §§ 25-51-25-57; as amended. Similar provisions are now located in chapter 18 of this Code. 
Sec. 11-11. - Permit to move buildings. 
(a)  Required. No person shall move, or assist in moving, any structure or building over any street, bridge or paved sidewalk in the city unless a written permit therefor shall have been issued by the city engineer. The city engineer may refuse to grant a permit when, in his opinion, after having examined the object to be moved, it is of such bulk or is of such weight as to constitute an undue hazard to the street pavements, curbs, signs, street plantings or other items within the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Application. Any person desiring a permit as required in subsection (a) shall file an application therefor with the city engineer. Such application shall describe the structure or building intended to be moved, shall set out the route over which the structure or building in question is to be moved and shall contain such other information as may be required by the city engineer. If the structure or building is to be moved over a state-maintained street, the applicant shall provide copies of all applicable state permits to the city engineer, and such state permits shall be considered a part of the permit described in subsection (a). 
(c)  Appeal to council. Upon refusal of the city engineer to issue any permit pursuant to subsection (a), the applicant therefor may, by notice filed with the city clerk within five (5) days after being notified of such refusal, appeal such action to the city council. The city council shall, at its regular meeting following the filing of such notice of appeal, hear evidence upon the application for such permit, and shall either affirm the action of the city engineer or direct that such permit be issued. 
(d)  Contents. A permit for the moving of a structure or building issued pursuant to an application, filed as provided in subsection (b), shall set out the route over which the structure or building in question is to be moved and shall also include such other terms and conditions as the city engineer may deem proper. 
(e)  Bond. The city engineer may require, as a prerequisite to the issuance of a permit pursuant to an application filed as provided in subsection (b), that a satisfactory bond, if required, has been filed, conditioned, among other things, that permittee will pay any and all damages which may happen to any tree, pavement, street or sidewalk or to any awning, wire, traffic-control equipment, fire alarm, police alarm, telegraph or other pole, provided such awnings, wires and poles are in place in accordance with the law governing the same, or to any other thing injured by any such house mover, his agents, employees or workmen; and conditioned, also, that such permittee will save and indemnify and keep harmless the city against all liabilities, judgments, costs and expense which may in any way accrue against the city in consequence of the granting of such permit, and that such permittee will in all things strictly comply with the terms and conditions of his permit. 
(f)  Trimming of trees. As provided in Chapter 7 of this Code, no trees or shrubs in the public right-of-way or plaza shall be trimmed without a permit issued by the superintendent of parks. Whenever it becomes necessary to trim trees or plaza plantings in order to move a structure or building along a street, the permittee shall do such trimming under the supervision of, and to the satisfaction of, the superintendent of parks. Any trees broken or mutilated during the moving of a building shall be reshaped by trained personnel at the expense of the permittee and to the satisfaction of the superintendent of parks. 
(g)  Cutting of wires. Whenever it becomes necessary to adjust or cut wires, when any structure or building is being moved along a street pursuant to a permit as required in subsection (a), the permittee must, prior to the beginning of the movement, make satisfactory arrangements covering the cost of adjusting, cutting and repairing such wires with the owner thereof. 
(Code 1962, §§ 25-62-25-68) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 11-12. - Parades. 
(a)  No parade shall take place within the city without a permit in writing from the city manager, designating the dates and streets over which said parade shall pass. 
(b)  Before any circus, or other agency employing heavy, equipment, shall be allowed the privilege of hauling heavy wagons, equipment and paraphernalia along, through or over any streets in the city, such circus or other activity shall give a cash bond in an appropriate amount determined by the city manager, conditioned that restitution will be made for all streets damaged by such hauling and such heavy loads shall not be hauled over any street except by permit of the city manager designating the streets to be used and the date and hour of the parade. 
(c)  No person shall throw, spray or scatter any substance, object or material on, upon or over any street or adjacent sidewalks or pedestrian areas during the conduct of any parade. No one participating in a parade or proceeding along the route of a parade shall throw, spray or scatter any substance, object or material including any candy, prizes or favors of any kind. 
(Code 1962, § 25-15; Ord. of 1-19-99, § 1) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 11-13. - Obstructing streets, sidewalks, crossings or seating areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct traffic on a street, sidewalk or crossing of the city, or interfere with other persons lawfully using said streets, sidewalks or crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use a bench or other seating area owned or operated by the city so as to interfere with its use by other persons, including but not limited to the storing of any materials thereon. 
(Code 1962, § 25-16; O-2015-01, § 1, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 11-14. - Defacing sidewalk, roadway or curb. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint or place upon any sidewalk, roadway or curb in the city any words, pictures or advertisements of any kind whatsoever, or for any person to cause the same to be done without a permit from the city engineer. 
Sec. 11-15. - Playing ball in streets; use of skates, skateboards and similar devices. 
(a)  No person shall engage in playing softball, baseball, basketball, football, soccer or similar sports upon the public streets of the city. 
(b)  No person shall operate, ride or use any motive device propelled or designed for propulsion by human power upon any public street, public sidewalk, public park or public vehicular area located in the central business district or upon the Riverwalk. The term "motive device propelled or designed for propulsion by human power" includes: tricycles, coasters, scooters, skateboards, roller skates, roller blades, sleds and wagons, but shall not include bicycles as defined in section 5-1 of the Code (when operated on city streets) and wheelchairs or other devices operated or used by handicapped or disabled persons. For the purposes of this section, the central business district shall be the Central Business Zoning District as established and modified from time to time under chapter 18 of this Code, and that area bounded by the western line of Seventh Street, the southern line of Market Street, the western line of Third Street and the northern line of Chestnut Street. For the purposes of this section, Riverwalk, a public park, is defined in section 7-1.1(a) of this Code. 
(c)  No person shall operate, ride or use any motive device propelled or designed for propulsion by human power on any public street outside the central business district except for the purpose of crossing the street. 
(d)  No person shall operate, ride or use any motive device propelled or designed for propulsion by human power on any public sidewalk in a reckless manner or without exercising due care for the safety of other persons using the sidewalk. Any person operating, riding or using any motive device propelled or designed for propulsion by human power on a sidewalk shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the chief of police is hereby authorized and empowered to specifically designate from time to time certain public streets or portions thereof upon which persons may be permitted to operate, ride or use any motive device propelled or designed for propulsion by human power under such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the chief of police to insure the public safety. 
(Ord. of 11-19-96, § 1; Ord. of 6-1-99, § 1; Ord. No. 0-2005-12, § 1, 2-15-05)
